												  As you can see, by my so far 1300 hours (6 man-months of work), I felt there was more to the game than what you could pick out in just a coupla hundred hours of play.  I found so many slight adjustments that occurred whilst I was playing, such as you came in the game in the dry season, as evidenced by the fires visible on the cab ride into town, plus the cab driver's admission that it WAS the dry season.  That meant that the flare gun and Molotov cocktails were at their peak efficiency for destruction, since when the wet season came about three hundred hours later, the grass turned green and your flame and smoke damage were quite a bit reduced.   Also if you timed the moon just right, you could pick a cloudy night for a most stealthy job and have a better chance of completetion.  I found out at 750 hours that after you ride shotgun on that weapons barge across the lake, and you warn the doctor, that you don't have to fight you way thru the town to make it out alive.  You could just hop up on the cart, climb the stall to the tarp above it, jump onto the roof of the clay building just behind the Dr.'s office and make your way to the swamp boats that were moored right there in the garbage cove.    I would pile cars up  in special preset locations and set C4 to explode as I approached the exits, and then had a Liberty Jeep waiting (those are the best armor rating, except for the 3 tonners, I have read others more informed than I say) to ride like a snowplow thru the enemy blasting away. Thank goodness for game saves, those made it possible for me to complete the game in many situations where I, in my mighty inflated ego, thought the only  way through was blasting away and running and dodging like a basketball player making way downcourt.   I do believe that playing the game on Master (Very Hard) is the only way to play, and you should be by the first five hours, unless you are a nubie, it gives the enemy some brains, and they go after you, not just wait to be shot.  Love the way they will ambush and surprize you, call you out.  That you can go back into the first area in FC2 after getting cooler weapons in the second area is a great idea.  Going back and blasting like no tomorrow is a nice way to past time.   Using subtrafuge, and disattraction, with drawing their attention to the other side of the camp and knifing the few left on duty station is a way of penetrating into some camps that you feel just have to be obliterated by grenade-launcher technicals until you realize there is another way, and another, and another ad nauseum.  There are just so many ways to accomplish each mission, with the one where if you kill everyone in the mine, except the bosses in the tin admin shack, they will ply you to let them live and you can  walk right into an office of the enemy with all of your weapons and just blast them to bits, which until then you thought that you needed to be searched and disarmed before entering the mucky-mucks hdqtrs.  The thumbs-up the dude at the door gives you when you arrive to fulfill the promise they gave at the mine is awesome, dude is like, no problem, bro.  If you drive a nade-jeep all the way up the narrow path to the safe house to contact your mercanary friend about the killing of the government minister of censory before having the dejay read the propaganda to kill the medical doctor in his rounds, you can step outside of the safe house right after the meeting and climb directly into the jeep without touching the ground, and blast away over the hillside into the resort area where he is residing with his finger on the cut-off switch in case anyone trys what you are gonna do.  I thought it was easy having a nade-boat fifty feet away in a cove ready to go a hundred feet to blast the resort, but being able to hop outside and complete her or his part of the mission within seconds is majical.  This is perhaps not so much a game as a sort of lifestyle alteration.

r 16, 2015
												The first time I felt bad killing someone in Far Cry 2, it was a death I didn’t see coming. I’d seen plenty of unpredictable, often hilarious things happen as a result of my violent actions -- I once shot a driver who then rolled his truck into a zebra, over a bridge, and into a river. Moments like this get more out of hand in Far Cry 3 and Far Cry 4.But when remembering my truly definitive Far Cry moments, and when asking myself which Far Cry game is best, I always think about Marty Alencar, the friend I murdered.Marty was my first and best Buddy in Far Cry 2’s Africa. He was the man I rescued from a fiery plane crash. The guy who always brought me back to life when I took too many bullets, put a gun in my hand, and stood by my side until everyone around me died.Far Cry 4’s Guns for Hire system operates on a similar idea to Far Cry 2’s Buddy System, allowing you to summon an ally instantly to fight alongside you. But they’re nameless henchmen, expendable fodder I used to deliberately detonate landmines and send to certain death for the sake of distraction. I never cared about any of them. I used them.Compare this to Far Cry 2, where I relied on Marty, approaching him every time I stepped out the door, knowing he’d tell me he had my back, knowing it was true. Marty was a good man, always ready with another option when a mission wasn’t going to benefit me as much as it could. Yes, these “character traits” fed into the gameplay structure and story missions of Far Cry 2, but it convinced me that Marty Alencar was more than a Buddy -- he was a friend.Marty dragged me out of the line of fire and into the bushes when a random group of guys jumped me on the road. Stupid. You never take the road. A gunner on the back of a truck mowed me down while I fell into my own misplaced Molotov flames. Marty hands me a pistol and opens fire. I find a couple grenades, knock the truck around, and finish the job. When it’s all done, I hear Marty screaming for help. I can’t see him.By the time I find his blue smoke streaming out of the woods, he’s grunting incoherently. I kneel down, jab a regenerative needle into his stomach, and wait for him to head home. He doesn’t get up. He’s still wounded, so I put another needle in him. Nothing, but he slows down, and his eyes roll upward. One more needle. Marty’s head hits the ground, and he stops squirming.I overdosed my best friend.The wieght and impact moments like this have is why Far cry 2 is the real gem of the series and how Far Cry was meant to be. The pure unscripted brilliance.

er 25, 2013
												I'm going to begin this review with a confession: Far Cry 2 is my favorite game in the Far Cry series.Since that one was so well received, let me go for a second confession: Far Cry 2 is probably the least popular game in the Far Cry series.It is my favorite game in the series because of the overall "attitude" of the game. It is everything Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon is not. It is the very antithesis of Blood Dragon: Where Blood Dragon revels in being irreverent, ridiculous, and detached from reality, Far Cry 2 is gritty, realistic, and dark. It is a modern retelling of The Heart of Darkness, in which you play a mercenary hunting an arms dealer in a fictional African country, all the while battling malaria.It is not the most open world. You are not a bullet sponge. Health does not regenerate, and in fact guns will jam on you based on how dirty they are. There isn't even a skill tree or a quick melee button (you have to manually switch to your machete). However, it is probably the single most immersive gave I've played in a long time if not ever, and a fantastic story takes you through a unique setting not often seen (or done well) in games.Gameplay: Far Cry 2 is dated. It's not unplayable, but if you've recently played some of the other Far Cry games then the absence of some features is certainly conspicuous. However, the guns have punch, the player is fragile, fire is dangerous (it's a dry African setting), and the game reeks of realism. Yes, reeks. The main reasons people hated this game were because your character has malaria and because guns jam. Guns jamming is avoidable but you do have to address the malaria from time to time. It plays like a survival game, because you have to struggle to win (without it being too punishing). There's no skill tree and you have to really work for your equipment upgrades. While this isn't for everyone, if you go in expecting this kind of gameplay, you're going to enjoy the game more than someone going in blind. 8/10Graphics/Visual Experience: While the game is old, the graphics aren't too bad. I go back and play this every once in a while and I'm blown away by some of the nature scenes. The game is truly impressive when compared to other games released at the time and that gives it some true staying power. The environment is immersive (the first game I ever actually got lost in: The first day I played it, I played it for 12 hours straight) and while it's not in the same way characters in Skyrim have complete lives, it's still capable of sucking you in if you let it. The score that follows accounts for both the game being dated but still capable of impressing me: 7.75/10Sound: The song from the title screen is still on my phone somewhere. Guns don't always have a bassy sound but always feel like they have some punch. Ambient/background noise is done well, gives the environment some life without having wild animals like 3 and 4 do. 7.5/10Replayability: Not as much as the later games in the series. The main draw of 2 is the immersion and story. While the environment can suck you in, it's not particularly fun to explore because you don't get the feeling of missing out on interesting things as you drive from place to place. If you're like me you'll want to play and play until you finish the story, but there is a hard ending and that also kills post-story replayability. 5.5/10How it Runs: It's still a demanding game. I've played games released in late 2015 that made my computer run hot less often than this game. However, there are very rarely spikes in the resources the game needs to play smoothly. Physics aren't too intense, the worst the lag will probably get is when there's a bunch of fire on the screen. This is the first game with fire propagation, which they certainly wanted to show off. They actually had to set a limit because during testing, there were times when the entire in-game world was set on fire without the limit in place.

ry 16, 2014
												Off-roading in Jeeps. Unlimited gunplay. Setting fires that spread with the wind. Hunting down your target with a machete. Firing a mortar into a pack of zebras. There's a reason this game still garners respect and admiration, and retains a cult-following to this day. It's an, "off the beaten path," strategy-laced masterpiece. The gunplay is raw and satisfying. The environments are beautiful. The map is massive.The main complaint thrown at this game is respawning guard posts. The reason so many people hated this mechanic is because they played Far Cry 2 like a Call of Duty title. This game is not about just pressing the X button occasionally in between set-piece action sequences. This game forces you to slow your roll, take out your map, and plan a route to your target. It simply wants you to take your time with it. This is part of the beauty of the game.Each and every situation in Far Cry 2 has unlimited potential. Almost everything happens dynamically. You may have heard the term, "emergent gameplay," being tossed around in the gaming press as of late. Well, Far Cry 2 was ahead of it's time for attempting to show the mainstream what "emergent gameplay" actually is, and in my opinion, the mainstream wasn't quite ready for it when this game released back in 2008. If you end up playing Far Cry 2, make sure you play it on either "Hardcore" or "Infamous" difficulty. It turns the A.I. into what you'd think gangs of vicious mercenaries and cold-blooded killers should be.Just effin' buy it.

1, 2016
												Far Cry 2 is one of the most immersive games I've played. It's a game I've always considered vastly underrated. I would go as far as to say Far Cry 2 is one of my favorite sandbox games period.Unlike most games Far Cry 2 tries to remain topical and relevant to current day events. The game takes place in an unnamed African country. The government has fallen and guns are worth more than human life. You play as one of several would be assassins sent to kill the Jackal, a notorious arms dealer.What Far Cry 2 does probably the best out of most sandbox games is it makes you feel like you live in Africa. The game's hud is minimalistic, your health pickups are syrettes of morphene. You're infected with malaria and regularly come down with a fever requiring constant supplies of medicine to avoid dying from. Your guns visually decay and eventually break apart in your hands. The world beautiful, but is always extremely hostile to the player. With long stretches of open land requiring almost constant access to vehicles and guard checkpoints at every corner forcing the player to massacre their way through. I never feel like I'm ever safe or that I'm ever comfortable when playing this game, and it's something that always fascinates me when I play it. I always feel like I'm perpetually on the brink of death in every firefight and I need to just keep pressing on, keep moving forward, and keep my finger on the trigger. There are hundreds of games that look like you're in a warzone, Far Cry 2 makes you feel like you're in one.

r 24, 2014
												Date of review: 10.24.2014Platform: PC Released in 2008, Far Cry 2 took a sharp turn from the first Far Cry, and threw the player into a much more realistic, grim, fictional African country. Forget the super mutants and crazy scientists, and get prepared for arguably the most authentic game representation of an African civil war.Story:In Far Cry 2 you can choose to be one of 9 pre-created characters, and while the choice itself will not have any real impact on the outcome of the story, the characters have interesting backgrounds and the ability to choose definitely improves the immersion.However, no matter who you choose, you will be a mercenary, sent to assassinate the Jackal, a notorious arms dealer who is arming both warring African factions, the UFLL and the APR… (the remaining characters will also show up in the game, as “buddies”, and they will help you throughout your progress). Of course things will go wrong, very wrong, and you will find yourself in the middle of a bloody war, AND sick with malaria. The story is exciting, and unique. Forget the good guy(s) who fight(s) the honorable war against the evil enemy kind of stuff... In Far Cry 2 everyone is a corrupt, backstabbing son of a b****,  and as you progress through the main plot you will realize that there is no good or bad choice, there is only bad and bad, and there is nothing you can do about it. Definitely not your average approach, but you know you are dealing with something unique when you get a Nietzsche quote right at the beginning of the game…10/10 Visuals:Far Cry 2 could obviously not  keep up with today's AAA games in terms of graphics, but maxed out it still looks very good. The African wilderness is very well depicted and diverse, with deserts, vast savannas, and jungles, and lively with several forms of wildlife running all around the place. The towns are filthy and dilapidated, with signs of poverty and war visible everywhere. On top of that, Far Cry 2 also has a live day-night cycle which is not only visually pleasing, but also adds a lot to the immersion.While I was more than satisfied with the visuals of the Dunia Engine, I did have some problems when enabling DirectX 10, which was causing seemingly random crashes on Windows 7 64 Bit Ultimate. On Windows 8.1 64 Bit Pro the problem disappeared…All in all, nice visuals, with some technical hiccups here and there. Today's computers should run it without any problems even on maximum details (for reference, you can check test system specifications at the bottom of the review).8/10Gameplay:Far Cry 2 follows the path created by the first Far Cry in terms of gameplay, but it also polishes and adds a number of new features to it. The world is truly open and huge (50 square kilometers) and provides a ton of things to do. You get a decently long main story with varied and interesting missions, and plenty of side quest from weapon dealers (who will reward you with new weapons), from buddies (who will reward you with safe house upgrades) and from the locals (who will reward you with malaria medicine). And on top of that, you have a lot of miscellaneous “quests” as well, like diamond searching and outpost scouting.You can probably rush through the game in 15 hours or so, but you can easily spend 50+ hours and still have things to do.But this is an FPS, so what about the weapons? No need to worry, the weapons are also varied (from pistols and sub machine guns to assault rifles, sniper rifles, light machine guns and even exotics such as the flame thrower and the mortar) and provide several ways of combat. It’s up to you to decide whether you will try to dispatch your foes from far or in a bloody close combat. Stealth however didn’t really work for me, and as far as I can tell, the developers didn’t want to make it a really viable option… something I can understand in a way, this is a civil war after all. Still, it’s fun to shoot, the weapons are quite realistic (don’t expect an ArmA type of game though) and the flame thrower is really awesome, even if not very effective actually.Still, this wouldn’t be a Far Cry without vehicles, right? Right! You also have vehicles in Far Cry 2, from small cars and modified assault trucks to boats and gliders… and while they feel completely arcadish, trust me, you will be thankful for them as the distances can be really huge.Unfortunately however, Far Cry 2 has its problems as well. Some of the side missions become repetitive after a while, the weapons have a degradation system which is interesting, but way too fast, the AI is simply painfully stupid sometimes (although when it works, it will surprise you…) and… well you have the “outpost system” which is one of the most frustrating features I have ever seen in a game. There are dozens of outposts scattered throughout the map, manned by the soldiers of the warring factions who will shoot you on sight. While the concept does make sense, and clearing the outposts is fun at first, they will soon become frustrating because of their insane re-spawn rate… it’s really not fun to clear out an outpost, walk away a couple hundred meters and come back to find it fully manned again. Ubisoft, this was really stupid!8.5/10Sound:In terms of music and sound effects Far Cry 2 is above average. While the soundtrack isn’t really memorable, the African tribal theme is pleasant and adds to the immersion, and the environmental and combat sounds are actually quite good. Unfortunately the dialogs are a bit soulless which sometimes kills the characters.8/10Replay value:While the plot is linear and there aren't any choices which would significantly change the outcome (which was done on purpose as far as I can tell, because in the end Far Cry 2 is story oriented and has a very strong message to communicate), the game provides countless possibilities, and can easily suck you in, making the game worth returning to.9/10Conclusion:Far Cry 2 is a very good game, with a unique setting, a unique plot, and a strong message which raises some very interesting moral questions. And while it might be a bit outdated by today’s standards, it’s definitely one of those games which you have to play at least once.I really recommend it if you are willing to invest some time into it, and if you are interested in something different, something special. If you are looking for a simple “tunnel shooter” however, you might get somewhat disappointed.8.5/10Test system specifications: AMD FX-8350 (OC @ 4.6 GHz); 8 GB DDR3 RAM @ 1866 MHz; AMD Radeon R9 280X (AMD Catalyst 14.4), Windows 7 64 Bit Ultimate / Windows 8.1 64 Bit Pro.

content:
, 2015
												Far Cry 2 is game that I would call a "victim of the bandwagon". It was generally hated by the community upon release because it had nothing to do with the first game. (Which frankly isn't a bad thing.) Rather, FC2 tried to take the series in a new direction. No mutants or cliche action seqences. Just gritty violent dark chaos   unfolding in the African jungles around you. The stripped down approach is quite appealing because the game seems to take itself more seriously. Putting more emphasis on tactics than just going in guns blazing. Story: You play as a hired gun that was sent by an unknown party to kill an infamous arms dealer named the Jackal. According to information provided, he is largely responsible for increasing instability inside Africa by stirring up civil wars in the country by providing weapons to both sides. Sounds easy, right? Go to Africa, find the Jackal, kill him. As you soon find out, it's not the simple. You soon start to play a part in the fate of the country and that perhaps, there's bigger problems than a person selling guns. It's an interesting story if you're willing to invest into it. The Jackal is an interesting character to listen to as he describes his life in the country. How the increased violence and warfare is slowly tearing the country apart. Gameplay: FC2 is a sandbox shooter at it's core. You're dropped into a beautiful lush world with various objectives to complete at your leisure. How you approach the goals is also up to you. Go guns blazing, go stealth, snipe, etc. As long as you got the tools, you got a plan. It's very satisfying to go in stealth and pick off guys from the darkness of the jungles. Watching them panic as their numbers get reduced one by one. Overall, I can't complain about FC2. It's a well made shooter that will keep gamers entertained for while. If you like planning attacks out and you're all about think first, shoot later. This game is up your alley.

												I've put in more than 40 hours into this game on the Xbox 360 version, as well as the non-Steam version, so don't mind the lowly 9 hours I've put into the game here on Steam.This is a fantastic game, and I personally prefer it over Far Cry 3. I was a huge fan of the original Far Cry (no, not the one on Xbox called Instincts, but the very first one on PC!). It was a flawed but fun game, with glitchy AI but beautiful levels and an open world design, where you could do a mission multiple different ways. I was worried when Far Cry 2 was announced to be in Africa and not a tropical island like the first, and that Jack Carver wouldn't be returning. I bought Far Cry 2 anyway when it released on PC, back when games didn't always come with Steam keys.I was immediately addicted. The game is very gritty, with just about everything out to kill you. It's definitely not for casual gamers. Weapons start rusting and breaking after long uses, eventually exploding in your hand, damaging you and forcing you to scavenge for a weapon off the ground while enemies are shooting at you from all directions. Cars can start to break down, requiring you to quickly get out, pop the hood, and use your magical wrench to fix it all while enemies are driving down the road trying to find you. Bones will break. Shrapnel will stab into your thigh. Bullets will require pulling out of your arm. You'll need to heal yourself, which uniquely has your character fix himself through multiple animations of ripping out large chunks of metal from his legs, bandaging himself, etc. It all looks fantastic and gives the game, as I said earlier, a very gritty feel.The game is flawed, just like Far Cry 1. The AI is iffy. It's hard to stealth. The story isn't delivered very well. Everyone talks like they've got to get to the last rocket off Earth. There's respawning guard outposts (though you can easily go around them, to be honest). But even with all of that said, I still think the game is much more unique and fun to play compared to Far Cry 3. I love exploring Africa, it looks gorgeous. If you ask me, I think the engine they used for FC2 (Dunia Engine) looks much better than the slightly cartoon-y style FC3 had with the Dunia Engine 2.I'd recommend the game if you're looking for a different, less casual type of FPS. It's got an incredible amount of detail, the weapons are fun to use, there's some very cool features like weapons breaking down, the healing system, and the way AI interact with each other (enemies will try to drag their friends away after they've been hurt, for example). It's a very underrated game, and I hope one day we'll get another Far Cry like this. One that isn't afraid to be different and try new things.EDIT: I recently started playing Far Cry 4 on my Playstation 4, and I just wanted to say that if you were a fan of Far Cry 2, but sad that FC3 removed a lot of the neat ideas 2 brought with it, you should definitely check out FC4. It feels like a mix of all the things I loved about FC3 and brought back a few things I missed that FC2 had, like fire realistically spreading (FC3 sorta had it still, but it didn't work well), being able to go to sleep to change to a specific time of day, and hell, even a certain character returns from FC2! I won't spoil who it is, but it took me by surprise, since he wasn't a particularly big character in FC2. He's also the first recurring character in a Far Cry game, other than one other character who returns from FC3. Seems like Ubisoft is starting to make the games connect a bit!

												Far Cry 2 - for me still the best part of the whole series. After playing through it multiple times (during internet downtime) i can safely say: This game is incredibly awesome!You start as an agent sent to an african country to hunt down an arms dealer. Too bad, you end up getting malaria and in need to rely on help of the local warlords. You help those guys out and get deeper and deeper into the fight between the different forces. The game, as allready mentioned, takes place in a fictional african country. You have 2 very huge areas in which are you free to move around and shoot people and animals. You have a lot of different weapons to use, some which you can find, others which you can buy. You get access to new weapons by completing side missions, same as malaria pills, which you need to survive. During your time you get to meet a few other mercenarys, some which get to be you friends and come help you in times of need. The Story is generic, but enjoyable, same with the missions. The graphics are beautifull, the african setting totally stunning. Yo can spend an incredible huge amount of time in the game, if you e.g. play on a high difficulty, simulating maximum realsim. The engine does its best to help with that! The sound you are listening to during your playtime might be a bit generic but is very nice to listen to. Multiple possible endings complete this wonderfull game.10/10 Still the best Far Cry game i've ever played, plus one of the best SP shooters. [Hint: i've heard mods make this even more enjoyable. I did not test that out though]

												This game is absolutely great no matter what haters say. Haters are mostly people who've played Far Cry 3 first, which has its positives, and while it's more cinematic than Far Cry 2, you just play to get over with it after a while. The Cons:Far Cry 2 only has 2 actual cons and they're both closely related. First of all, driving everywhere is mandatory, unless you use a bus station, which basically fast travels you to another bus station. However, you can't fast travel anywhere at anytime. The second con is related like I said, and it's the fact that you have to drive all the way to another underground station to get more Malaria pills. Malaria itself is an interesting part in the game and it adds to the difficulty and surprise since you might be taking out a huge army of enemies and suddenly feel the Malaria kick in. However, having to drive to an underground station to get passports and then travelling to another Underground station to give the passports and get the pills, is a huge detour that could have been avoided.The Pros:This game's positives overwhelm the negatives by far. The physics engine is absolutely perfect and it's undeniably better than Far Cry 3 and 4's since almost everything is dynamic. That means you can use fire for your advantage, unlike 3 and 4 where fire just spread everywhere randomly around the source of the fire. In Far Cry 2 since the environment is dynamic, by looking at how the wind blows (grass and trees' leaves can indicate that since they are moving n/s/w/e) you can actually use fire to your advantage and trap enemies inside a fire circle that's getting closer to them by the second.Another notable pro is that Far Cry 2 has a great gameplay that makes sure you're never bored. Malaria, Weapon jamming, respawning camps (some people find them annoying but we could all see how dead the island was in Far cry 3 after all camps were captured), a great arsenal of weapons, and of course, much fun with the flamethrower. It's also worth noting that Far Cry 2 in Infamous mode is an extremely hard challenge for all players and it can generate Dark Souls level of rage, which means the game actually respects the player and doesn't just ask you to be a Rambo in Africa. Overall, this game is great and the atmosphere are well as the gameplay itself show its true quality. Also, no Uplay! 11/10.

content:
er 27, 2014
												Far Cry 2 is rather an anomaly amongst AAA releases, and - in light of Ubisoft's more recent games - a world away from their typical modus operandi in the way it presents an uncompromising and utterly standout creative vision, ridden all the way to completion. It's not a perfect game - there are a number of features that are evidently only partially implemented and have little effect on gameplay (the buddy system, the reputation system, the malaria), and the story and characters are lacking to say the least. But, what it lacks in narrative it makes up for in atmosphere and pure creative integrity. I've never played a game that so accurately recreates the FEEL of a real-world location as Far Cry 2 does Africa. Whether the sun is rising over the still river water in the morning, or setting over a fire in the dry grasslands, this game is DRENCHED in atmosphere. You can almost smell the dirt and feel the sweat dripping off you as you play. Aside from creating a living, breathing world (which, in my opinion, is one of the most important features that open-world games often fail to include), it shows that there was someone with vision that pushed the creative team to create a product that was not necessarily going to hold the hands of the player (unlike Far Cry 3 with it's HUD crammed full of indicators telling you what to do and when). For Ubisoft to make such a choice and release a game which may not have been accessible to every single walking, talking wallet is, in light of their recent history, utterly mind-boggling, and I applaud the team behind this game for their efforts. Everything else aside though, the game is genuinely well-made - the core features all work wonderfully, with solid gunplay, responsive driving, and a well-designed sandbox that rewards exploration with many distinct and beautiful locales. The enemies are aggressive and unforgiving, typically forcing you to plan your attacks and prepare the right weapons for the job - it's so rewarding when a plan comes together. Equally rewarding, however, are those moments when you're caught unprepared - perhaps you only have a sniper rifle, a pistol, and some molotovs, and are caught from behind by a number of enemies, so you start frantically flinging molotovs in the direction of the enemy who are somewhere out there in the bush, as you relocate. You find a new spot and look back to see the bush ablaze and enemies fleeing, some already dead in the fire. These moments of pure, unscripted tension and excitement are what makes this game far deeper than it would seem on the surface, and this is perhaps why this review is littered with anecdotes. Because this is a game that creates anecdotes organically. Of course, with Far Cry 3 they made a number of changes that made it more accessible, but less memorable in my opinion - in favour of a realistic setting they crafted a cartoonish tropical island, in favour of a do-it-yourself mission style they filled the HUD with feedback and mission markers, in favour of challenging fights and impressive AI they put enemies in brightly coloured shirts who bum-rush you the second you fire a bullet, and on top of that they littered the world with meaningless fetch-quest items. It's not to say that I think FC3 is a bad game, but I find myself getting bored quickly every time I play it. Far Cry 2, however, is a game in which the fun one has is limited only by the player's imagination and creativity. The thing is, in its quest for realism, and its lack of strong narrative, I find the game actually offers the player a freedom that few other games genuinely do. The side missions are typically pretty bland, yes, but the strength of the world design and the freedom that you're offered means that there are quite literally countless ways to finish them. So you need to assasinate a target? Perhaps you block the road with your car and lie in wait to ambush him. Perhaps you wait until night and sneak in with a silenced pistol. Perhaps you snipe him from a nearby hillside. Perhaps you trap him in grassland and set the countryside ablaze. Perhaps you stride in with an RPG and just blow him the hell up. Even the way you choose to get to the location is undecided - do you drive the quickest route? Do you take the long way off road to avoid the checkpoints? Do you hop in a riverboat and take a shortcut downstream? You're given a target on a map, and complete freedom to traverse a believable world from then on. And even though I will criticise the lack of characters and story, the characters that are there feel like real, shady people. The main antagonist (although he is no Vaas) is enigmatic, and his cynical and exhausted outlook on the world becomes genuinely affecting as the game progresses, and I find that the thread of narrative that exists actually leaves you thinking about the real world situations that exist right now in so many African nations.It's clear that have a deep affection for this game, and that may be taken as bias by some, but it's an affection that was hard-won from release day as I slowly got used to Ubisoft's take on the franchise, unravelled the features of the game, and then began exercising my complete freedom to explore and manipulate the vast and beautiful landscape. This is a testament to what a strong creative vision can do to a AAA release, and while it might not go down in history as a particularly successful iteration, I feel that Far Cry 2 is one of the most criminally underrated games ever released and I defy any player not to be caught staring in awe as the sun rays filter through the canopy overhead. I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a dirty, gritty, realistic shooter in an incredibly immersive world that lays the tools on the table, and lets the player decide what to do with them.

er 19, 2013
												A Good game on many accounts.Farcry 2 is unique, fun, exciting and definately challenging. The enviroment is dynamic and beautiful, albiet sometimes locked in and small. The tactic of creating bush fires to devastate enemies has become a godsend for me.Malaria is a topic all on it's own. Deadly, realistic and game-changing at times, it hosts a brand new, rarely implemented idea that is interesting as it is deadly.Unfortunately, this concept is also extremely annoying and frustratingly good at stopping progress. You have to constantly backtrack to get new pills and it tends to pop up during important moments in conflict, costing you a lengthy retreat or a undeserved death.Another issue i found was that the game feels.... crowded. You cant drive 500 yards without hitting another guard post (there are 63 in the map!) or enemy patrol. And once spotted, prepare to be tirelessly chased down and shot at until you are, injured and with a smoking engine, forced to pull over and face the threat. You can scout these posts and keep them from respawning soldiers, but it's a lengthy, time consuming process that takes away from the air of flowing gameplay and beauty otherwise found in Farcry 2.When it comes to guns, theres a LOT. So much different weapons and tools to use, so little time. From flare guns to rocket launchers, you will never have to worry about getting bored. The weapon unlocking system is fun but a bit tedious, and it seems to be a magnet for the ever-so-present danger of malaria. The story is less implemented and less of a focus, allowing you to create your very own path to find your conclusion. This may seem to make the game "offset" at times but it also makes Farcry seperate from other "Go here, do This." games like Battlefield, Call of Duty and Halo. Vehicles are fun, relatively diverse, and suprisingly fragile. It only takes a few wild bullets from a machine gun to turn your beautiful safari ride into a smoking husk of a truck. Return fire is not an option unless you stop the vehicle. Gliders are fun and a great way to get from place to place. Be careful when getting off them though!Map creator is absolutely astounding! Fluid controls and a large array of options can make anyone into a professional map creator. I've spent a good long time building maps and playing on others. It is quite possible to never play the same map twice in mulitplayer.All in all, this game has it's pitfalls, but the pro's outway the con's. This game is interesting, breathtaking and unique. I love playing Farcry 2 and im sure you will two.

My score: 8.5/10 (with realism mod)Playthrough time: 27 hours (main story, many side missions, most main missions with buddy quests)Pros:+Great looking open world design+Approach each mission in the way you prefer+Very immersive game (especially with realism mod)+Excellent gunplay, combat is very engaging and funCons:-A lot of tedious extra travel if doing all the buddy missions-Game feels unbalanced without realism mod-Story doesn't make all that sense all the time-Speeded up voice acting sounds strangePerformance notes:Works well with Xbox 360 controller but I preferred keyboard + mouseGraphics performance R9 280X, 1080P max settings: 60 FPS (V-sync) almost all the timeMain reviewFarCry 2 is a first person shooter you probably either love or hate. Some people have called it a central African truck driving simulator rather than a first person shooter, and it all depends on how you look at the gameplay mechanics. It has a lot going for it with the open world, letting you tackle the missions as you prefer. The graphics and the African setting looks great. The game has a lot of features that really immerse you in the game, as the lack of minimap, instead utilizing a map you actually have to equip as an item and look at.The game puts you in a central African nation, where different factions are waging war at each other, and your mission is to stop the arms dealer supplying both sides. You have "buddies" helping you with missions (giving you optional ways to tackle the main missions) as well as giving you side missions of their own. They will also help you out of trouble if you get shot down.It's up to you to choose how to tackle each mission: get to the mission in an open world, utilizing buses for instant fast travel to a few set locations, otherwise the other vehicles available or going on foot, then finishing the mission objective in the way that best suits your playing style. Stealth, guns blazing, a tactical approach with grenades/molotovs to smoke the enemies out, or any other way? Your choice. Getting to the point of interest for each mission can take 1-4 minutes per mission, and sometimes involve shootouts as you get discovered by enemy patrols or checkpoints.The story sets out ambitious but doesn't hold together all that well. Most of the game is standard missions that are somewhat similar. One odd thing is that the DVD release of the game required the developers to speed up all recorded dialogue to make it take up less space. This is also in the steam version of the game. The fast talking NPC:s sound really odd!There are four things I got tired of while playing the game:1) Guards at guard posts always shoot at you, if you clear them out while passing they respawn until next time you pass.2) Enemies locate you way to easy, and fire at you with expert aiming, even almost dead enemies seem to have no problem hitting you with handguns at 300m range.3) Some enemies (this gets more frequent later in the game) can take almost a whole clip of ammunition before going down.4) If you do the buddy quests for the main missions, it can get quite tiresome to get to 3-4 different locations (some times at different sides of the map) to prepare everything needed for completing the main mission in an alternate way.I found out the perfect solution for problems 1-3: Dylan's Far Cry 2 Realism Mod 1.4. It fixes the stealth, the enemy health and the checkpoints (you can pass checkpoints without being fired upon most of the time). The game also gets a lot harder since your health is reduced as well (remember to save a lot), but much more satisfying. You're best off planning your assault, and it's really satisfying approaching an objective, taking out a few guards from afar with a sniper rifle, staying hidden to not draw enemy fire, then moving in closer and finishing the last guards off at close range with a silenced sub machine gun. You also come to appreciate strategic advantages as an elevated position. One of my best experiences with the game was behind cover with an assault rifle at an elevated position, moving from cover to cover, mowing down the enemies below. All the time the action being really tense since you know that getting hit by one or two bullets can end it all, so all firefights are really tense. At moments like these the game is glorious.I would really recommend the realism mod, and the game requires a bit of patience. For the right player, driving to each mission, sometimes avoiding (or taking out) enemy patrols along the way just builds up the tension, but will be tedious for other players, so you have to ask yourself if the way the game plays suits your taste.Except for running the realism mod, my recommendation would be to skip most of the buddy quests. It gets far to tedious to do them all, and the rewards aren't that great. The pacing is much better if you just stick to the main mission most of the time (ignoring the complaint calls you get from the buddy).Far Cry 2 is one of the best FPS games I've played, and also one of the most immersive games of all genres. It has a few drawbacks, mostly solved by the realism mod, and it requires the right player for the game, it isn't for everyone. If you want all action all the time, it isn't the game for you, but the realistic and short but immersive and tense firefights this game can offer are hard to beat if you're in to that kind of action.

												This game is my favorite single-player first-person shooter of all time. I enjoyed Doom back in the 90s, but other than that i am not really a fan of the genre. I find the mechanics somewhat repetitive - you are forced to kill everything, everywhere, spraying bullets around like you're in some kind of direct-to-video action flick. Even acclaimed shooters like Half-Life and Bioshock come across as cartoonish and tedious to me. Counter-Strike changed everything. A game where you only get a rifle and a sidearm, where every shot matters, where a bullet to the head means instant death and spending the next few minutes learning from people far more skilled than you. After playing Counter-Strike, every first-person shooter felt like a mindless kill-fest where stealth or tactics did not matter. The good news is those things do matter in Far Cry 2.You are still pretty much railroaded into killing everything that moves. It is an FPS, after all. But stealth always feels like a possibility. The tension before the killing ensues, the time you spend crouching motionless in elephant grass, is a highlight of the game.The enemies in Far Cry 2 are some of the most human i have encountered. It's why killing them takes a toll - they are a lot like you. If you have been seen - if any of your enemies spot you - the whole base goes on alert. Forever. They will lay down suppressive fire in your last known position. They will wall-bang. They will establish search parties. They will freak out and start getting paranoid over the slightest noise. If you are seen - or heard - again, expect to die. One or two shots from an enemy rifle will wipe you out. But stay perfectly still, crouched in the undergrowth, and the enemy may creep past just a few meters away. And, as they widen their net, you may be able to slip through and circle round. Inevitably, ♥♥♥♥ will go south. You are spotted and clipped, then running through the jungle, sliding to obscure their line of sight, spinning round to lob a grenade or to spray and pray. Mostly, you will die. It is ♥♥♥♥ing brutal.I know some reviewers have complained about the mechanics of this game. Respawning bases. Deteriorating weapons. Malaria. I will admit i played with Dylan's realism mod and never tried it any different, but in Dylan's mod it all makes sense. You are sick and scared and stumble into the jungle with a pea shooter. So you see an AK, grab it, but it jams in no seconds flat. You see an unguarded jeep, jump in, then get hit by an RPG half a click down the road. The game teaches you these hard lessons in the first half hour. How are you supposed to survive in Ubisoft's nightmare version of Africa? Don't pick up jury-rigged weapons. Don't jack jeeps. Wait till dusk, get your belly in the mud and proceed to your destination at a crawl. Avoid the roads, avoid the checkpoints, scout your targets and look for a headshot. Value reliability over firepower. Value cover over speed. Value your life.The story is grim. You play an opportunistic soldier of fortune in the midst of a civil war. Almost everyone is evil and corrupt, and the vast majority attack you on sight. Even if you try to minimize casualties on an assassination or sabotage mission, something will invariably ♥♥♥♥ up and the bodycount will rise. Or your next mission will require you to clean out a whole area anyway. Every time you hear a squeak you expect a technical to pull up and unload 50 cal into your back. Every time the sun falls on a certain pattern of leaves your trigger finger will twitch. And gosh, those hanging vines really do look like bodies sometimes, don't they? I loved Spec Ops: The Line for its simulated PTSD effects, but those were mostly scripted. Far Cry 2 plays it totally straight and your brain still goes there. ♥♥♥♥ is ♥♥♥♥ed up, man.So yeah. The game is punishing. It's bleak. You spend most of your time holding your breath and crouched in the dirt. Every now and then you are awed by a herd of zebra crossing the savannah at sunset, or the majesty of a tropical storm, or the slow rising moon. And then a bullet ricochets off a nearby cliff face and everything turns to ♥♥♥♥ again. A lot of games have made an impact on me due to their strong narratives. Far Cry 2 is different. The plot is thin as a potato chip, but its unforgiving sandbox houses an atmosphere thick enough to haunt me offline. Best single-player FPS since Doom? For me, yes. Hands down.

												My Jeep had smoke coming out of the hood. It was driving slower than it usually did. I had just survived a brief skirmish with some trigger-happy hooligans, but with one quick grenade under their Jeep, the problem was solved. I saw a guard post up ahead."Piece of cake." they said. "Clear it with that shotgun you just bought." they said.I jumped off the Jeep and pulled out my shotgun. It really was a thing of beauty, a work of art: it was ornately decorated with what looked like silver on an African or Brazilian wood with a reddish hue. The sound of it being fired was pleasant but aggressive, kind of like gangsta rap or heavy metal. It was brand new, and I decided to affectionately name it Ho Lee Schitt, after my adoptive father from China.I sprinted over there. "YIPPIE-KI-AYE-AY ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥S" I screamed, in my best Bruce Willis voice. "It's time to ♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ up!"But then, I realized the harsh reality of what was coming. I had limited ammo, and no grenades or molotovs. I had the rapt attention of about five heavily armed people who I had just threatened. The fastest means of escape I had was a small dune buggy on the other side of the shantytown. Malaria struck me almost instantly, and I heard the roar of a Jeep's engine. I felt a sharp pain overwhelming the entire left side of my body as I lost my grip on Ho Lee Schitt."HO LEE SCHITT! NO!" I screamed. and then I felt myself get smashed to the ground by a heavy steel chassis, and everything went black.But not for long! One of my buddies that I met earlier just came to pick my pathetic, lumpy body off the ground and save my life."Ol' buddy, ol' pal!" I was able to whisper to myself with all of my energy. Everything went black again, but only for about five seconds, and I saw my buddy, courageously fighting off my enemies with a rusty old pistol like the independent woman she was.But then I noticed her struggling. She left my body on the ground as she had to load her last magazine into the pistol. Odds were, one of us or both of us were going to die, and I was determined that if any of us were to die, it would not be her.So I bit the bullet and looked at my leg. It was surely broken, but there was a bullet hole in it, too. I couldn't just leave this bullet there, so I performed a brief, gory self-surgery with my trusty machete. She noticed that I was coming to, and decided to give me the gun."Go!" I yelled. "Go into that house over there for safety. If one of us dies, it will not be you!"I saw as a bullet was fired into my left arm, which I noticed was also probably broken. I shoved my finger through the bullet hole and pushed the bullet out, leaving a clean hole in my arm. I collapsed to the ground, like some fat guy in dire need of doughnuts. I realized that I was going to die of malaria-induced lead overdose if I didn't get up, so I popped my last malaria pill and stabbed a morphine syringe in my arm.I arrogantly belted out, in my best James Brown voice, "AND I FEEL GOOD! I KNEW THAT I WOULD NOW." Then I saw it. Ho Lee Schitt was in the hands of one of my enemies. I was furious. I ran over to the dune buggy I saw, jumped on it, and ran him over. He was crawling on the ground begging for mercy. I crouched next to him, and shot him once in each eye. Ho Lee Schitt was mine again.I ran over to the two remaining men, murder in my eyes, and my tongue stretching out longer than Ace Frehley's. They each had a clear shot on me, and i risked getting buckshot all over my face and the "PIMP" tattoo on my licker; however, their rusty shotguns jammed, obviously because the bullets were scared of me. A quick bang here and a quick bang there and there were two less idiots in the world."AND I FEEL NICE! LIKE SUGAR AND SPICE!" I continued to sing. The adrenaline was coursing through my veins, and I jumped up in the air and high-fived my buddy. We stayed in the air for a full minute, like the end of some Van Halen concert on MTV or the closing credits of literally every episode of The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air. I was Born To Run, and against the better judgment of my friend, I kept rolling on that Thunder Road to the place beyond that guard post: New Jersey.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------"gr8 8/8 m8" - IGNThis game is amazing, definitely the best in the series, and I dare say that it is the best FPS of 2008 (yes, I know that Call of Duty: World at War came out in 2008. What about it?)

												"See that plane? Last one out of the country"This review contains a good amount of history so the game is less confusing to people who arent fresh on African History, you have been warned. Farcry 2 is a game that will at first, confuse people from the newer games in the farcry series.To the untrained eye, this is a brutal, not fun, masochism sim. You will die, you will kill people you care about because they beg you to. You will run in the jungle away from packs of native Africans who are dying to cut your tendons and leave you to starve, but Malaria will get you first.To kill the confusion, lets have some backgroundFarcry 1 was essentially a linear half life style shooter, albeit an incredibly difficult one. It has almost nothing in common with farcry 3 and 4, which can be summed up as giant playgrounds of 0 difficulty.Farcry 2 is a mix. Open world, brutal, Quick tutorials, no holding your hand. This is Africa, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, not some cute little island, not the scenic mountains of India, every ♥♥♥♥ing thing in this country wants to kill and eat you, the people most of all. The big components of later games, stealth, vehicles, first aid in first person, etc, are present here, but are not given to you nicely. You may not even realize the stealth system, exists until you are in a bush with 10 men with machetes walking by on the road, and they dont see you.. puzzling you as you realize this game is deeper than it looked. In addition to all the features of later games, this game also has a ton of immersion. Your map is actually pulled out to use it, you get to pick from a selection of (Sadly only male) Characters and your choice affects your viewmodel, etc. Fire is even more realistic than later games and will change entire battles for minutes at a time, and is dynamic, If say for instance the fire spreads over a guys dropped gun or an ammo cache, the bullets might start going off from the heat, and best of all, guns deteroriate, and actually jam, realistically. One last mentionable feature which is quite interesting, is enemies in this game actually behave like people. They arent ludicrous men of no fear, they actually panic, and even flee. You will find yourself sniping a small outpost, and the last man you try to kill will book it into the jungle, the battle music stops, you raise a brow, you run around in the outpost like a tard trying to get him to notice you, assuming he just lost sight of you or ran the wrong way by accident,  but hes gone, he didnt want to die and instead of sitting around like every other NPC in every other game waiting to be shot, he ran away, Fight AND flight are represented here.To be fair and describe both pros and cons, the game is missing a few features. There are no dangerous animals such as lions or crocodiles (The game devs felt this would make an already unfair and cruel game too frustrating, but I wish they had added them) Theres some very "African" scenarios that were never played on, such as hunting or big dangerous game with a large caliber gun, for instance. And one feature I feel would be super nice to have had is the ability to use a gun in cars, not while driving like Farcry 3 and 4, but just pull up your gun, letting go of the wheel, that kinda thing. You get ambushed by people in cars with massive machineguns in the back ALOT in this game, so having to change seats or get out of the car every time is a -massive- pain. If you don't know anything about Africa, this game will also fly completely over your head, so let me spell out some stuff.This game models itself after African countries such as Angola, which were heavily affected by the cold war. Multiple sides, sporting nicknames like UNITA or the MPLA, sprouted up. These sides usually were based on their tribal and ethnic origins, but they pretended to be for whoever was sending them weapons. An MPLA officer may scream joy for the soviets who buy my guns, joy for communism, but what he means is "Joy for my Tribe" the two sides in most of these battles cannot be told apart, and in this game that occurs too, which confuses many a player trying to find which one they want to support. Once the cold war died down, these factions had lost their free toys, so now we have a bunch of tribes armed with ridiculously lethal weapons and no backers, so they start mining Africa's rich Diamond deposits and selling them off. These "Blood diamonds" fund wars in Africa that essentially still go on today. So, in this game, you are a merc hired to track down a man who trades weapons for these diamonds. To do so, you work with various factions whose names are all acronyms just like real life African war-factions. You may also get jobs from certain locals, missionaries, "Princes" to take care of dirty work in a country abandoned by the world.  You will fight men with machetes, rockets, flamethrowers, but Africa itself is your worst enemy. Between psycho wildlife, malaria always a mere spell of sickness away, and the humidity and weather rotting your guns into dust in your own hands, this country wants you dead.Do not buy this game expecting Farcry 3 africa edition. Buy this game expecting a rust-style survival simulator. Buy this expecting to be confused, afraid, lost, and desperate. Read heart of darkness, watch apocalypse now, get in that mood, that is the point. Do not buy this if you are afraid of unfair odds or unwinnable situations.The last bit ill touch on is the buddy system. This was introduced to make resource management and the overall stress level even more horrifying. You have people, who will try to help you stay alive in various ways. You have a main one and can have side ones, and theyll actually exist and can be found in "Mikes bar" and they interact with eachother and you. They can do a number of things, giving you info, offering alternate ways to take on missions (These ways drastically alter the way a mission is played and are up to you to choose or not) and If you "die" they may save you, drag you to safety, etc. But they can die, in battle, on the way back, heck, you might be saved, 30 minutes later find your bleeding out on the side of a riverbank, some militants in an airboat shot him up? Why? because he was there. You can heal him, with one of your expensive needles, but what if you are out? then you can leave him there I suppose.But he will beg you to end it... Embrace the pistol you put to his face, and you will pull the trigger.The last plane out left as you arrived. Death is the only way out now.

 Video Retrospective Below 


YouTube™ Video: FAR CRY 2 IS THE BEST IN THE SERIES 

			Views: 7,333		

			Downward Thrust - https://www.youtube.com/downwardthrust Many critics deem Far Cry 3 to be the best in the series and, whilst I will admit that it is fantastic game, the second main entry into the...		

Cast your minds back to the holiday season of 2008, the original Dead Space released as a suprise hit, as well as the highly anticipated Fallout 3 from Bethesda, and of course Gaben graced us with the superb Left 4 Dead, and Far Cry 2, a sequel to a game that, by all accounts, had all but been forgotten to many, released on October 21st in North America.Showcasing a modified version of the CryEngine, dubbed the Dunia Engine, Far Cry 2 was certainly an impressive technical feat for its time, featuring dynamic weather, volumetric lighting, a realistic physics engine and perhaps most impressive of all, dynamic fire propagation, with fire acting in a realistic and driving manner. Ubisoft Montreal had taken over the reigns from Crytek who had moved onto pasture news with their Crysis franchise, and it was clear that the Dunia Engine was to be an important tool for the series, with future games in the series continuing to use the engine, as well as being used in conjunction with the Anvil engine in Assassins Creed 2 and Assassin's Creed Brotherhood. When looking back, 8 years later, its still hard to deny just how Far Cry 2 continues to look, holding up well with many more recent games in the series.Far Cry 2 takes place in a small, failed Central African state, currently embroiled in civil war. The government has recently collapsed, leaving two factions vying for control. At war are the United Front for Liberation and Labour, or the UFLL and the Alliance for Popular Resistance, abbrieviated to the APR. Your main goal is to find and assassinate the Jackal, an arms dealer who has been selling weapons to both sides of the conflict. It's worth noting also that Far Cry 2 is a sequel in name only, featuring none of the supernatural elements from the first game at all, though these elements were re-introduced in later games.Throughout the course of the games story, you are forced to work with both the UFLL and the APR, each using the player as a deniable agent in order to avoid a full-scale war. In addition to the hunt for the Jackal, you can provide the Underground with stamped travel documents for refugees in exchange for anti-malarial drugs, ambush convoys of weapon shipments in order to gain access to a greater variety of weapons and equipment from arms dealers, and assassinate targets acquired by intercepting signals from various cell-phone towers in the area. There really is no shortage of things to occupy you in this game, and while many people lament the all too common 'malaria attacks' for being more intrusive than compelling, it does help to break up the pace of the main plot, without feeling too much like padding out the games length.Realism was something that Ubisoft really wanted to push with this game, with features such as weapon degradation, the previously mentioned  dynamic weather system, a day and night cycle, as well as the aformentioned fire propagation mechanism. Weapons will become dirty over time and prone to jamming, eventually becoming completely unusable, you have to hold a physical map and use a handheld navigation system to get around, when vehicles are damaged you must perform a short repair animation and on top of this, you have to deal with a worsening affliction of malaria, having to take a pill in order to combat the blinding and potentially fatal effects of the illness.Many saw these 'realistic' features as little more than annoyances that distracted from the overall experience, and I disagree, these quirks were what made the game unique, and set the Far Cry 2 apart from its generic FPS roots. Far Cry 3 and 4 dumbed down the realistic features, and I felt the games regressed as a result, feeling more like an average open world shooter that are all too commonplace in the current market.The dynamic weather system allowed for different weather conditions such as storms and strong winds. And the time of day also affected the behavior of enemy AI, heightening their awareness at night, but hindering their ability to see the player in hiding, while during the hot part of the day the enemies might sheltering in the shade in groups, but be able to easily spot the player from a distance. Several species of animals can be encountered in the game, and while none of the wildlife found in the game pose any direct threat to the player they are able to distract the enemy, as well as make them aware of the player's presence. The previously mentioned dynamic fire propogation also played a key factor during enemy encounters, allowing a small fire to spread and eventually cause large brush fires, which could be used to the your advantage during combat if handled carefully. The behavior of fire is dependent on many factors such as wind speed and direction, rain, as well as the type ofvegetation. With fire spreading much more freely in the dry, grassy plains and savannahs compared to the humid jungle environments.These elements forced you to make tactical decisions when attempting missions, and is something that I really enjoyed during my original playthrough, it also added a great deal of replay value, with each encounter playing out differently depening on the conditions and time of day.Without going too much into it, as I sadly never got the chance to really play it back in 2008, there was also a multiplayer component to the game, which attempted to include many of the dynamic elements of the single-player game such as the use the of fire. As well as including a quite comprehensive map editor, something that was seen in the Far Cry also. This map editor was incredible, almost everything can be tweaked and tuned to your liking, and I actually had a lot of fun playing around with the various features of it, even without getting to actually use said maps in multiplayer, though I have since some pretty creative and impressive maps made online. Thankfully, the map editor managed to keep its place in future games in the series, with the exception of both Blood Dragon and Primal which were sadly solo experiences.Far Cry 2 will always be a bit of a difficult game to judge, it tried to do so much that I can't help but appreciate and commend Ubisoft Montreal for their ambition, even if some features could be considered annoying to many. None of the later games in the series have ever managed to capture the sheer scope,  and sense of freedom that this game had and for that reason it has to be considered the best in the series, and one that you should definitely pick up and play, either for the first time or for 100th time.

												Welcome to my review of Far Cry 2. I hope I can help you to decide if you want to buy this game or not. I will try to show you the positive sides and negatives also.Let's start with the fact that this FPS is one of the most immersive open world games you can find. All of your HUD is hidden and your map is in game (you have to bring it up to see where you want to go,there is no mini-map). When I said it is hidden,i meant that when you are exploring you won't see it,you will only see your health bar when you get hurt,and you will see your ammo when you are low or when you are about to reload.The sound design is amazing, except for the voice action. They speak super fast and without emotion, its kinda hilarious but you get used to it. Other than that the sound quality is superb. From winds at night, to listening to the wild life in the distance – you get such a good feeling when you are exploring on feet.Next the graphics – they are great for their time,but when you start the game you immidietly will see that they put a very big effort to make to world feel alive, the engine handles everything perfect – to the grass and trees to the enrupting flames when something blows up or you throw a molotov.There are a lot of mission to do.*Main Missions*Buddy Missions*Convoy*AssassinationWhen you go to a weapon vendor, you have a pass a mission so more guns will be unlocked.Also your guns wear down the longer you use them.They start to jam in a middle of fight and eventually break.So you have to always resupply at the vendor to keep your equipment up to shape.Last we will talk about buddy system and choices in the game.Your buddy is there to help you,when you go down,he comes and helps you – brings you to a save place while killing your attackers (which is cinematic).He can give an alternative way to pass a mission,and if he gets injured you can decide if you want to save him,or to leave him (or worse put a bullet in his head).Now let's talk negatives about this game.The biggest one is the respawning enemies.What I am talking about is,when you clear a checkpoint and leave it,and go for example 1km away to re-suply at weapon shop  and go back,they will be there again.Also if you try to skip it and just drive past it,they will shoot you down,and you have to fight them anyway.Also when you are exploring and traveling with your car,there will always be a jeep which is will come right to you and shoot you,so you have to stop kill them,and then move on (and again,again …).And when you are playing on higher difficulty is easier to just walk,because you can hide in the environment – but it takes more time to go from point A to point B.If you want a good open world game,in which the game does not hold your hand,you are free to explore whenever you want,do the mission how you like, and choose who you spare or kill. This is the game for you.If you can look past the respawning enemies and jeeps you will have a great time ranging from 20h to 30 depending if you do all the side mission or not.

er 16, 2014
												When I first played this game, I underestimated on how addictive Far Cry 2 can be. I just cannot stop playing it and kept going on for hours.What the game did right: This game is similar to its predecessor but expands the limited open world that the first Far Cry game was trying to construct on.  The environment is now far more diverse, ranging from dry savannahs to humid jungles with thick vegetation.  There is also a dynamic weather system in which fog can overtake the land or a rainstorm can appear and change the way you play.Adding to its wide ranges of landscapes, I can argue one of the more "tactical benefits" this game boasts is its fire.  A lot of games have a blaze kept at a constant size but FC 2 offers greater realism in that part. Throw a Molotov Cocktail at a dry patch of grass and see the fire consume the grass with its voracious appetite but in a humid climate, it will inflict little damage.  The A.I. of your enemies are no longer the same "dimwits" that got slaughtered in FC 1. If you're spotted out in the open or make too much noise near guard posts, they will come for you. They also converse with each other and try to protect themselves from the player which reflects real life. In one instance, a downed mercenary will be helped by another merc. Stealth has been improved. If you're careful enough, your reward is being able to silently take down one enemy after another. For the most part, their awareness is fairly balanced, unlike FC 1 in which the mercs couldn't tell if someone else was firing a loud weapon but still could see the player behind tents and bushes. Also, your choices on when to use stealth makes a big difference. For example, you can go at night where potential assailants cannot easily see you but are alert. A unique feature that FC 2 has is its buddies. They are in the game to help you with missions, increase your reputation by providing optional quests, or save you if your well-being has been thrashed to zero. I do enjoy interacting with them upon taking missions. When combining the aforementioned aspects, you can do missions with almost any mentod you want.  You can either quitely sneak past foes or go in guns blazing. It's all up to you. Exploring doesn't easily get dull and the replay value is high.While I do favor this game, some problems are existant. What the game should have avoided doing wrong:The voice acting for most of the characters is inauspicious. Most of the characters speak too fast and have a flat tone. One of your buddies' dialogue sounds like it was taken from Google translate and that makes it inauthentic. Over time, the side missions get repetitive. The "convoy missions" are the most subjected to this.  It gets quickly mundane to find circling rival arms vendors and blow up their trucks. The worst part is if you want to have better weapons sooner, there's no other way around this other than to proceed through the main objectives most of the time. The "weapon degradation system" is one that I have debated in choosing if it's interesting to keep in a game or conclude it's mostly annoying to have in a firefight. As of now, I have decided that it's a nuisance as some weapons degrade too quickly and jam at the worst times. Also, close to the end of the game, even with reliability upgrades, the game will punish you if your shots miss too much and you cannot obtain new weapons (unless you stored them).Also, the malaria mechanism is very annoying, with no way to ever stop it, only delay it. When you're under attack by that damn disease, you can barely see well and cannot sprint away from danger. Although it doesn't last that long, it may cost some precious seconds for you to flee. The diamond cases in this game may somewhat excite newcomers for a while but it's painful to endure when trying to reach for some diamonds on a cliff. Although not necessary to find, it's just a distraction from what the game can truly offer. I did mention you can interact with your buddies, but that's very limited.  All you can do is accept 2 of their quests and after that, they will just say "hi" if you meet them regularly. The (re)spawning of enemy mercenaries in certain locations is downright stupid. In one case, you can take down all enemies in a base but when you leave for a certain distance and look back with a scope, the place is then refilled with enemies as if nothing has happened. The developers should have put a time limit in how fast enemies can respawn when you're sufficiently far away. The A.I. is good when confronting them but when they drive, it's a mess. The drivers tend to have problems in making a  U-turn and are horrible in judgement. One time, a patrol car tried to run me over but it missed and plunged into the water.Finally, the storyline is woefully linear. Though understandable, your choices are very narrow and don't have much impact on the game. Trying to avoid providing spoilers, it's the same "bad" ending, if you decide to detonate some explosives or bribe some border guards to help out a fleeing country in need. Other: I haven't tried out multiplayer yet but I have heard that it's dead, which is sad. However, if you feel like allowing your imagination demanding to make a map with the African landscape, there is a map editor that is easy to use. Shamefully, it's quite limited and it's meant for multiplayer. Customizing this game is almost impossible to do, unlike most games. For those who wish to mod, they will be sadden that this is almost unachievable. Still, there are a few mods that can enhance the game (and perhaps tweak balance), like Dylan's Realism Mod. Conclusion:This game is definitely worth a purchase. While it may have cons, the pros in this game will entertain you and not disappoint you for at least one playthrough. If you're bored of playing games that trap you in confined spaces, get this game and feel how open it is.

												Not much of a review guy, so this will probably be the only game i'll ever review on steam. This is also going to be a little biased and you'll see why in a second.Okay first off, the world itself is amazing. For a game made in 2008, the level of detail in the world and atmosphere is phenomonal. The music that comes along with it is great, changing whether or not the game detects you being in a fire fight or not. The character models are also good, no two seem to look the same although they do have similarities. Only gripe would be the voice acting; characters mouths dont always seem to move in sync with the dialogue. The map is massive, and you'll spend a good amount of time driving to locations or maybe just walking like I usually do. If you're not a patient person, and need to have some kind of action 24/7, this won't be for you. The action is there, and explosions and gun fights happen frequently, but if you're expecting the rushed delivery from something like CoD or Battlefield, stray away. Theres a good selection of weapons to choose from once you've done a bunch of the convoy missions. Some include different snipers (Dragunov, AS50), submachine guns (MAC-10, UZI), Assault Rifles (AK, AR-15) and theres rocket launchers, a dart rifle to sneak around with, a mortar and a 6 round grenade launcher. Theres more aswell I just dont remember everything. All will deteriorate and jam once used too much, so you've got to keep an eye on your loadout or you'll run into an outpost empty handed and get slaughtered. You can only carry 4 weapons at a time, and choose wisely or you'll be stuck in long range engagement with a shotgun, pistol and a flamethrower. You can choose how aggressive or passive you want to play depending on your loadout which gives the game some replay value if you went through the campaign once and only played a certain way. The game is a ton of fun once you get past the tutorial (which only lasts about 10-20 mins).If i have to mention some cons, here are some. The respawning enemies at outposts can be annoying sometimes I suppose, but if they didnt respawn youd clear out all of them and then just be driving around an empty map that sure is well designed and beautiful, but wouldnt have any of the action youd expect from an FPS. Sound design from gun sounds to weather to just everything in general is really good, but if you're bothered by a characters mouth not being in sync with their dialogue then...yeah. AI can be a little finnicky sometimes, you can be on a rock in some cliff sniping down on an enemy outpost, put a bullet in a guys head, and his friend right beside wont even notice or react. Other times they'll find your location right away and immediately start firing at you. Enemies seem to take a little too much damage sometimes. When I played this game before I always carried a sniper so i could kill most people from a good distance with a headshot and its a one shot one kill, but if youre going in with an AR and thats all, you can put around 15 rounds into someone and they wont die. Other times they will. Its weird sometimes, but it doesnt really take away from the game in my opinion. It's just something you get used to. One thing I was disappointed by when I bought this was there not being any multiplayer. I try to create a Ubi.com ID and it just says theres a problem with the Far Cry 2 servers. Not a big deal, for only 3.50 its a good pickup especially for a great campaign. Theres some things i've probably missed, but for just 3 dollars, please just try this game. Its an absolute masterpiece. I played this game for YEARS literally when I bought it on PS3. Had thousands of hours invested online and beat the campaign dozens of times. Havent played in a while so I figured I'd pick it up on PC and give it another go. That's why this review is biased though, I have so many memories with this game and it's what got me into FPS games which lead me into COD4 and then into the cods after that. It sounds nerd as ♥♥♥♥ but Far Cry 2 had a special place in my heart and I wont forget this game. Not too many others I can say that about. 10/10.
