AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below) Game Name: Far Cry® 2: Fortune's Edition Original Release: 2008 Genre Tags: FPS; Action; Open World;   My Overall Grade: B Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 12-25 hours Multiplayer Aspect: Auxiliary Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Strong narrative advocates; Fans of the intellectual property; Aesthetes; Game atmosphere connoisseurs REVIEWMany people were disappointed in Far Cry 2, and it does have its flaws, but I still found it to be an enjoyable experience overall.  The game succeeds in being immersive and captivating, and the actual gameplay is exciting and has some novel mechanics. Also, there is an interesting story aspect imbedded in the main campaign. These qualities can help some people overlook the minor annoyances; others however may feel like it’s not worth putting up with them, especially if they aren't as interested in the narrative and atmospheric aspects.I felt that the environments were well-designed and the gameworld was a pleasure to explore. The graphics are pretty solid, and the animations and effects are noticeably good.    Far Cry 2 definitely has a nice setting.  If you enjoy immersing yourself in foreign gameworlds, you should like this.The gameplay is also pretty fun overall. There are a lot of good ideas and unique nuances in the game. Also, the combat can be exciting and the open-world allows you to plan your route of attack any way you would like.  There are some annoying aspects to the gameplay, though.  But there are some pretty awesome missions sprinkled throughout the game that make putting up with the annoying parts worth it.As for those annoying parts, there are two main aspects of the gameplay that can become tedious at times. For one: the gun jamming. The idea of implementing mechanics where guns found on the ground have little ammo and jam frequently sounds interesting on paper, but it needs to be executed well. In Far Cry 2, there are times it winds up being far more annoying than interesting. And the other main gripe with the game is the extremely frequently respawning guard posts.  Clearing 5 guard posts every time you want to travel on the map gets old fast. But both of these annoyances can be extensively minimized by just playing on easy.  Guns will jam far less often, and you will able to drive right through the guard posts instead of clearing them out every time. So I suggest you don’t play this particular game on a high difficulty.  You will only magnify the aforementioned faults with the game and allow them to overshadow the fun parts. And as I mentioned, there are some really fun missions in the campaign.So if you would be interested in this kind of game, and feel like you would be able to enjoy the good parts, then Far Cry 2 should be something you consider checking out.Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

												As much as I want to recommend this game, I can't. There are just too many immersion and game breaking bugs that will never be fixed.I'll admit, I did have fun for a while. Sneaking into a heavily guarded fort on a rainy night, killing the target and sneaking back out after only killing one guard with just a knife felt pretty awesome. But there are just so many annoying factors for the majority of the game, and let me start off with the two biggest issues:THERE ARE PROGRESSION BLOCKING/SAVE CORRUPTING BUGS THAT FORCE YOU TO RELOAD AN EARLIER SAVE.And you have no idea when they occurred. I had this happen to me twice in one playthrough, but luckily I had many save files to fall back on and find the ones that still worked, which set me back 4 hours. I almost rage quit and I wouldn't blame anyone for doing so. Having that many save files is also annoying because it takes forever to open the load menu because each save is ~5MB. I'm not completely sure, but I noticed that when the door guards tell you to go look for a guy in captivity, your game is about to break. Look at the map to see where the buddy is, then reload a save that was before you talked to the guard and go find them on your own. I have heard of other bugs like key NPCs vanishing or just refusing to talk to you, but I did not personally experience them.THERE IS A BUG THAT ONLY LETS YOU LISTEN TO 11/18 JACKAL TAPES.Jackal tapes are the ramblings of the arms dealer you are sent to kill. The Jackal is the main villain. These tapes are the only way you can get inside his head and see why he behaves the way he does...and you can't get them all in the current state of the game. This is a pretty big part of the story that just goes missing, especially because those last few tapes reveal a lot about the character (because the majority of the game doesn't tell you anything story related). How do I know that? Because I looked them up on YouTube, the only way to listen to them all now.The game crashes constantly with DX10.Use DX9.Enemies and supplies respawn after they go out of draw distance.Go too far away and come back, and they'll all be there again. Not only is this annoying when you're trying to get somewhere that involves backtracking, but it makes you feel like nothing you do matters. It just wastes your time.Enemies know exactly where you are the instant you miss.Good luck trying to take out a base without save-scumming. The instant you miss one bullet, they all know your exact location and start closing in and shooting even if you used a silent weapon like the dart gun. This is a glaring flaw because you have to plan your attacks on every set of enemies. They can very quickly overwhelm, flank, and kill you on higher difficulties so you must try to take out as many as possible from range. Don't even think about turning down the difficulty, because...Enemies are stupid.Even if you crank the difficulty up, which gives the AI the ability to flank you and such, they'll still do some really dumb stuff. I once blew up a barrel from a distance and the AI decided the best way to investigate the situation was to gather around it. About 6 guys just grouped up and I shot them one at a time. They never took cover, just spun around looking for me. On easier difficulties they'll "run" up to you, stare at you for a few seconds, then fire. They seem to have overreacted to far cry 1 difficulty complaints.Cell tower and arms dealer side missions are always the same.There is absolutely no variety in any of these. The cell towers have you assassinate one guy always dressed in a suit with a desert eagle in random heavily guarded areas. Sometimes he's in a car. Sometimes he's in a cease-fire zone. The arms dealer missions are EXACTLY the same: it's always blow up a truck with a technical in front and behind it driving in a convoluted circle on one of the 9 map squares. Always. There is no creativity whatsoever, and it's pure padding.Most of your time will be spent driving.Almost every mission will have you travel across the whole map repeatedly, and because of respawning enemy camps this can take forever. Good luck driving through an outpost because the AI will get in their cars, cheat by going faster than you can to catch up to you, and blast you away. The only time you can "drive" past an outpost is when you go full speed in a swamp boat, the AI doesn't seem to notice/catch up in those cases. There are 5 "fast" travel points across the 9 map squares in an X shape, but that's not enough and normally you still have to do a good bit of driving to and from them. Driving in-and-of-itself is annoying as well because...Vehicles have horrible behavior.They struggle to go over the smallest of obstacles and handle like arcade racers. If you manage to get your vehicle stuck on a 6 inch flat rock or in a dried up river bed while it's upright you can't push it off, you just have to abandon it. But if you drive your open top vehicle off a 50 foot cliff and it ends up sideways or upside down after bouncing around a few times (not damaging your health at all) you can just go to one side and spam the use key to flip it upright. All of this is very immersion breaking.The vehicle repair animation is stupid.I realize you can't expect them to put in a completely realistic fixing animation where you rebuild the engine or something, but at least have some variety. All you do is put a socket wrench on one nut and twist it for a few seconds. That's it. For every vehicle. If you get a repair manual, you twist faster, but only for that specific vehicle that the repair manual was for. Apparently buggies, ATV's, trucks, technicals, and even Jeep(TM)(R)(C)'s all have a magical nut that will instantly repair a vehicle to factory conditions when twisted. Who knew?There are no civilians outside.There is no friendly/neutral AI except the almost stationary buddies. This situation only makes sense at the very end of the game due to the story, but for practically the entire time there is no reason for it. Every single person outside is armed and dangerous. Every story mission you are an under cover operative and both sides will shoot you on sight unless you are in a cease-fire zone.There are infinitely spawning mobs and clairvoyant AI in Cease-fire zones.If you shoot anybody in a cease-fire zone, every single AI in that zone will (1) know your exact location and (2) infinitely respawn as hostile until you leave the zone and run a bit further, then you can immediately come back and they won't care. This hostile behavior happens even if nobody saw you take the shot with a silent weapon. Very immersion breaking.Weapon durability only applies to you.I get why durability is in the game, it makes sense to have a weapon degrade over time. An enemy's weapon never jams when he wields them. However, the instant he dies his weapon becomes utter ♥♥♥♥ and will jam like crazy until it explodes in your hands three reloads later. Some of the weapon design/behavior is horrible.The two that stand out the most to me are the MGL (that revolver like grenade launcher) and the dart gun. Now I don't know too much about guns, but I do know that the MGL (1) Has 6 grenade slots and (2) reloads like a revolver. It doesn't have 4 grenade slots in a magazine style reload system. This reload animation is just insulting. As for the dart gun, apparently it's hard to carry more than 10 darts the size of bullets. What is the point of having a silenced sniper rifle if you can only use it 10 times before you need to find ammo. Not to mention the gun has the worst reliability and on easy can break before you even run out of ammo. Wut?!I'd go on but I'm out of space. DON'T BUY THIS GAME!

												Far Cry 2 is one of the best shooters of all time. Like any good story, it's loosely inspired by Heart of Darkness. And believe you me, the story, barebones as it might seem (no traditional cutscene until the very very end), is shocking and incredible. Trust no one, shoot everything that moves, you will be friendlier with your ingame buddies than your real life ones, all that good vidyagamey stuff.Far Cry 2 avoids many of the flaws of its successor - a game I would best describe as Robinson Crusoe for somebody who wants a power trip. Not knocking its many successes (the animal system, etc), but many RPGs make the mistake of letting the player get away with pretty much anything in the lategame. Far Cry 2 is not an RPG. You will make decisions, but you're not in search of XP: you're in search of a better chance at survival, and if you're feeling lucky, maybe you'll try to keep your buddies alive too.Far Cry 2 is an experience.I chose to disable the crosshair because muh immersion (note the presence of ironsights makes that decision slightly less punishing compared to, say half-life) and I highly recommend you do the same as well, because this game, despite having questionable graphics from the mid-2000s, works best when you're immersed and twitchy and prepared mentally for the worst.Far Cry 2 gives you nothing. You have to earn every buddy, hoard every high quality weapon you own, build your reputation with the factions brick by brick. Regardless of your choice of APR or UFLL - pick your own lesser of two evils - your greatest enemy is the jungle itself. Your guns will jam and even break (usually when you need them most), the harsh terrain and many, many faction guard posts means that even a trip between two safehouses a mile apart must be planned and taken with the utmost caution, and don't even get me started on malaria. If you play Far Cry 2, prepare to be challenged.Far Cry 2 is a first person shooter that does not encourage combat. Even one soldier is a very valid threat of death. You do have a safety net in the form of your buddies, but don't rely on it. It's almost always better to detour around or sneak past a guard post than to plow through it. Stealth is encouraged but not rewarded - you can stealth kill, but guards will almost always scream out upon death, meaning that a kill threatens you more than helps you. Even carrying a sniper rifle at all times (highly recommended) and engaging from a great distance carries great risk, from multiple guards jumping in jeep and running and gunning you down, or mortar strikes, or a random patrol invalidating 90% of your hard work. Recommendation? Be ready to move, always keep your health high, and your life is worth more than anything else, even (especially?) the mission.Far Cry 2 will not leave you in the same place you began it. Many (most?) video games place you as the most important person in the world and give you all the tools to your success. This is not a power fantasy. This isn't even an underdog fantasy. This is hard work, and any reward will be in your head alone. You will be beaten down and beaten up, but if you beat the game, you will genuinely feel accomplishment and success unlike any game out there.

content:
ber 19, 2016
												Far Cry 2 is an open world FPS where you play as a merc hunting down "The Jackal"; a notorious arms dealer that has armed two warring factions (APR and UFLL) in an Unnamed African Country (UAC).In terms of gameplay, you will spend most of your time doing the following: -Driving through the jungle, savannah, desert, and rural town settings of the UAC. -Shooting, exploding, burning, or sniping your way through hostile outposts, infrastructure buildings taken over by enemies, and the roads of the UAC. -Looking for diamond cases.-Completing main missions for both the APR and the UFLL; (kill this guy, destroy this outpost, destroy part of the UAC’s infrastructure) and side missions that include buddy missions (kill this guy, blow up this structure, retrieve this object) , underground missions (give these passports to these refugees to get Malaria pills) gun runner missions(blow up this weapons convoy), and assassinations (kill random guy in suit and his bodyguards). These are all the mission varieties you will ever have.I listed driving first because you will be doing it A LOT in this game. There are only four fast travel points (bus stations) per section of the map (two sections); and most of your missions will force you to drive even if you take a bus to be closer to your destination. Unfortunately, driving in Far Cry 2 is hampered tremendously by two things: enemy patrols and the overall terrain. You can't go for even 4 minutes of driving without some patrol truck hunting you down. It gets worse at the second act of the game, when they get heavy mounted MGs and even one hit kill grenade launchers. Your vehicle will get stuck all the time in small holes in the ground, rocks, tree roots, small trees, other cars, etc. At least there’s a wide and believable variety of vehicles to choose from, ranging from trucks, ATVs, actual Jeeps, and even a buggy. The shooting in this game can be immensely satisfying. You can either go in guns blazing with machine guns, snipe from afar, use a mortar to thin out enemy positions, burn them with a flamethrower, or blow them up with RPGs. Stealth is supposedly an option, but the game isn’t really built for it since shooting even with silenced weapons alerts all the enemies in the vicinity.There are a lot of weapons to choose from, including assault rifles, pistols, machine pistols, LMGs, RPGs, sniper rifles, grenade launchers, etc. Experimenting with these will be your main incentive to obtain more diamonds, which will allow you to buy more of these weapons and their respective accuracy and reliability upgrades. Weapon jams and explosions are a feature of the game. The longer you use a weapon, the more prone it is to jam and eventually explode, and since all enemies use worn out weapons, buying from the arms dealer with your diamonds is a must.The combat AI in this game is well designed for the most part. Wound an enemy and his ally will come to his aid, allowing you to kill them both. Enemies will shoot towards your last known location, and if you’re no longer there, you can flank and shoot them with ease. The AI feels dynamic and believable, but it is relentless. If you’re spotted by an enemy patrol they will chase you, even on foot, and shoot you until you take them out. It can be quite overwhelming to face more than five of them at a time, because the foliage will prevent you from shooting back properly. Now, this game has several underdeveloped ideas that all aim towards a more “realistic” experience, but only interrupt gameplay and annoy the player. The worst offender by far is Malaria. You will need Malaria pills to treat your symptoms for every 40 minutes of real time. If your Malaria goes untreated, you will faint and magically reappear at the nearest main city. It breaks the flow of gameplay during exploration and missions. Were it not for Malaria, you wouldn’t even touch the Underground missions.You can repair any damage to your vehicles, (from explosions to machinegun fire) by tightening a single socket in the engine. Buying the vehicle’s manual (10-20 diamonds per manual), allows you to tighten the socket faster, but there are no changes in the animations or in the way you repair vehicles. Overall, it’s much simpler to find a new vehicle instead of stopping every 5 minutes to repair. In terms of player progression and overall changes in the game world, this game is quite lacking. When completing main missions,none of the factions will care that you recently murdered their leaders and hundreds of their comrades. Your missions are supposed to be “top secret” which supposedly explains why every outpost and soldier wants you dead even if you’re doing missions for their faction. But really, it’s too obvious that the developers simply didn’t code friendly AI for the soldiers. You will destroy a lot of the country’s infrastructure: the train tracks, the morphine production centers, the Malaria pill shacks, the WATER PIPELINES, the diamond mines, etc. You can visit these places again and see the destruction firsthand, but the amount and types of enemies, the amount of drinking water, diamonds, Malaria pills and the way to obtain them, will pretty much remain the same. Your efforts to support either faction end up feeling pointless.The same happens with buddy missions. You can have two buddies: One for upgrading the many safehouses throughout the UAC, and one that can come to your rescue if you get fatally wounded. You earn points by doing additional mission objectives for your buddy, or doing buddy missions, which is really pointless considering that a “level 3 buddy” will give you all the same benefits as a “level 15 buddy”.  You never learn anything new from their stories, which are summed up in two or three sentences at most. Hunting for diamond cases can be a lot of fun, but some of them seem to be impossible to reach. Nowadays it can be regarded as a way to pad out game length, but I found entertaining.*SPOILERS* The story in this game won’t pick up until the second act. You will support the equally tyrannical and selfish APR and UFLL because you’re looking for information about the whereabouts of the Jackal. But your character never really tries to learn where the Jackal is, and your employers never tell you anything. You will NEVER hunt down the Jackal, and by the third time you see him, you will be working with him. It just feels nonsensical because of all the people and infrastructure you will destroy for killing a single guy who probably caused less death and destruction than you did. The game justifies this change of heart by presenting the Jackal as a “humanist” who is tired of the war and wants to save the civilians, but it all feels forced. The developers need to be given credit for how gorgeous the game looks even for 2016 standards, and the style that they chose for the game. The game runs smoothly and beautifully on modern rigs, and asides from a few AI glitches, everything looks, sounds, and feels as if you were in an actual African jungle, savannah, or desert. Structures, vehicles and weapons look used, broken down, barely functional, worn out. It really adds to the immersion in a spectacular way. The way you can create dynamic bushfires in this game is amazing and a viable strategy in the drier regions of the map.Despite all all of its problems, inconsistencies, glitches, and underdeveloped ideas, this game can be a lot of fun. It took me a while to complecomplete my first playthrough on Infamous difficulty, along with all the side missions, almost all of the diamond cases, and all the weapon and vehicle upgrades. All the while, I was having a blast on the combat segments; even if the driving wasn’t so smooth and game progression was non-existent. I can safely recommend this game to anyone remotely interested in open world or FPS games, just know that this ride can get a bit bumpy.

												In Far Cry 2's chaotic world of mercenaries, gunrunners, and armed militias, you'll find yourself dropped into a dizzying web of shady clients and paper-thin alliances. All manner of names and faces are introduced during the course of the storyline, but the real star isn't anyone brandishing a smuggled weapon in search of blood diamonds; it's the daunting and awe-inspiring 50-square kilometers of African landscape that make up the game's open-world setting. Aside from providing the opportunity to soak up an amazing sunset, Far Cry 2's free-roaming terrain brilliantly harmonizes with the first-person combat. The diverse landscape and myriad environmental factors work alongside a wide assortment of weaponry to give you tremendous freedom to approach each mission. Combined with solid multiplayer, Far Cry 2's sheer breadth of action provides you with plenty of reason to stay lost in the African wilderness despite an underwhelming plot and the occasional sense of tedium in navigating from one location to another on the gargantuan map.Far Cry 2 is quite the looker.Far Cry 2 is quite the looker.Far Cry 2's story is filled with potential. You're a mercenary working for a client who's sent you to an unnamed African nation engulfed in civil war, and your job is to take out a notorious arms dealer known as "The Jackal." He quickly proves to be an elusive figure, so you'll need to begin working for various warring factions that the Jackal has armed so you can trace the supply line back to your target. The two primary organizations at the heart of all this bloodshed are the militaristic UFLL and the revolutionary APR. You'll spend the bulk of the story working for these two groups, getting to know their power structures, and taking on all of the violent tasks they throw your way. Complicating things is the fact that your character has malaria, which means you'll need to occasionally play nice with the more ragtag Underground, the only group with the medical connections necessary to keep your potentially life-threatening symptoms at bay.Each story mission can be played in multiple ways. There are 12 potential buddies randomly scattered throughout the storyline who you can befriend (nine of whom are available to choose as your silent protagonist), and they're often keen to tack on their own interests to the quests handed out by the UFLL and APR. Instead of just taking out a target, you have the option to earn extra reputation points by working alongside your buddy to first squeeze any remaining assets from the soon-to-be-deceased. This also earns you the ability to increase your level of companionship with that buddy. It's a neat reward, but it doesn't shed much light on their backgrounds. But that's par for the course; the main story is delivered in such a rushed, quick-and-dirty way that you never feel very involved in the game's overarching conflicts. The plot is less Blood Diamond than it is early Grand Theft Auto, a long roster of changing faces that scroll by far too quickly to capitalize on the politically charged setting.Although disappointing for a single-player campaign that could easily drain more than 30 hours of your time, any shortcomings in the plot are mostly forgivable thanks to Far Cry 2's overall structure. The game is organized in a way that provides a daunting amount of freedom to explore, earn currency, and wreak havoc on the game's landscape and its denizens. It's all laid out in a manner typical of sandbox action games. Pulling out your map reveals a collection of icons that signify available missions and points of interest that you can meander toward at your own leisure. Among these are dozens of side missions that you can take on, with various forms of rewards. Delivering transit papers to trapped refugees earns you malaria medication, destroying rival convoys for gun merchants unlocks new weapons for purchase, and performing assassinations for mysterious voices at the other end of your cell phone rewards you with diamonds. You can also rough up militias stationed in small camps and turn their dwellings into your own safe houses. The side missions can feel a bit repetitive when played through in rapid succession, but they offer a great change of tempo when sprinkled throughout the main narrative. But what's most clever is how their differing rewards intermingle so wonderfully with your needs in progressing through the story: Malaria pills keep your HP and stamina up, diamonds buy you new weapons and ability upgrades, and safe houses provide temporary shelter to stock up and save your game.With so much ground to cover, you'll be spending a lot of time driving, boating, running, and swimming.With so much ground to cover, you'll be spending a lot of time driving, boating, running, and swimming.The freedom of choice that goes with selecting which mission you want to perform carries over to how you execute them, and that's where Far Cry 2 really shines. There are a variety of factors that affect the way you approach each mission, from the number of people you need to kill, to the landscape, to the weather and time of day. If your job is to take out a key figure hidden deep within a militia camp in the jungle, you'll do well to take a nap at your safe house until nightfall and silently stalk your prey under the cover of darkness. If it's a windy day and you need to take out a bandit outpost in the dry plains, you can start a fire from far away with a flare gun and let the breeze and arid conditions collude to spread the flames toward their camp, finishing off the survivors with a sniper rifle. Need to clear out a bunch of scattered guards? Why not shoot an oil drum near an ammo stockpile and watch as the bullets erupt in every direction like deadly pieces of popcorn? Of course, you can also get up close and personal with pistols and machine guns, but the moments in which elaborately planned assaults succeed are some of the most gratifying points in the game. The whole process of staging an attack only becomes more intricate and rewarding as you slowly upgrade your safe house into a full-blown armory and unlock new weapon and vehicle abilities--all done through the gun shops.Overall, Far Cry 2 is a game in which you can quite literally get lost for hours at a time. But that feeling of exploration is precisely what makes the game so much fun; your creativity never feels stifled when approaching a mission, and the game's overall structure of side tasks, friends, rewards, and upgrades is a diverse ecosystem rivaling the landscape itself. No matter whether you're a PC fan whose played through the similarly structured Crysis or a console owner new to the world of open-ended first-person shooters, you won't be disappointed by Far Cry 2.

												It took every part of my being to push through and finally see Far Cry 2 to the end. This is because it's not only mentally exhausting, but emotionally as well.Let's get what it doesn't do well out of the way, because it doesn't do a lot of ♥♥♥♥ well. There's all sorts of fun things that people hate like weapon degredation, the malaria mechanic which gives you a vomit-tinged screen until you press H and pop a refreshing malaria-fighting Certs into your mouth, the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ open world which is full of repetitive quests that revolve around shooting the other soldiers of fortune you're working alongside of, or shooting a man in a suit, or blowing up a truck that's driving around in circles. It's really, really ♥♥♥♥ing grindy too. The secondary missions don't offer much more than just your stupid mercenary friend calling you up in the middle of your mission to ask you to do something so he can be a bigger, more amoral ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for dollars than you can. All it is is you being an unpleasant little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for money to other unpleasant little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s also here for money. Are you still with me? Good. Because it turns out that this game has so many flaws it has essentially developed Three Stooges Syndrome, the syndrome where it has lots of bad ideas yet they all don't end up killing the game, but rather strengthening it.All of the things up there would normally have killed my interest in this game really ♥♥♥♥ing dead. And they did the last two times I tried to play it, all the way back in 2010. But today, the game clicks for me. I don't know whether it was the depressed state I was in or whether I've realized that AAA video game design has been so design-by-committee that this was the thing I ended up dying for. This game ended up satisfying something I wasn't aware that I needed than, say, Grand Theft Auto 5 or Saints Row the Third, which are just straight-up celebrations of how awesome you are. Far Cry 2 tells you to your face that you're just another ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in a jungle with a barely functioning weapon, and that you won't matter if you live or die.But also at this point in time, the mental state of your mind also is very, very helpful when getting into this game. In order to actually sit down and play it, you must learn to accept the environment that the game is forcing you into. Everything is ♥♥♥♥. War is constant. The missions suck. Nothing really works. You are accepting missions in order to make like worse for everybody. Your guns get dirty really fast. You're trading rough diamonds for all the guns you can get your hands on. Absolute ♥♥♥♥♥ in buggies and jeeps and cars will drive off the road to try and run you down for no other reason than you are there, and you are a target, and everyone hates you. Everyone hates you here in Africa, and if it means that you will die so that there's one less target to shoot, you're gonna get shot. You are a person in a ♥♥♥♥ tornado. And the ♥♥♥♥ tornado has everyone you know and love in it. And you all can't stop ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ into the ♥♥♥♥ tornado. 												What's best about Far Cry 2?The true answer is that there is no one thing that can be considered best about Far Cry 2. Its brilliance lies in the fact that it is more than the sum of its already impressive parts. Essentially the game is a playground that caters for whatever mood players find themselves in. Want to storm into an enemy encampment in broad daylight John Rambo style, perhaps running a few unfortunate soldiers down with a MG-mounted Jeep before letting loose with your grenade launcher? Go ahead. Prefer to fast-forward the incredible day/night cycle to midnight by taking a nap in one of the Safe Houses and sneak in under the cover of darkness before slicing and dicing from behind with your machete? Be the game's guest.Ubisoft Montreal isn't, of course, the first developer to do open world shooting.But it is so well executed, so technically proficient that I can't help but feel it at least matches and in some areas even surpasses other games of the genre.After choosing from a selection of nine refreshingly un-clichéd mercenaries, ranging from a 45-year-old Mauritian to a 38-year-old Algerian you're thrust into an unnamed African country being torn apart by two warring factions.Your mission: To kill The Jackal, an arms dealer who's fuelling both sides of the conflict with weapons, and making a mint as a result. You immediately run into problems - malaria wraps its diseased mitts around your innards, forcing you to collapse as soon as you arrive in town. You wake, groggily, and find The Jackal standing ominously above you. He knows everything - who you are, why you're here and how defenceless you've become as a result of the malaria. In pity, he hands you a machete and a hand gun, and lets you live. This is where Far Cry 2 kicks off.Outside, all hell breaks loose. The United Front for Liberation and Labour (UFLL) and the Alliance for Popular Resistance (APR) are going at it in the streets. You make a break for it, dodging bullets as you head anywhere as long as it's away from certain death. But there is no escape - either you're shot or you collapse from the malaria. You wake in a slaughter house just outside town. A merc, one that you did not pick to play as at the beginning of the game but is determined by that choice, now reckons you owe him a few favours on account of him saving your ♥♥♥. From there, it's up to you what jobs you take on, whether it be paid work from the UFLL or APR, malaria pill jobs from various good Samaritans, weapon vendor jobs that unlock new purchasable gear, buddy jobs that improve your 'history' with the NPC mercs or assassination jobs dished out by a disguised voice heard from communication masts. What they all have in common, however, is combat, and it's here that Far Cry 2 initially frustrates.I'm used to developers holding my hands so tightly during game tutorials, and even beyond, that Far Cry 2 will at first jar with many due to the fact that it's actually pretty tough right from the start. Simply shooting stuff is difficult. Unlike the console versions, the PC version doesn't have a snap to target function when you zoom down the barrel of your gun. This is fine - the PC keyboard and mouse set up allows for a degree of FPS accuracy console controllers simply can't. But this doesn't stop your weapons, especially at the beginning of the game, from being, frankly, crap.You'll find the recoil offensive, the jamming so regular you'll tear your hair out and the enemies so hard to spot in your splendid surroundings that it won't be long before you grab a mouthful of dirt. The healing system doesn't help. Whenever your health dips you can inject yourself with magic hit point juice. That's fine, but when your health bar is almost depleted healing will instead trigger an animation where you gruesomely pick bullets out of the holes in your skin. The problem is that this animation, which takes about five seconds to complete, is interruptible by enemy fire. Some will applaud Ubisoft Montreal's approach. Some will criticise it. Whatever your opinion, persevere. Soldier through the difficult opening few hours, keep earning diamonds, keep reducing the recoil and reliability of your weapons with upgrades, and above all, keep experimenting, because it's only through experimentation that you'll realise Far Cry 2's undoubted potential.The save system differs from the console versions in that you can save absolutely anywhere and whenever you want. There are no checkpoints in Far Cry 2, at least not in the traditional sense of the term. Instead, you'll get a pop-up asking you if you want to save after you complete mission objectives, when you use the coach transportation system or when you go to sleep using one of the Safe Houses. The many guarded checkpoints will annoy some, but for others they will reinforce the feeling that you're never safe. Because the map is so big, you'll spend a lot of your time driving around. If you're going to stick to the road, you're going to run into at least three checkpoints along the way. Every soldier manning the checkpoints has a shoot first, ask questions later policy, too, making driving more a case of survival than sight seeing. The enemies respawn, too, so you can never once and for all clear enemies from that check point on that road you keep using to get to and from town.Obviously if you're a shooter fan you should buy this game. A simple glance at the score should confirm in your mind, if there was ever any doubt, that Far Cry 2 is nothing but brilliant.

												This is a fantastic game with one of the best environments and gameplay I have ever experienced. Despite this, I have heard so many complaints and gripes about this fine title. Many jump into this open world game expecting the many side missons of FC3, or the hand holding of many modern FPS games, and complain when FC2 does not accomidate them. Many also whine when the story does not cater to their ideals and makes them make hard, immoral, decisions. "The story is crap," they say "The ending made me feel bad." I've also heard many complain that playing as an often heartless merc made them feel uncomfortable. How can that be bad? If a game can provoke an emotional response like that, then it has done a fine job. I have heard people, in the same breath, complain about the fast respawn time for enemy outposts breaking immersion, then say that the method of quick travel (finding a bus to take you to another bus stop after a loading screem) isn't easy enough to access and traveling is a pain. I say false to both statements, especially since they contradict each other. Having a world full of hostile entities makes you prepare for such encouters, and also refills the world with more enemies to fight, something that I feel FC3 lacked after you cleared out outposts. As for having to drive for awhile for any mission, I never could go more than a minute without something exploding, cathcing fire, or shooting at me. With all of this being said, I do acknowledge that this game is not for everyone. Since it does NOT hold your hand in, and instead is fairly abrasive, be it via malaria attack, a lucky mortar strike, or a jamming gun, it likely doesn't appeal to anyone who is looking for some mindless fun/action a la Metal Gear Rising or FC3. This game is rough, and can be frusterating at times, but because of these same qualities, I love this game for not being afraid of trying something different. As a result, I have never played another FPS that has gotten my heart rate up so much everytime an enemy appeared.Play it, try it, but DON'T expect FC2 to hand you anything.

content:

												TL;DR ... for all its faults, FC2 is a "summer popcorn movie" video game that's enjoyable if you just switch your brain off and go with the flow.~~~~~~~~~~~BackgroundFC2 came out when "open world" and "50+ hours of gameplay" started becoming buzzwords on games. It comes from the generation of games that were more focused on creating massive playing areas, then didn't have enough time to pad them with actual game play.So, they slapped in a bunch of repetetive, cookie-cutter missions, scavenger hunts and enemy AI that's stupid but makes up for it by being programmed to cheat.I got this game when it first came out, b/c I had just built a new dual-core rig (when dual-cores had just come out), and wanted to see what it could do by playing Crysis, Far Cry 2, and other games of the time. Picked it up again during steam summer sale, and the good and bad come rushing back.To pro/con it, I have to break it down by components, since each component has pro/con.~~~~~~~~~~~PLOTPro: it tries to delve into some deeper aspects about moralityCon: It gets pretty pretentious and self-righteous for it's own good. It's hard to follow as you're thrown right into the middle of confusion without much explanation, and even your journal and cut-scene tip text doesn't help much. But, overall, you're not missing much. You're basically a lackey for everyone, so switch your brain off and ignore thinking.~~~~~~~~~~~NPC'sPro: there's large varieties of themCon: They were trying to cut-down on file size, so it seems they sped up everyone's dialogue after recording it. Everyone talks super-fast, which makes it difficult to follow, especially ones that have accents.~~~~~~~~~~~ALLIESPro: you get a "buddy" that can help revive you out in the fieldCon: it feels like what they wanted to do was let you have an AI NPC follow you on missions like a side-kick. Instead, they were rushed for time, couldn't implement that, so instead they just implement some half-a**ed cutscene with a buddy helping you out, then acting completely stupid in fire fights as they die from either standing out in the middle of now where, getting caught in a brush fire like an idiot, etc, etc. Basically, to enjoy the game, just think of your Allies as nothign more then quest givers, and ignore any aspect of them "participating" with you...because you will feel it is very lackluster if you do think of them as a "companion".~~~~~~~~~~~MISSIONSPro: there's lots of themCon: they're all the same cookie-cutter design ... go here, kill everything, collect this. I don't mind that so much (again, we're switching our brains off to enjoy this). What bothers me is you can only have 1 quest at a time. And the quest giver and the actual quest are usually on opposite sides of the massive map. So, you get a quest, spend half an hour getting there, complete it in 5 minutes, then spend another half hour getting back to the quest giver. While out and about, you will see other quest opportunities. You can't take them, or they will cancel your current quest. This is beyond dumb. For a map of this size, they should let you gather quests, then take care of all of them at once when in the area of operation.~~~~~~~~~~~ENEMIESPro: there's a variety of enemy dress and faces, plus they use guns you can useCon: the enemy AI is a bipolar mess of smart and dumb. You sniper a guy, and some will take cover while others try to investigate. Some will flank you and surprise you, but you realize they can only do this because their footsteps have been purposefully made extra quiet so you don't hear them. So, it feels cheap when they ambush you. The ones taking cover behind buildings won't come out. You can sneak around and pick them off with a sniper from a distance and they stay in duck-n-cover formation. I literally looked over a cliff. Saw two guys hiding. I shot one. The other guy didn't do anything. He just saw his buddy die, but he keeps hiding there. I shoot him, too. *facepalm* The devs purposefully made the AI cheat to give them a competitive advantage to challenge you. They will use their amazing eagle eyes to spot you through foliage and cover then chase or snipe you even though they are nothing but a dot in your sniper scope. Their clothes blend into the color pallette of the game, so it's hard to detect them. They will make next to no noise while walking through brush looking for you even though you sound like a herd of elephants while crouch-sneaking. When the game first came out (before patches) they were even able to run 50mph to catch up to you if you were driving through a checkpoiint without engaging them (thankfully that seems to have been fixed). But, basically... don't expect super impressive AI.~~~~~~~~~~~GUNPLAYPro: FC2 let's you load out with a primary, secondary and support weapon. This is pretty ingenious, because it lets you tailor your load out to your play style and/or mission.Con: I usually consider myself good at FPS (grew up on Doom and Quake), but FC2 has been brutal in run-n-gun play style. The PC is slow, can't sprint very far or fast, and likes to stop moving to do lots of activities (eg: malaria kicks in... better stop in the middle of this street while getting shot to take a pill instead of letting the player make me keep walking while doing so). Machine guns are jump as all get out, but sniper rifles have completely perfect, stationary zoom making head shots from a mile easy. Standing 10' away from a guy, you will watch as you can't hit him point-blank... unless you bring up your iron sights to target. You get a silenced sniper rifle (dart rifle), but it's not considered a primary weapon and is severely hobbled on ammo. There's just all these baffling design decisions.~~~~~~~~~~~WORLDPro: it's largeCon: everything is the same color pallete of "browns and greens that easily blend into each other". The world is so large that it takes half an hour to get to your mission site. There are so many mountains that all driving feels like "corridor" driving in that you rarely have very open areas to zoom through. Plus, when there are, there are so many trees and rocks in the way you can't really go too fast. There doesn't seem to be any permanancy in the world, too. You take a car from a place. Come back later... the car is there again, reset, as if it was never taken. And nobody gets upset over you taking vehicles. There are "checkpoints" throughout the place where enemies hang out and make it hard to pass through. You clear one out. Come back 5 minutes later...it's repopulated again like nothing happened! This makes you feel as if your actions are pointless / worthless, and dissuades you from clearing places out. (ie: you would have incentive to clear a place out if it stayed cleared out, but since it respawns 5 seconds later, you start to just avoid conflicts by going out of your way to go around those places since they just become time wasters). Diamonds are used as currency to buy new weapons, and they spread HUNDREDS of these suit cases to go scavenger hunt all over the place to pad the game with "game play" that isn't really compelling game play.~~~~~~~~~~~Did I mention you need to switch your brain off?There's a lot "wrong" with the game, but it is what it is due to the open-world fantacism + huge push for better graphics that was all the rage back then (and still sort of is).Overall, I still recommend the game, because it's entertaining going on missions and clearing places out. Sitting on a rock sniping people, pulling out a grenade launcher and blowing up vehicles with occupants still in them, tossing a moltov and lighting up a bunch of grass to burn people to death... it's mind-numbing fun.The game is best if you fire it up, spend an hour running a mission, then turning it off for a bit.

												Let me start by saying that this open-world FPS isn't for everyone. I started playing this game years ago, and i finally finished it only a couple weeks ago. This is partly because of the massiveness of the game, and partly because of the repetitive nature of it. One review i read of this game said it's the game that "doesn't give you what you want, and slaps you for asking". This is very true, the game presents many obstacles (guns that deteriorate and jam, malaria that makes you have to take medicine at any given point in the game, lack of ammo & resources, etc.) and doesn't have a single auto save. Every save is manual. Every. One. Fast travel is hardly any faster than driving across the giant map, because you can only travel to and from one of 5 fast travel stations on the map. And let me tell you, vehicles in this game do NOT go fast.This giant stew of inconveniences is what gives this game it's value. The setting is Africa, a wasteland containing only violence, disease, and scarcity. By making the player endure these frustrations, Far Cry 2 gives every convenience you recieve a kind of personal importance. The regular attacks from enemies beat you down until you become a proud killing machine. The slow and dangerous nature of transportation in this open world gives you a familiarity with the map, and maybe (what happened in my case) an unprecedented respect for the design. The story plays a passive role in this game (kill things, get payed, get closer to completing your main mission), but it fits into the violent & depressing theme. The ending, however, is fantastic. This game is slow. The combat is relentless and routine. You have to struggle to complete each mission, and the characters are all shallow. By stripping away all the usual comforts you would expect to find, Far Cry 2 does something extraordinary. It puts you outside of your comfort zone. You're alone in this troublesome world, and you have to discover for yourself how to make it out alive.

r 17, 2015
Far Cry 2 is one of a kind experience and although is quite criticized by fans of the franchise I find it to be one of the most underrated games I have seen.50km2 of awesomness	Set on Africa, you take the role of a mercenary who finds himself in a middle of a war. The Government has been dismantled and there are now two factions trying to take control over it. Your goal is simple: kill the Jackal, an infamous drug dealer who benefits from the war selling guns to both factions.	In order to do so, you must shot your way to the Jackal. You can ally with both or just one faction which makes for a non-linear story; something really appreciated for those who value replay-ability.	Powered by Dunia Engine, the visuals are really well done and you will find yourself on savannas and desserts within a effectively designed world. The engine does a good job improving the stealth aspect thanks to day/night cycles that actually varies the way the IA work as well as includying dynamic fire propagation on the grass along others. Inmersive and awesome to explore	As the franchise got as accustomed, the world is filled with cars, trucks, hang gliders, boats and ATV's. Throughout the story, you will need to take pills that help you to control your malaria. Oh, yeah! You got malaria at the very beginning of the story. Failing to take said pills (which runs out really fast) will make you pass out and you will have to restart the mission again.	There is not a big selection of guns on this one though. I have to note also just how minimalistic and inmersive the interface on this game is. You don't check the map by a popup window in front of the actual gameplay but rather, your character holds an actual map wherever you need it and so on with a lot of elements on the game. Those are little details I love to find given they improve the impression that you are really there.It definitely has its problems, though	I hope you like driving, because oh boy, you are going to drive a lot. Not that it gets incredibly tedious. During your driving you will find enemies along the way which helps keeping things interesting. However, you are still going to drive a lot.	Likewise, to be considered a realistic game it's surprising how long it takes to kill enemies. Not everyday you see a regular person wearing nothing but a t-shirt get shot six times on the chest and still count the story, but enemies on Far Cry 2 sure can. Nevertheless, it works both ways considering you can walk to an enemy from a good distance while he is shooting directly at you and still kill him with a machete. The story is great, with interesting dialogues and memorable quotes but I really could never put my heands on the multiplayer, something about Ubisoft's servers not responding when I tried to sing up. I have never heard of it being shut down but to be honest I haven't bothered to look up much on the subject. Multiplayer was just a feature in this game, singleplayer is where the fun part is at.Playing this game on the Hardcore or Infamous difficulty mode makes it so much enjoyable, really. Because you can't get shot nearly as much as Normal you start making better strategies than just show up with your car in the middle of your enemy's base and start shooting everywhere like you were blind-folded. So, should you buy it? You're damn right you should. Far Cry 2 has to be one of the most enjoyable shooters I have ever played. An awesome game about exploring, surviving and killing so you can get a sweet, sweet revenge on everything the Jackal has put you and others through. Oh, and also, about driving. A hella lot of it. Let's also take a moment to appreciate the fact that this was (and probably will) be the last Far Cry without uPlay DRM. Anyway, despite all the flaws (which aren't that many, really) Far Cry 2 is well worthy of your money.

18, 2014
												Finally got around to playing this game. The only reason i never finished it before is because I was annoyed with the malaria aspect but it turns out only to be a minor annoyance in the game. I finished Far Cry 3 before finishing Far Cry 2, although I started playing it years ago. I always knew I would come back to it and I am glad I finally did. I won't do any comparison to the original FarCry because that is entirely a different game, in my opinion.I found FC3 far too easy, being able to track your opponents, even through trees and rocks nerfed the difficulty enough, and getting special superpowers as you level up only made it worse. In FC2, you have malaria, which is like, the opposite of a superpower and became a hazard if you started having an "attack" in the middle of battle. And also, you have weapon jams which happen randomly as your weapon wears down. A weapon jam might sound annoying but it is a little detail in the game that adds a little realism and extra challenge to the game which I can appreciate. Your "buddys" are randomly chosen from your character choices from the beginning of the game, each with their own look and dialog.  You also have the chance to get incapacitated instead of dying, getting revived by a buddy for a second chance to finish the fight. if you go down too soon after though, it is game over. When you are low on health and apply first aid, the animations go from wrapping up a wound on your arm to pulling a bullet out of your flesh with a knife and plyers. Another way it differs from FC3 is your character is not the focus of the game story whatsoever. The story is really about the Jackal, the factions and Africa, and you are just someone who is in the right place at the wrong time. You do get to choose a character, which only effects how your hands and arms look in the gameAll these little details make a very unique first person shooter experience, and I think really smart game devs can learn from playing this oneIn the end, the only real problem I had with FC2 was not the malaria, but the fact that I couldnt use a custom loadout. Every weapon falled under primary, secondary or special and you could only carry one of each. Meaning I could not use a sniper rifle and an SMG at the same time as they were both considered primary weapons.The good far outweighs the bad though, and if you are jaded with your regular FPS experience, give this one a try.-edit- 2 years after this reviewI'm convinced this was one of Ubisoft's last good games. Also, it doesnt require uplay.

ry 7, 2015
												It's not the violent slapstick and chain-splodes of the hysterically volatile camps, filled to the brim with ammo dumps and fuel tanks. It's not the moments of pure adrenalised catharsis, where, rifle in hand, you power through smoke and machinegun fire, enemies to the left and right. It's not even when you stride through the ruins, calmly putting down survivors by plunging a machete into their chests.No. Its appeal is in the moments beforehand - when, from some lofty perch, you think of what's to come. You check your ammo. You reload your weapons. You heal up. You anticipate. It is the calm before the storm. You are the match before the flame. In the most player-centric world yet created, in a game that you know is about to surprise, delight and enthral you, standing still, waiting to strike, is one of the finest pleasures you can experience.After playing Far Cry 2, I'm simply unable to go back to straight and simple first-person shooters. This game has executed my expectations. Would you, could you, go back to games with similar gunfights as this, but along a more rigid axis? I think your own expectations are going to rise dramatically. And I think you really should play this game.

												Before reviewing this amazing game, I decided to play it for quite a while. As of the time I am writing this, I have two hours. Most of my reviews haven't been helpful, and I really want this one to help people geniunely decide if this is a game they want to invest in or not. Let's start off with the basics. Intro So you start up the game, and click new game. There are 9 characters to choose from, each from different nationalities with different voices, buddies (which I will go into detail of later), and ages. All the characters are male, though. Difficulty Levels There are 4 difficulty levels. Easy, Normal, Hard, And Infamous. On to the next thing.. Unscripted Player-Driven Events! Unfortunately for modern gaming, this is something most new games lack. Far Cry 2 is great for this kind of thing. Something I Found on IGNMarty dragged me out of the line of fire and into the bushes when a random group of guys jumped me on the road. Stupid. You never take the road. A gunner on the back of a truck mowed me down while I fell into my own misplaced Molotov flames. Marty hands me a pistol and opens fire. I find a couple grenades, knock the truck around, and finish the job. When it’s all done, I hear Marty screaming for help. I can’t see him.By the time I find his blue smoke streaming out of the woods, he’s grunting incoherently. I kneel down, jab a regenerative needle into his stomach, and wait for him to head home. He doesn’t get up. He’s still wounded, so I put another needle in him. Nothing, but he slows down, and his eyes roll upward. One more needle. Marty’s head hits the ground, and he stops squirming.I overdosed my best friend.Something that happened to me in game (Not IGN)When I was playing Far Cry 2, I was crouched behind a car. I fired off a few shots at a guy, and he was killed. I realised something; I was wounded! As my health was rapidly pouring away, I quickly healed myself, but while I was doing that, my car exploded and fell on me. Instant death.On to gameplay and stuff! Gameplay The gameplay is quite hard. If you are a newcomer and download the RealMode mod and play on Infamous difficulty for the first run of the game? You will die. A lot. You might die even without the mod. This game is BLOODY HARD AS ****.  Pick up a enemy weapon? Well prepare for it to be unreliable as hell. Snipers explode in your arms without any notice, guns jam, deal less damage... Recoil is a whole different thing. With weapons you purchase at the gun shops, they will do more damage, accuracy, etc. They also have a permanent "good" condition. However, firearms you "borrow" from your dead enemies, are quite the opposite; With inferior range, accuracy, and damage.  Wrap Up & Conclusion This game has its pros and cons..PROS- Amazing openworld experience- Great fun- Is pretty old and still looks amazing- Supports mods- Player driven eventsCONS- wtf is a con there is none buy this gameAll in all... BUY THIS DAMN GAME RIGHT NOW

												After many hours of stabbing my way through Farcrys 3 and 4, i was overall pleased with the changes made to the gameplay in those titles. Smoother, polished gameplay and greatly enhanced driving is what i enjoyed most about 3 and 4. They are great games, but they also felt like fantasy stories at times. That is why Farcry 2, in my opinion, shines above them.Gritty combat in a dark war torn nation is part of why this game is still the best in the series. Everything just feels so real. If one of your buddies die, tough ♥♥♥♥, he/she is gone forever. Malaria and jammed weapons make this game even more unforgiving. Shooting up an enemy checkpoint to steal their ammo and meds is also a little unsettling when you later see a guy on the ground, bleeding and screaming about how he wants to go home, but he can olny watch as you come crouch next to him and put a bullet in his head. The setting and feel is perfect, and the gameplay follows suit.Simply put, Farcry 2 is a game that requires strategy and patience, which is a great change of pace from the usual FPS realm. An interesting variety of weapons and a storyline that holds more than meets the eye make this game one of a kind. Replay value is very high, considering the unpredictability of the AI, the enviroment, and also how you choose to approach each mission. A satisfiying one man army experience is felt when played on hardcore or infamous difficulty. Ignite the conflict. Make them fear you. 9/10--To get the most out of this game and bring it to its true potential, i HIGHLY recommend installing Dylan's realism mod and sproyd's enhanced graphics mod, both of which are easy to install and can be found at moddb.com--

23, 2013
												What sets this apart from other shooters is the overall theme. Everything feels honest and real, from the syrettes and the malaria to the politics and ultimately the narrative. Without spoiling anything, I'll say your mission from the beginning is to take out an arms dealer, but as you get acquainted with other characters it becomes something much more. No matter which character you play as, you aren't a hero — you're not even a remotely good guy. As the story progresses you will come to terms with that fact, and how you deal with it is entirely up to you. By the end this game delivers a very powerful message. I really like the open world and how missions can be completed in many different ways, both by teaming up with the NPC buddies (optional) and also by learning the enemies' realisitc AI. Enemies react differently based on the weather, time of day, which weapons you're using, etc. It's a really deep system if you want to learn all the ins and outs. Otherwise just play it like any other game and it's still fun. There's a lot of variety in the landscape: jungles, plains, mountains, deserts, etc. There's also a lot of detail: Blades of grass part realistically when you sneak through fields. Hang gliders are a great way to travel and provide some amazing scenic views along the way. The Act 2 map is just as large as the Act 1 map, which I thought was already large enough for the entire game to take place in. That was a really great surprise. The Fortune's DLC adds a lot of new side missions to complete whenever you want to work on them, which add a lot of lore to what's going on in the war torn country. It also adds a little ATV which is by far the fastest means of getting around, and a crossbow which shoots incendiary arrows that explode on impact. Overall I thoroughly enjoyed every hour of Far Cry 2. I found it to be much more immersive than the first game. It still looks great today, and now that Far Cry 3 is out the price is really low!

content:
ry 17, 2016
												Far Cry 2 heavily expands the appealing, basic formula established in Far Cry 1. I would call it the first modern Far Cry game since most of the hallmark Far Cry features come into their own in this title. The core of a Far Cry/Crysis game is fast paced, streamlined, semi-realistic, immersive first person military shooter in large open environments where the player is free to explore multiple approaches (stealth, close range assault, sniping, explosives, vehicles, turrets, or any combination thereof) to overcoming enemies. Far Cry 2 also introduces a large open-world, non-linear mission system with multiple factions, weapon and equipment unlocks, safe houses and buddy companion-system. The central african environments are breathtaking and the game takes great pains to immerse the player in the environment. The HUD is incredibly minimal with most actions and situations being context sensitive and told through actual interaction with the environment. For example, rather than healing being simply invisible (the health bar just refills), you'll see your character inject a syrette in his/her forearm, reset a broken limb, or pull a bullet from a gaping wound in their leg. The map just doesn't appear on the HUD, you actually pull a physical map and GPS out. When your character suffers the affects of malaria, you're vision will blur and turn green and you'll have to pull out a pill bottle and swallow a pill to counter-act the effects. All these things effectively serve to immerse the player in the world, but don't inhibit gameplay. The enemy AI is also very sophisticated and will communicate with one another, actively hunt for you and attempt to surround you (or where they think you are), or even get scared and take cover or run. My primary grievance is that random encounters when traveling can be a bit to frequent and bypassing frequent road blocks and guard posts can get to be a grinding chore in traveling around the map.The mission system that unveils the story is fun and engrossing. The story is not just handed to you, but the player will have to really pay attention if they want to figure out what is really going on. The interplay of the factions, the player, and their buddies is fascinating and keeps the game fresh from start to finish. The side missions do get a bit redundant though, which include destroy arm shipments, and assassinations. Luckily, the core Far Cry gun play is solid and doesn't get old quickly. It is fun when a situation goes from you getting a jump on a bunch of enemies to reinforcements showing up and surrounding you as you run short on ammo and having to fight for your life to break the encirclement and make a run for it. Which brings me to the buddy system which is rich and unrivaled in any FPS/RPG that I have seen. The system is rather organic and you really seem to build a relationship and history with your buddies who are fellow mercenaries try to profit in this little civil war.All in all, there are few games I can safely recommend as must plays for anyone, but this is definitely one of them.

content:
er 8, 2016
												Far Cry 2 was a bold game, and the perfect example of a diamond in the rough, if you will.After the original highly-acclaimed game set the players up in an exotic tropical locale and had them face up against mutants and various other assorted enemies, the sequel instead drops them in an Unnamed African Country where the worst monster is man. Finding themselves in the midst of a civil war between two warring factions, the player is hired to kill the Jackal, an arms dealer supplying both factions with weapons and thus fuelling the furnace. However, things go awry, the player contacts malaria and are caught in a crossfire they barely escape from. Penniless, weaponless and without any contacts, they will need to work their way up on the 'social ladder' if they are to reach their end goal.If there's two words that would describe Far Cry 2 perfectly, they would be 'world building'. The game actually manages to make the prospect of trudging through a dull, brown African country interesting, simply because of all the small details the game throws at you. As mentioned before, the PC is sick with malaria and must take pills regularly, even if a crisis hits him in the middle of a firefight, or his symptoms will worsen and make it even more difficult to do anything effectively. The game's currency takes on the form of rough diamonds, which are received as payment for missions, but also can be found in briefcases scattered throughout the UAC. These diamonds can then be used to pay for new weapons, upgrades and other improvements such as increased ammo capacity.And speaking of weapons, the dusty, hostile climate of Africa does not bode well for their condition. Weapons will start degrading in quality almost as soon as they're fired, and begin gathering rust. If they're rusty enough they'll jam while being fired and the PC will need to unjam them in the middle of the fight, again adding to the tension of any confrontation. Ultimately, if the weapon is not replaced, it might just explode in your hands, rendering you defenseless until you switch to another weapon or pick one up off of a fallen foe. Weapon variety should also be mentioned, going from Desert Eagles to the M79 to a Japanese mortar, a rifle that fires darts and a few light machineguns, to say a few names.The AI of the enemies is more than decent and will surprise you more often than not. You will constantly be flanked as they shout orders to one another and will need to act fast, as cover will not be the be-all end-all of a fight. However, it does suffer from the occasional hiccup, but then again, which game doesn't? (Except FEAR.) Something should also be said about the vehicles on offer, most of them having been refitted with mounted weapons which can be used by switching to the respective seat. Vehicles do get damaged when shot, but the PC can repair them by simply opening up the hood and...twisting a bolt with a ratchet. Huh. Maybe he's just the second coming of Bob the Builder. The buddy system also gets an honourable mention. The PC can meet several other foreign mercenaries, like himself, along the game, and they can give him alternate objectives for some missions or even rescue him when he falls, but once they take too much damage they'll need rescuing themselves, and once they die, they're gone forever. Their personalities and backgrounds are also fairly varied and they'll even talk about and to each other.While all this may sound perfect, there are several somewhat obvious faults with the game. First and foremost, everyone always attacks you outside of the designated ceasefire zones. This is explained as the PC being sent on secret missions by both factions, so the militia in the field wouldn't know his purpose, so that can be somewhat glossed over, or modded out. However, that complaint doesn't mix well with the next, that enemies will respawn on every cleared guard post, even if you only walked some 100 meters away. This can get annoying really quickly as you'll have to blaze the entirety of the map sometimes (which isn't incredibly large, but is varied), wading right through several guard posts you'd previously cleared, only to have to stop at each of them and kill the new enemies so you don't risk getting shot in the back as you're leaving. Another chief complaint is the Hivemindedness of the AI and the fact that they can see through the thickest of foliages. This could be passable if the one enemy that spots you would have to shout out for his comrades first, but that doesn't happen. The moment you're seen, everyone in the location knows where you are, and WILL fire in your general direction, even if you're hiding in tall grass.To add to that complaint, the stealth system is wonky and usually doesn't work because of the last fact. There are a few options for stealth, which is even encouraged on the last difficulty setting, including the Machete you always wield. However, a full stealth playthrough is nigh impossible unless you hit 100% of your bullets, because the moment you miss and the bullet whizzes past that one guard's ear, he will turn straight at you and try to murder you, together with all six of his buddies.Finally, the game is fairly bug-free, except for several annoying bugs that halt mission progress and are a pain to get through.To finish up this needlessly long review, I would recommend Far Cry 2 if you're looking for a different experience to most other FPS games. It might not seem like it, but it is a breath of fresh, dry, hot air in the genre. Most of my complaints can most likely be fixed by way of mods as well, so, give it a try!

												Far Cry 2 has nothing in common with its predecessor other than the huge open world that characterised the first game, as well. In fact, the first episode was rather linear (practically, each level was a different island) whereas here you can go wherever you want. There are two maps with an enormous amount of territory to be covered. Just look at the pictures posted on the store page to see how beautiful and varied these areas are. As already stated, the game is beautiful. The jungles, the rain, the burning grass and trees (pyromaniacs will love it) once you obtain a flamethrower. It is just gorgeous! Too bad the story does not hold anything special in it. You complete missions for two competing factions that try to rule the area. If I'm mistaken this is all fictional and there's not even a mention as to which African country you are in.The game is very difficult. Even on a normal difficulty enemies you pass by in a vehicle can shoot you from a distance - I'm amazed how precise shots they have each time. If you go through a single outpost it is almost impossible to do that without being hit by the enemies. Another issue is how the enemies in these outposts throughout the game get respawned for no apparent reason. Mission destination points are usually deliberately placed to the farthest place on the map making sure you need to go through at least a couple of outposts along the way. This is bad as the game is prolonged due to some unnecessary, repetitive actions. Still, overall, this is a good game. It is entertaining and you can have some really funny moments during the combat with enemies. If you are not familiar with the franchise, however, I think the best is to choose the 3rd episode which is a more refined version of the Far Cry experience.

content:
3, 2014
												There are three kinds of enemies that can kill you in this game: malaria (doesn't really kill you, but will knock you out cold if a symptom attack catches you without the much needed pills), blood-thirsty mercenaries just like yourself (who duke it out supporting dubious causes for a hefty payment in blood diamonds), and the CoD-ey, impatient, quicktime-event-trained, short-attention-span mentality you WILL have when you first boot up Far Cry 2. All the past years, games in the likes of Call of Duty, Medal of Honor et al. have all created a FPS playerbase with a tremendously short focus of attention, a shocking lack of thinking and planning tactics, and a complete disregard of taking your mind off the shootybanging going on in the foreground, in order to soak in the atmosphere in the background. Far Cry 2 is, apart from a solid shooter, a magnificent atmospheric game, full of engrossing ambience and breathtaking vistas that will provide with a cheap vacation alternative to sub-Saharan Africa, albeit in a much more hostile environment than you would ever wish for. The nature that surrounds you can be both an ally and an enemy if you don't treat it properly, as a vantage point you used meticulously to pick off guards in a distant outpost can become a death trap at any moment, should a raging wildfire cut off any escape routes. Propagating bushfire mechanics can be harnessed to cause chaos and mayhem to enemy positions, but can also uncontrollably harm your character as well. Getting from point A to point B in this game can seem tedious at first, as you will have to walk or drive to wherever you need to be, but as you get more and more used to the feel of the adventure, you will discover alternate routes, shortcuts and safe zones to better facilitate your travelling needs.Don't expect fauna to be a threat, or to have any intelligence. Grazing herbivores are all you are ever going to see, and zebras tend to one-bump-one-kill themselves on your car, even if you are fully stopped. A full time-of-day cycle and dynamic weather effects will paint a much more convincing picture of your surroundings as you comb through the map length- and widthwise.TL;DR- An incredible experience worth the price of admission, it is a must that you should not overlook, especially since it goes dirt-cheap on sales more often than you would change underwear.

er 14, 2014
												Far Cry 2 throws the player into the wild African savannah where you have to fend for yourself. No one is there to hold your hand, and the world offers limitless opportunities. Problem is, you have caught malaria and you are in the middle of a civil war. As a mercenary, you offer your services to the various warlords as you drift ever closer into the dangerous conflict.If you enjoyed the first Far Cry, you will probably find Far Cry 2 quite enjoyable as well. While not related story-wise, the game offers a similar tone in gameplay. The game gives you the freedom to roam a massive world set in Africa. And there is no doubt in saying that the world is gorgeous, yet this is also where one of the most fundamental flaws lies. The world is sparsely populated; there are no massive cities, villages, or interesting locations to visit in the game. The world mainly consists of outposts with 100% goon density. This shallow attention to detail is what makes Far Cry 2 quite repetitive once you hit the 10 hour mark. An impressive addition to Far Cry 2 is the durability of weapons. Unlike most FPS games, the weapons in Far Cry 2 can jam or completely break in the middle of a fight. This makes pre-mission planning much more fun as it promotes the idea of checking the weapon state. Yet this “realism” that Far Cry 2 so heavily promotes can be a pain at times. Your character contracts malaria early in the game, and forces you to do boring side-missions to acquire 1-4 pills. Depending on how long you play, you may have to do quite a few of those malaria quests. It is also bothersome as symptoms may show up in the middle of a firefight.As for story, Far Cry 2 follows in the footsteps of the first Far Cry in that it doesn’t provide an interesting plot at all. The characters are poorly voiced and uninteresting, the plot never really develops, and you could care less what is happening around you. It becomes quite apparent after a few hours that the budget went straight into developing the world and not the story or its characters. At times, you may feel extremely lonely in this intimidating setting.Overall, if you like a sandbox playstyle with goons who will make life hell for you as you try to traverse the African terrains, then this game should be plenty of fun. Even if you don’t plan to play the main mission, go raid some outposts. I found it quite entertaining. Score: 7/10
