												Let me be as brutally honest as possible, as I'm only given two choices of "Yes" and "No" it's hard to pin point where I stand on this game. Pros: - Something to do with the story, I don't really care about story, too busy shooting things and exploring- Lots of things to do- Good gunplay- Good graphics for it's time, and even still good (to me) todayCons: (and boy, do i have a lot of these)- Respawning guard posts, I know Ubisofts main intention for the respawning guard posts was to make it so that you always had something to do, but when cars are oh so very easily damaged, it's a massive slow down when you can't actually just drive through a base without getting your car shot out by one or two guys- Enemy AI, Don't get me wrong, it's funny to hear them say "I saw atleast 3 guys" over and over, but when your trying to be sneaky, and enemies can see you through random bits of foiliage, but you can't see them, that's a tad bit unfair, a minor set back- The sheer mass of the game, the map is absolutely MASSIVE or maybe it just feels that way due to the fact that it takes ages to get anywhere, paired with the fact that stamina isn't unlimited, makes the exploration factor take a painful amount of time to do. Take this scenario, you don't know that there is one specific part that links the south part of the map with the north (as if the north part wasn't big enough) you take your buggy over to the north part, expecting to be able to get there, but alas, your character passes out and you can't. it respawns you without a vehicle, and you have to spend the next 15 minutes walking to find a randomly spawning enemy car. It has happened to me, it's probably happened to you, and if it hasn't, consider yourself VERY lucky.I could go on, and I may seem to be very heavy on the cons, and not so heavy on the pros, but believe me when I say this, this game has it's moments, it's quite fun, i enjoy it, if it weren't for the MASSIVE amount of driving that you had to do, and respawning guard outposts, this would be the perfect game, and I think i speak for a lot of people, because far cry 3? content:
y 20, 2014
												The definitive African civil war mercenary simulator. Equal parts brilliant and flawed, the game is wrought with frustrating game design but is thoroughly soaked in its sweaty, mosquito-infested atmosphere. Be sure to mod the game first to reduce some of the frustrations the game throws at you, Dylan's Far Cry 2 mod is good. Since most won't like the game, I'll discuss the good points first.Far Cry 2 drops your mercenary hide into an ongoing civil war between 2 factions in a war-torn African country, your objective is to hunt "the Jackal", the infamous arms dealer that arms both sides and thus, is fueling the war. The thing about the story is that it's actually not bad. The plot is heavily inspired by Joseph Conrad's Heart of Darkness, the resulting focus on barbarism and morality is clearly evident. The game has an interesting approach to realism, the attention to detail is amazing. Your gun can jam in the middle of a firefight, performing the clearing drill around enemies creates a new level of tension. Fire is caused by anything flammable, molotovs, propane tanks, exploding cars, etc. And it propagates beautifully, better than in Far Cry 3 even. Your minimap is made of paper and you physically pull it out whenever you want to check it, it baffles me why no other game does this to improve immersion. Heck, even the plants bend when you step or drive over them, you can shoot the branches off trees too. A grenade will send pieces of a shed and the surrounding shrub flying, revealing the skeletal famework and anybody inside that is still alive. The AI is not perfect, they sometimes take turns to be impressively stupid and annoyingly sharp. But once combat starts, they yell updates at each other to coordinate flanks and comb the jungle for you when you are in hiding. At first, you will flounder around the map, attracting the attention of every enemy you meet, a frustrating and demoralizing experience. Slowly, you understand the quirks of the stealth system, you unlock guns which compliment your playstyle, you discover the value of always moving in a firefight. You grow fearless and become feared. You learn how to shoot to wound instead of kill, so that you may silently watch their comrades run out of cover to rescue their buddy and take them both out. As your reputation grows, soldiers in the cease fire areas no longer arrogantly push you away when you run up to them, instead, they mutter fearful apologies and back off. Sometimes, in combat, they will panic and scream about how they just want to go home. As your character uses his machete to execute the wounded soldier on the ground, you realise that the game's mechanics have turned you into the monster you were supposed to kill.Alongside that, an ingenious game mechanic is the buddy system. The game randomly assigns you buddies from a lengthy roster. Most of the time, you will be helping them run errands or get taken along by one of their crazy ideas to complicate the central mission. However, imagine this scenario: you attempt a raid and something goes wrong, a PMC flanked you from the tall grass to your right and you go down in bursts of shotgun fire. Your grow frustrated at the idea of restarting the attack, but then Josip, your hilarious, middle-aged Algerian buddy appears onscreen. He drags you to safety as you recall the time he got you to kill a car dealer for him because "Turns out car is piece of ♥♥♥♥ - so *he* is piece of ♥♥♥♥" and then awkwardly uses the word "cool" with a thumbs up and cheesy grin. You dig out the bullet from your forearm, the two of you re-enter the fray. However, assault truck pulls up. it's full of enemies and the machinegun on the vehicle sprays at both of you. You dive for cover and take it out with a grenade, only to see your buddy squirming on the ground. You move over to him and give him a morphine jab, expecting him to spring back to life just like before. But this time, he gurgles for more. With realization dawning, you give him another jab, his reply is the same. Now you have no more morphine and a dying buddy in pain. The game prompts you to unholster your pistol and you place it in his mouth. He even thanked you before you pulled the trigger. This is the way you get players to care.Unfortunately, those things only happen when the stars are aligned and the game plays as intended. The unfortunate reality is that in order for your emergent interactions with the militia to occur, the game throws them at you around every corner. This makes traversing the 50 square kilometers of the open world a serious hassle even when you master the art of finding paths of least resistance and take the bus whenever possible. Although it is highly satisfying to sneaking through a village to silence a high value target, it is just as likely that while sneaking through the town, the PMC on the platform at the other end of the town spots you with predator vision and blasts you with his RPG. Usually, stealth plans are thwarted midway because one missed shot from any silenced weapon alerts the whole camp to your position and they will almost instantly fire upon you from wherever they are. Using the machete is also, strangely, not a silenced kill. Making it useless expect in finishing off wounded enemies. I suppose Far Cry 3's magical teleporting knife instakills are an upgrade. The map design also causes fits whenever you encounter a steep cliff that blocks your safe shortcut to the objective. It makes you wish for helicopter travel or at least the ability to climb.Another unfortunate thing is the mission variety, although you are free to tackle them they are confined to 3 types. Assassination/intimidation missions where you either kill or force people to do things and maybe kill them afterwards. Sabotage/retrieval missions where you destroy or steal objects which are in a village filled with PMCs. Last is the convoy ambush, which is exactly what it sounds like. The last type usually only applies to the arms vendor missions which you complete to unlock the possibility of buying new weapons. So for most of the game you will be contending with the first 2. There are only so many ways to skin a cat and nearing the end, missions have the same draggy expectation as a fetch quest. When combined with the frustratingly long and tedious travel, you can see why this game was a major disappointment for many.The frustrations are slightly reduced with modding, Dylan's mod makes weapons much deadlier, increases the ammunition count, improves the effectiveness of your camouflaged suit, reduces the frequency of malaria attacks and jams as well as the chances of being chased when running through a checkpoint along with many other tweaks. As a result, you are more vulnerable and your gameplay will have even more tension. It's a good thing you have an extra life thanks to your buddy. I would advise to play it modded on the highest difficulty even on your first try because all is fair when you can usually down enemies with one round from any gun. Try to avoid conflict as much as possible and save very often, because you may die from ridiculous circumstances. That's all I have to say.

content:
25, 2014
												I played this game when it came out and I must say that although I was very impressed with the game at first, it soon became boring and repetitive.The mission structure is very similar-basically go and blow something up or free somebody etc.Characters are shallow and not interesting.The world seems kind of empty with nothing much to do than destroying camps and dealing with very annoying armored jeeps that follow you when you pass by.Now 5 years later I bought a new powerful graphic card,found some great mods and decided to give it another go.I must say that I'm very pleased with the game.What this game gives you is very unique experience and that is enough to cover all it's flaws.This game made me realise what I've long forgotten.It's that not everything has to be action packed,flashy story,indepth customization of everything,points,cover system....It's just simple and beautiful.It makes you appreciate the time spent just roaming the wilderness with nothing on your screen to destract you from beautiful world around you.Total immersion.We need to stop with consuming games like an always hungry fat kid and appreciate the atmosphere and experience.You will often feel alone and kind of lost in this great world,which coupled with an amazing weather system,beautiful graphics and fitting background music makes the experience very unique.Sometimes it feels like a dream to me.Like you never really know what is going on but you just exist,just to watch that beautiful sunset.It gives you time for thinking between action parts.And action is great and the whole weapon system is designed very well.From buying,upgrading to the shooting mechanics and wearing out including great jamming system and animations.The arsenal is also pretty big with plenty to choose from.The other thing that shines is AI.Although they can act like idiots at times mostly they are smart and they will very often surprise you and flank you.They will also detect you quickly even if you just peak out behind cover to take a quick look.Just like IRL,they are not blind like in other games (Hitman:Absolution for eg) and there is no "detection meter".If they see you, they see you.Your best bet for sneaking is to attack by night wearing stealth suit and even then it will not be easy,because if you are too close they will hear louder sounds such as bumping in objects or reloading etc. and come to investigate.GREAT STEALTH GAME right there.Using quick save and quick load is much recommended.As I don't want to write a book here I will conclude and tell you to try it if you are looking for a trully open world game with a great action,juicy explosions and shooting,GREAT STEALTH possibilities and an amazing atmosphere.You will love Africa after this,or hate it.Whatever.What you will not find is many RPG elements and a great story.But lack of those gives the game its charm and keeps the focus on other things.WHAT I HIGHLY RECOMMEND is getting this mods from moddb:sproyds_FC2_SweetFX_config and VERY important DylansFC2Mod1.4 as it will basically fix the game.Just check it out even if you don't like mods(like me)Play on highest difficulty and enjoy!

content:
2, 2014
 Far Cry 2: Buy it! 
I am less than 10 h/ into the game, but I can say that it is worth however much money you get it for. The AI for the enemy's can be a little shaky, but for the most part you can actually use their purposly implemented features to your advantage. Scenerio example: 

You spot an enemy in the distance, in a base camp. Your mission objective is far away, yet you can't resist the urge to make your own fun in this barren wastland. You get a little closer, while still remaining in the bushes and shrubs, and you finaly get close enough to where you think you can make an accurate shot. You crouch down, take aim and fire at their shoulder. You hit, and the rest of the enemies remain clueless as to who fired the shot. They rush over to the wounded souldier, and as they get there you make a dash to get with close range, and take out 3 enemy's with your shotgun remaining unharmed and get behind cover before any other enemy's can get a shot off on you. 3 down, 2 more to get an easy advantage on using the same method with a little more run and gun.

The enemy's "caring" features as I would like to call them the feature I made a scenario about above. If you wound a souldier, or put one into a dangerous situation, if all goes well another souldier will move into the same general area, or go to the wounded souldier and help. This is a very cool feature that I like using, but you need to make sure that you are for enough away.

The different characters that you can play as all have a different initial spawning spot, which also means that your "boss" at the beggining has different traits (and of course different voice actors) which spices up the beggining of your game differently, which adds to replayability. Of course, I haven't played very far into the game on different characters so I can't confirm that the story/npc's that you meet later are different, but at least during the begining you can choose different characters to play as which gives different startings to the game. 

 Permadeath. Do it. Seriously. Permadeath is where if you die in game, you can't respawn. Well of course you still can, but if you are following the rules then you delete your save/all other saves corosponding with that character you are playing with. 

This game has a unique  buddy system , which can be fatal, and helpful. The more buddy's you have, the "safer" you will be. Your buddy's can save your A☻s, but sometimes can give you false hope, like if you only have one syrrette (morphine) left and you are at low health and your buddy is down, you can save them in the hopes that if you "die" that your buddy will rescue you, but your buddy is just as open to dangers as you are, and can die also. 

Syrrettes are morphine shots that restore your health to full, but you can only use them if you did the non syrrette heal, which is to hit the same key (H) and it will make your character do one of the dozens of healing animations, like biting a bullet out of your arm, using plyers to get a bullet out of your leg, pulling a peice of metal from your thigh, putting your arm back into it's socket, etc. which makes the game feel VERY realistic in the damage sence. Syrrettes are easily obtainable at safe houses, your "boss's" "house", enemy camps etc. but if you are constantly in the feild enjoying the open world aspect of the game, then you might run into trouble, esspecially if you are playing permadeath.

Some notes:

-If you steal an enemy car from a camp and another enemy sees you, they will engage.
-ALWAYS use a vehicle that has a mounted turret. It's as easy as hitting "C" to switch to the turret and within second you have a weapon that can be way more powerfull than your weapons that you carry.
-Make your own fun! Don't forget, this is an open world game. You can run around having fun and engaging in casual shennanigans alongside actually completing the game.

Anyways, you guys should 100% buy this game! It's worth it if you like unforgiving enemies, multiple ways of completing missions, having open world possibilities, and playing through older games (it was made in 2008). Enjoy!

												This game is a hidden treasure that all players must have in their collection. There is so much realism, so much detail, and so many more features than Far Cry. It's unbelievable how amazing this game is, and also how underplayed it is. I've heard people say that it differs too much from it's predecessor to be an official sequel. Although it's made on a different engine and has a surplus of extras not featured in Far Cry, the basic elements are still the same: shoot mercs in a sandbox world set in an exotic locale.If you never played Far Cry 1 and if you were to ask me I would say skip it entirely and get Far Cry 2. It's crazy how much detail is here: driveable vehicles, mounted guns, fixable cars, unlockable safe houses, weapon upgrades, uncontrollable wild fires, exciting action, riveting music, helpful allies, challenging AI, beautiful scenery, and to top it all off you have a bad case of malaria!

er 24, 2013
												Worth playing for the first 10 hours or so, it's really great fun during that initial period.The gunplay is great and the touches of realism are well executed for the most part, which combined with the well designed gameworld, all leads to a very nice sense of immersion.Unfortunately after a while the game becomes extremely repetitive with pretty much only three types of missions, two of them being identical each time around (the gunshop and assassination ones), whereas the main story missions are also all very similar.Some questionable design choices also really get in the way of allowing you to have fun, making the need to travel around during missions an absolute exercise in frustration and tedium. The way everyone will shoot you on sight no matter what gets really ridiculous eventually, since you don't even need to be aggressive towards someone randomly driving around in order for them to start relentlessly giving you chase as if their life depended on it.The way enemies respawn instantly after the area where you fought them is out of your line of sight (why not make them respawn until a full day has passed by?) practially makes clearing up the camps pointless. The few fast travel locations don't really help much in avoiding excessive driving around. Had there been more fast travel locations and the uber aggressive enemies were toned down a bit (or if they at least didn't respawn so quickly), I would've been more willing to put up with the repetitive missions, since repetitve as they were, they were still fun to play.I can't say much about the story itself since I didn't see it through to the end, but it was serviceable at best during my time playing. Not sure if it gets more interesting eventually, but if it does it sure takes a while to get going.Ultimately I decided to call it quits on the main story and side missions and decided to just muck around freely. It was a more liberating and fun experience, though the fun didn't last long since due to story reasons (the main character has malaria) you can't go around without checking your health periodically, which requires doing more repetitive missions and I couldn't be bothered with that anymore.Nevertheless, as I said at first, for the first 10 hours or so the game is awesome and I don't regret buying it. If you have more patience to deal with repetitive gameplay and can tolerate some of the more annoying design quriks, you'll certainly have fun with this game.

ry 13, 2011
												Story? Nah. Beautiful graphics? Eh. Repetitive? Yeah.Awesome gameplay? Hard as nails difficulty? Yesss. This game is awesome fun. A little hard to get into, pretty slow to start, but once you gather a few upgrades, you're set. In Far Cry 2, you are not a badass murder machine who roams the lands with impunity. You are a malaria infected loner who prefers to wage gun battles with rusty pistols which explode on short notice while popping pills like candy when the fever strikes.If taken at face value, the game would be fairly boring. A large varied world with not a lot in it, lots of bad guys to shoot, a few collectibles. What it is, though, is an extremely immersive battle simulator. The AI is great, the gunplay is quite fun, the weapon jams add depth and unpredictability, and the amount of ways you can enter an encampment and ruin the mercenaries' day are many.When someone watched over my shoulder as I played, he said it was like watching an action movie. It's like that. It's tense, precise, and satisfying, and at higher difficulties, brutally decisive. You won't play it for the story. The characters are two-dimensional, all of them inhabit little huts where they spout exposition and then send you on another kill all the peoples mission. You almost make your own story in the playing of this game. With no HUD and a sprawling savannah, Far Cry 2 will suck you in if you let it.It's a dangerous world. Bring your machete.

content:
er 27, 2016
												Far Cry 2 is set in a large, beautifully crafted rendition of the African wilderness.  It includes very satisfying gunplay and it allows the tactical use of fire in skirmishes - set the savannah ablaze or lob a molotov cocktail to flush your enemy out of cover with realistically modelled fire propagation!  The fire and explosion mechanics are great and the weapons have a good feel to them.  Enemy AI is generally pretty good - they will search for you and respond to stimuli in a realistic manner.  Annoyingly (because it is so obviously incongruous that it breaks immersion), the distinctive black and white character voices often seem to be assigned to minor NPCs of the opposite race.  The wheeled vehicles don't handle anywhere nearly as well as the weapons, but thanks to the beautiful world design, exploring the wilds by track or river is still enjoyable, at least at first.  As the game goes on, the driving becomes a bit of a chore (realism sucks sometimes).  I found travelling by boat to be more immersive and enjoyable - they certainly seemed to handle more realistically than the wheeled vehicles.You play as a mercenary tasked with killing an unscrupulous arms dealer that is supplying both sides of a civil conflict with cheap weapons.  Given your role and mission, you take a fairly detached approach to the civil conflict.  For most of the game, the story was of some interest, but I did not find it particularly gripping.  At times, it felt like little more than an excuse for various assassination and destruction missions, although they were thrilling enough to keep me motivated to do all the requisite driving.  Approaching the end of the game, however, the story became substantially more interesting to me, as a new perspective on the conflict was revealed.There is quite a wide variety of weapons available, although I found myself using only a couple of favourites most of the time.  The world is massive and lovingly detailed.  With multiple African biomes, dynamic weather and wind that affects both vegetation and fire behaviour, it really is a wonderful place to explore.  The excellent gunplay is icing on the cake.By far the most realistic of the Far Cry series, with destructible environment and weapon degradation (including jamming), I found Far Cry 2 to be a challenging and enjoyable game.  The spawning of enemies at checkpoints was annoying at times and I would have liked an option for even more realistic damage levels (people don't often patch themselves up and fight on after being shot with an AK-47).  Although playing this way would have been a very difficult proposition, I think that it would have driven the use of different, more realistic tactics.  With such solid fundamentals, Far Cry 2 had potential to eclipse S.T.A.L.K.E.R. - Shadow of Chernobyl as my favourite First-Person Shooter game ever made, had it been more mod-friendly.  Sadly, Ubisoft had other ideas.  Nevertheless, even as it approaches a decade after release, Far Cry 2 remains a great open world FPS.  I strongly recommend trying it f you like open world games and planning your gunplay engagements from stealth.  The world is gorgeous, the gunplay satisfying, and I think it's worth playing just for the realistic fire and destruction effects.

content:
er 28, 2016
												$3.39 is a steal! Buy it now...or read my short review and then buy it.Note: My experience was altered using the Far Cry GES(Graphical Enhancement Suite) and Dylan's Realism Mod, I INSIST that you download these as they turn the game into what it was meant to be. If you decide to play with the Dylan's mod, play on Infamous diffuculty...trust me.Graphics:Stunning when using the GES, as it allows you to alter the saturation, contrast, and brightness (the game can be quite dark in the jungle). The jungles are vibrant, the deserts are scathing, and my goodness are the sunsets gorgeous. The weapon models are fantastic and the animations that go with them are even better, particularly the jamming ones. My only problem would be the environmental textures aren't great. Gameplay:This is a hardcore mercenary sim, whether it's CQC with shotguns and assault rifles,  wiping out a base from a safe distance with a sniper, or torching the whole base with a flame thrower, the heat of battle is intense and visceral. The guns handle great and the recoil is really nice, especially on the silenced makarov. Another great system is how fire works, when it's windy you could chuck a single molotov and the fire would spread to engulf the base in flame. One mixed bag in the game is stealth. Sometimes it works amazingly, other times not so much. For example: on a mission where I had to sneak into an old greenhouse and destroy an old pump, I took out a sniper on the outskirts of the base and then proceeded without taking any other enemies out. I snuck in and placed an IED on the pump and snuck out. It was glorious. On the other hand there are times where you are sneaking up and a sniper who is not even looking at you will all the sudden turn around, tell the other enemies where you are, and open fire. So stealth is definitely hit or miss. The AI can be weird at times too. Another system that is FANTASTIC is the buddy system, Quaribani, you will always be remembered as my first buddy. You really build a reputation with theses guys, and then all the sudden they can ripped away from you, you try desperately to save them as they are wounded, but you know it won't work and you have to do it, pull the trigger. You have various types of missions to choose from, the main story ones, buddy missions (different from the buddy objective in the main missions), assassination missions, and weapons dealer missions which unlock new guns.The main missions and the buddy missions take a little while, while the other two tend to be quicker. So overall the gameplay is really good, some of my favorite FPS gameplay for sure.Story:The story sets up like this: You're a mercenary who is hired to take out an arms dealer named the Jackal. He has supplied arms to two different factions in a civil war. You do work for these factions and in turn they give you information on the Jackal. The games faction missions can be very interesting if you do some of the Buddy objectives which make the missions longer, but they can also be VERY repetitive. If you're used to open world games this won't be a problem. Besides that problem, when the story picks up, it REALLY picks up. And depending on which ending you choose (yes, this is one of those games) it has a great ending(one word: briefcase).Sound:In short: weapons and sound good, voice acting is on fast forward, and everything else is hit or miss.Replayability:This is my one major problem in the game. There is no post story mode playability, you could load up an old save but I have so many it takes awhile to load. Your only other option is to start a new game. I don't understand why there isn't a feature like in the new Tomb Raider where at the end it tells you are now free to explore the island and do side objectives.Final Score:8.5/10. Buy it when it's on sale if you're unsure, but if it sounds like your type of game, go for it regardless of price.

												This is my most favourite game so far. Recommended ( but keep reading befor making decision ) if you love open world stealth, good challenge, first person shooting and do not mind backtracking through hostiles and breathtaking vistas.The game has shortcomings. It must be played in a specific way to be enjoyable (which is true for most games anyway). I usually do not like limitations in gameplay that force you to play in some specific style, but in this case the style was exactly my style, so the shortcomings worked for me.The gameplay is....different. If that is not your thing, you will hate the game. Lets see. Enemies in the world are bullet sponges and respawn as soon as the area is reloaded in RAM. So there is no value in engaging them before you reach objective. Hardest difficulty will force you to find alternate routes and practice stealth movement and long range combat to thin out enemies around the objective. CQB stealth is broken but shooting is not. You can definitely run and gun if you have godly reflex and aim.Yes, guns are worth discussing. The loadout is too complex in this game. Ammo is not abundant. There is no good medium range gun (something that was fixed in FC3). I used to switch between Dragunov and MAC 10 for everything. The condition of silenced guns is even worse. The dart gun has very limited ammo and it is long range. The DLC silenced shotgun is very short range and will leave you vulnerable in open fields. The silenced MP5 is trash. The weapon slots are restricted, so you cannot carry the shotgun alongside a medium range weapon. You can carry the dart gun alongside a real sniper gun though, but that will disallow you from carrying rocket laucher or IED. That is no big loss outside specific missions, becaus there is no good rocket launcher. RPG is too inaccurate, but still better than others, the GL and MGL take slots of secondary and primary, so not worth carrying outside certain missions, the Carl G puts your ♥♥♥ on fire, and the viewfinder of the explosive bolts reflects sunlight so you must find proper angle which is not always possible.That leaves you very vulnerable in case your stealth fails and a vehicle with mounted guns attacks you. MAC 10 helps, but not against GMG mounted vehicles. I enjoyed the suspense, you might not. I spent more time staring at the map (I got a PDF from web and printed it) and in stealth travel than running and gunning.Has high replay value. I was not a completionist, so did not go collectible hunting, amd more than 40% of the areas were new to me during second play where I found new ways to approach missions.In my opinion Africa is the most beautiful location in the World, yet it is never explored in videogames. This game might have outdated graphics, but the quality of ambiance can only be compared to legends like HL, Morrowind, Minecraft etc. There is one fault in graphics though, it is graphically too demanding compared to its graphics quality. It does not run smoothly even in rigs that are just enough to handle Crisis unmodded.

												I honestly consider this game to be the following:One of Ubisoft's crowning titles before they went sour.One of the greatest games (I have ever played) of all time.Why? 												Fun but flawed best explains this one.For the fun:• Gunplay is very fun and satisfying. Plenty of variety in weapons.• One of the most immersive (hate that word) games I have ever played. • A big beautiful maps.• Good voice acting and dialog. Doesn't come off as stilted or awkward.• Fire spreading mechanics were fun to play with.• Runs great. I had it completely maxxed out on my computer which is getting on in age.For the flaws:• Some not well thought out game mechanics, namely malaria and checkpoints.• Severely lacking a fast travel system. In my 33 hours of playing the majority of it was from driving place to place. (At least it was immersive..)• Missions could of done with some better varying.• Some weapons were not balanced well. (Was fixable with mods.)• Animals are completely pointless. Come on, when I think Africa, I think death by animals.• Checkpoints with quickly respawning enemies.Some really hate the malaria mechanic, which while annoying, was never game breaking or frequent enough to annoy me. (Also can be delayed with mods) All you have to do is a very quick delivery side mission for more pills. Saddly it never gets cured durng the game. Some also seem to really REALLY hate weapons degrading and jamming. I was never bothered by it and helped create some tense moments. I was frequently swaping my weapons with my bought ones since they last longer. I ended up barely dealing with jamming as a whole. (This also can be tweaked with mods.) The last big flaw to most and one that bugged me was the road checkpoints. Basically a small camp of enemies, usually at intersections. Since you have to drive everywhere and the checkpoints respawn basically after you leave, you end up being shot at a little to often. Plus they will follow you in jeeps with mounted guns, or worse, mounted grenade launchers.Saddly the animals could not be tweaked with mods.. they serve no purpose other than run around... and do nothing. They die to 1 hit by everything. A gazelle/impala thing WALKED into my PARKED ATV and just fell over dead. So at least they were amusingly pointless.The graphics were very nice, even though they were VERY brown. It fit with the game, but I still wish I was able to adjust the saturation to my own liking. The game also never breaks the First Person view ever, which was nice. Even using your map doesn't break you out of the game. Helped keep up the .. *sighs*.. immersion.All of these issues seem to have been fixed in Far Cry 3, from what I can tell from videos. I look forward to getting Far Cry 3 once it has it "Game of The Year" or "Complete" version out with all its DLC. If you want a fun but flawed game, you could do worse than Far Cry 2. I only paid $2.50 and feel it was well worth it. But if you want a less flawed game, go with Far Cry 3.

What I mean is there is no over-the-top drama queen playing puppet master over an already lucid reality. It also makes the game more interesting because you really do reach a state of panic at times looking for your medication. content:
11
												Let me start off this review by stating that the only other far cry game I have played, is Far Cry 3. Which is one I have obtained and played for the first time recently along with this installment in the Far Cry series. Now onto the review.   Far Cry 2 is a open world FPS set in an undisclosed country in Africa in between two factions vying for power after the government has collapsed. You choose from a selection of characters in the start menu when starting a new game and then dive into the world of Far Cry 2.   You may see other reviews giving this game a not recommended for having buggy AI, or annoying grievances such as respawn times for guard outposts. But I can assure you that if you look past those, and actually prefer a game be too hard than too easy, then you will more than likely enjoy this game. Many people also claim that the functions of having malaria strikes, (your vision basically turning green and a ringing in your ears as you desperatly mash the heal button hoping you have a medicine left.) difficult tough to kill enemies, and weapon degradation are what brings this game down. But to that, I can say that if you like a game that doesn't hold your hand and makes you think on your feet while not being ridiculous in its punishments, then you will probably enjoy those elements. More than once I found myself panicking and running for any piece of cover you can while enemies take pot shots at you from a meter or more away. Enemies do not take it easy on you. Unlike Far Cry 3, where enemies can lose sight of you and give up relatively quickly, in this game, the enemies will pursue with an intent to hang you above their fireplace. They are brutal, and don't take very long to notice you.   There are reviews I have seen where people say the stealth is non existant, and the enemies sight distance is "unrealistic" but I say that they are wrong, and have simply not managed to find the right way to stealth in this game. The enemies and stealth system work on a sort of "If I can't see them, they can't see me." Meaning that if your definition of stealth is hiding in a single bush and peeking halfway out behind cover, aiming your gun right at the guy, then yes, the stealth is non existant. Same goes for sound. If an enemy is down the road, and you open fire with a .50 Cal mounted machine gun, they WILL come for you.  This game is also very immersive. Turn off the crosshair, and you are left with an FPS experience like no other. There is no mini map like in the other Far Cry's save for the first. You have your own map that you have to physically pull out to see where your objective is. And no, it doesn't half ♥♥♥ it and show a big red dot in game when you get "close" to the objective. You have to use all of your senses to navigate, and you will die. A lot. This game also does not have the same sort of regenerative health that Far cry 3 has. And doesn't have the same healing system either. I found in Far Cry 3 that the syringes were useless halfway through the game because the animations for healing were enough to bring me back to full health. In this game, you HAVE to find medkits. You only stabilize your health when you are at one bar of health. And it can either be, (depending on the injury), a  lenghty, cringe inducing animation as you finger your bullet hole, or a quick one, where you rip out a glass shard from your hand. And depending on who you are, you may find this absolutely ridiculous and infuriating, or immersive, and an amazing addition to a game that already challenges you to your limits in terms of FPS.  All in all, I believe that Far Cry 2 is a great game for people wanting an extreme challenge when it comes to FPS games. And tired of feeling like a super hardcore robot killing machine that people fear. Because in this game, you feel outmanned, outgunned, and outlived many times.  So with all that said, Far Cry 2 gets the Blue Thumb of Approval. Highly, highly recommend if you can forget everything you know about other Far Crys', and look past some occasional bugs.

												This rivals STALKER as my favorite game of all time. As far as immersion goes, FC2 is unsurpassed. The game feels exactly like my real life experience in overthrowing an unstable African nation. It's hard, especially on the higher difficulty levels. YOu have to think about how to approach each mission, which works well because you have a variety of options. While most of the missions can feel repetitive after a while, it's fine because the actual combat is intense. You can never let yourself be distracted or opting for the mindless approach, as each (infuriatingly respawning) checkpoint can kill you, no matter how many similar checkpoints you've cleared. Even the respawning checkpoints work out to a greater point, nothing you do is improving the country, no matter how many nameless enemies you kill. It's not perfect, as I mentioned many of the missions are repetitive, but the gameplay feels as intense and dark as the narrative, and every aspect of the game seems to blend together into a cohesive whole. Gunplay is absolutely amazing, with each shot deadly for both you and the enemy. Flare guns in particular deserve a special mention, as the fire physics are devastating in this game. Apparently during early stages of testing, the fires would rage out of control, spreading across the entire map and killing every single character. The developers restricted fire to spread to a perfect circle, but to be completely honest I never noticed that as I usually used fire as a temporary distraction to flush enemies out of cover or to cover my escape. It can be frustrating to escape enemies in vehicles, as they'll chase you to hell and beyond, but now I'm just nitpicking. Nothing in the game breaks the immersion or flow, the map is an item you can pull out and look at while driving, and the entirety of the game reinforces the brutality of the setting and the fact that you're not a golden hero, magically fixing everything for the natives. Even the ending goes for the same, I won't spoil it but suffice to say, The Jackal (FC2's antagonist) is probably my favorite character in video game history.

												In response to the success of far cry 3, I feel it's time I look back and take a more in-depth review of far cry 2. Upon first look, it's a game with a terrible story and many infuriating game mechanics. More specifically, players hate the permanent dependance on malaria medication, the accelerated weapon degradation, the re-populating enemy strongholds and checkpoints, and the unusual fast-travel system. If you find yourself miserable due to all these problems, I understand if you want to un-install. However...I find a dusty, bloody, and primal charm from the whole game experience. Every issue I listed above is actually a reason as to why I love this game! And for me, it all comes down to immersion in the game's world. For example, the story doesn't grab you like it does in so many GOTYs. Instead of creating some elaborate story for the player to get distracted by, players are sent on small missions that allow them to play the game their own way. Weapon degradation forces you to use foresight and planning to ensure you are at your prime. Malaria also keeps you focused on living day-to-day, and prevents you from being the uber-warrior that so many games make you into. Never-ending enemy spawning keeps you on your toes. The fast-travel-by-bus system allows you to make short leaps around the map, but only in certain areas, forcing you to plan your routes effectively.Overall, far cry 2 is unapologetically rough. Underneath the seemingly frustrating game features lies highly immersive gameplay. The beautiful and lifelike ambient sounds and stunning visuals are just icing on the bloody, bloody cake.P.S.: I originally wanted to call FC2 realistic, but I now see it as engrossing, which is much more fun. If you can buy this game at $2.50 on a sale, please give this game a try.

												Fun but flawed best explains this one.For the fun:• Gunplay is very fun and satisfying. Plenty of variety in weapons.• One of the most immersive (hate that word) games I have ever played. • A big beautiful maps.• Good voice acting and dialog. Doesn't come off as stilted or awkward.• Fire spreading mechanics were fun to play with.• Runs great. I had it completely maxxed out on my computer which is getting on in age.For the flaws:• Some not well thought out game mechanics, namely malaria and checkpoints.• Severely lacking a fast travel system. In my 33 hours of playing the majority of it was from driving place to place. (At least it was immersive..)• Missions could of done with some better varying.• Some weapons were not balanced well. (Was fixable with mods.)• Animals are completely pointless. Come on, when I think Africa, I think death by animals.• Checkpoints with quickly respawning enemies.Some really hate the malaria mechanic, which while annoying, was never game breaking or frequent enough to annoy me. (Also can be delayed with mods) All you have to do is a very quick delivery side mission for more pills. Saddly it never gets cured durng the game. Some also seem to really REALLY hate weapons degrading and jamming. I was never bothered by it and helped create some tense moments. I was frequently swaping my weapons with my bought ones since they last longer. I ended up barely dealing with jamming as a whole. (This also can be tweaked with mods.) The last big flaw to most and one that bugged me was the road checkpoints. Basically a small camp of enemies, usually at intersections. Since you have to drive everywhere and the checkpoints respawn basically after you leave, you end up being shot at a little to often. Plus they will follow you in jeeps with mounted guns, or worse, mounted grenade launchers.Saddly the animals could not be tweaked with mods.. they serve no purpose other than run around... and do nothing. They die to 1 hit by everything. A gazelle/impala thing WALKED into my PARKED ATV and just fell over dead. So at least they were amusingly pointless.The graphics were very nice, even though they were VERY brown. It fit with the game, but I still wish I was able to adjust the saturation to my own liking. The game also never breaks the First Person view ever, which was nice. Even using your map doesn't break you out of the game. Helped keep up the .. *sighs*.. immersion.All of these issues seem to have been fixed in Far Cry 3, from what I can tell from videos. I look forward to getting Far Cry 3 once it has it "Game of The Year" or "Complete" version out with all its DLC. If you want a fun but flawed game, you could do worse than Far Cry 2. I only paid $2.50 and feel it was well worth it. But if you want a less flawed game, go with Far Cry 3.

content:
11
												Let me start off this review by stating that the only other far cry game I have played, is Far Cry 3. Which is one I have obtained and played for the first time recently along with this installment in the Far Cry series. Now onto the review.   Far Cry 2 is a open world FPS set in an undisclosed country in Africa in between two factions vying for power after the government has collapsed. You choose from a selection of characters in the start menu when starting a new game and then dive into the world of Far Cry 2.   You may see other reviews giving this game a not recommended for having buggy AI, or annoying grievances such as respawn times for guard outposts. But I can assure you that if you look past those, and actually prefer a game be too hard than too easy, then you will more than likely enjoy this game. Many people also claim that the functions of having malaria strikes, (your vision basically turning green and a ringing in your ears as you desperatly mash the heal button hoping you have a medicine left.) difficult tough to kill enemies, and weapon degradation are what brings this game down. But to that, I can say that if you like a game that doesn't hold your hand and makes you think on your feet while not being ridiculous in its punishments, then you will probably enjoy those elements. More than once I found myself panicking and running for any piece of cover you can while enemies take pot shots at you from a meter or more away. Enemies do not take it easy on you. Unlike Far Cry 3, where enemies can lose sight of you and give up relatively quickly, in this game, the enemies will pursue with an intent to hang you above their fireplace. They are brutal, and don't take very long to notice you.   There are reviews I have seen where people say the stealth is non existant, and the enemies sight distance is "unrealistic" but I say that they are wrong, and have simply not managed to find the right way to stealth in this game. The enemies and stealth system work on a sort of "If I can't see them, they can't see me." Meaning that if your definition of stealth is hiding in a single bush and peeking halfway out behind cover, aiming your gun right at the guy, then yes, the stealth is non existant. Same goes for sound. If an enemy is down the road, and you open fire with a .50 Cal mounted machine gun, they WILL come for you.  This game is also very immersive. Turn off the crosshair, and you are left with an FPS experience like no other. There is no mini map like in the other Far Cry's save for the first. You have your own map that you have to physically pull out to see where your objective is. And no, it doesn't half ♥♥♥ it and show a big red dot in game when you get "close" to the objective. You have to use all of your senses to navigate, and you will die. A lot. This game also does not have the same sort of regenerative health that Far cry 3 has. And doesn't have the same healing system either. I found in Far Cry 3 that the syringes were useless halfway through the game because the animations for healing were enough to bring me back to full health. In this game, you HAVE to find medkits. You only stabilize your health when you are at one bar of health. And it can either be, (depending on the injury), a  lenghty, cringe inducing animation as you finger your bullet hole, or a quick one, where you rip out a glass shard from your hand. And depending on who you are, you may find this absolutely ridiculous and infuriating, or immersive, and an amazing addition to a game that already challenges you to your limits in terms of FPS.  All in all, I believe that Far Cry 2 is a great game for people wanting an extreme challenge when it comes to FPS games. And tired of feeling like a super hardcore robot killing machine that people fear. Because in this game, you feel outmanned, outgunned, and outlived many times.  So with all that said, Far Cry 2 gets the Blue Thumb of Approval. Highly, highly recommend if you can forget everything you know about other Far Crys', and look past some occasional bugs.

It is meant to be a story, a captivating story where you think you are hunting evil and you think you are helping out, but all the while showing you that no matter what you do, you're still just as destructive and dangerous as the evil that surrounds you. This is one of my favorite games even to today. Play it, it will keep you engaged.

												Why I personally feel Far Cry 2 is still the best in the series:1st reason: No Facetious Antagonist. What I mean is there is no over-the-top drama queen playing puppet master over an already lucid reality. (Really, the psycho-male antagonist is getting old)2nd reason: Its Not Afflicted By Action Movie Animal Predators!Basically, youll notice in fc3 and fc4 (the same game just reskinned) that the friendly npc's and otherwise are completely negated by poorly scripted animal interactions. A badger has the same effect on the environment as a mountain lion. Its silly, it feels lazy, and it doesnt instill any confidence in the civilian/paramilitary AI.3rd reason: ITS NOT JUNGLE4th reason: The poorly received weapon damage system. Im sorry but if youve asked for an open world first person shooter to provide you with a proper sense of realism you will invariably have weapon decay. (Thats a given) It also adds a very interesting dynamic to the world; you are always conscientious to your gear and effectiveness.5th reason: Malaria; I know, its one of the most hated aspects of the game mechanic. It also makes the game more interesting because you really do reach a state of panic at times looking for your medication. You really do feel more a part of the world because you are consistently affected by it and in a way that you cant always control (just the same in reality.)6th reason: Its not copy and paste like the latter titles. Its doesnt force you to unlock the map in the generic ubisoft way (Assassin's Creed) and finally........ NO UPLAY!!!!  OMG NO UPLAY!!!!!So there ya go, if you can get over the ai (or man up and mod the ai a bit with the realism mod) and if you can look past the more repetitive missions (your an idiot if you think the other titles arent repetitive) then youve got an underrated gem on your hands.Thanks for reading!NO UPLAY WOOOOOOOOOOO!Puma~

ber 9, 2016
												One of my favourte games of all time, everytime I stop playing its lure draws me back into it, a fantastic world while not adding to the gameplay with random events, immerserses the player in a war torn Africa. Gueardpost litter the road which creates an uneasy feeling of isolation as you, a lone mercenary must choose to sneak past or run in guns blazing. Having started a new playthrogh on the Infamous diffiuculy (Dylan's Realism Mod) I must say that the tension is a firefight keeps me engaed for hours, stalking an enemy outpost as you silently kill the snipers is a as satifying as the moment you clear out the gurardpost and not a single shot is fired by the enenmy. However the game does have its nagetives, the respawning outposts may make you angry, I do appreciate the added challenge having to tackle it agiain, maybe this time I attack from a diffrent angle or try a diffrent weapon. Keeps the game feeling fresh, the only time this really beacame an issue is there a outlost near the fort where you must give the Prince his Father's ring, the outpost tends to respawn too quickly and because of the dense foilage, its very hard to engage in combat. The stealth mechanics aswell appear to be very strange, ranging from "Wow how did he not hear that',"I'm so clsoe to him how does he ot see me" to "How the heck did he know where I was". The enemy AI reacts strangly to stealth as they could be as oblivius as a rock or as aleart as an eagle with x-ray goggles .  Other than a few dumb moments the AI is this games is fantastic! If you fire apon them with a sniper rifle they will run into cover and hide, while other gurads will flank your location. They communicate in comabat and dicuss and carry out tactics in real time. If they lose sight of you they begin searching the immidiate area, confidently shelling put insults, while if you slay too many of his buddies, they begin to get scared. If you wound a soldier, his friend will carry him to safety. One point that really set this as one of my favourate video games is the games interaction with fire, one small ember can set a whole guard post on fire and these interations with the environment that truely creates an authentic game world, where the AI reacts postivly or naegtivly to the spreading wildfire. You start one simply by shooting a oil lamp with the dart rifle creating a distraction as you move in. While fire does carry over into Far Cry 3, its lush tropical forests does not really empashise the deadly viral spreading of a wildfire like Far Cry 2 can. If you always thought about playing this game, get it on a sale and the Dylan's Realism Mod, it truly pushes the game into another level as you are as fragile as your enimies. If enjoy a game where you like choosing to fight or stay stealthy, this game for you. At 4K on the GTX 1080, this game looks stunning and runs like butter smooth!!

												This game isn't for the faint of heart. It's a brutal slog through a nameless war-torn country in Africa where everything is against you. Both warring factions will attack you on sight, vehicles break down, and guns will degrade and jam on you when you need them the most.Whereas Far Cry 3 & 4 give the player a sense of empowerment over their surroundings, this game makes you feel oppressed by the terrible environment you're in. The African environment can be monochromatic at times but overall looks good and even gives a surreal element to the game (where are all the citizens??).After playing FC3 & 4 it was nice coming back and playing through this game for the contrast. I give major props to Ubisoft for taking a huge chance to make a game like this and mostly succeeding.

content:
r 8, 2015
												Far Cry 2, although it's not even really a sequel to Far Cry, is an amazing game. Why did they call it Far Cry 2? I don't know. The only similarities between the two titles involve the driving mechanics and the shooting mechanics. Otherwise, they have nothing in common.However, in my opinion, Far Cry 2 is the better game. While Far Cry had a more involving story, Far Cry 2 had a more interesting setting. The open world, fictional, war torn, central African country that your mercenary character arrives in is immersive and glorious. From savanahs, to jungles, to deserts and sand dunes, to valleys, Ubisoft Montreal packed everything you might find in a central African country into this 16 square mile playground. The towns are small and sparse, but the wildlife you find in between will capture your bewilderment. This, simply put, is a fully realized environment. And it's absolutely stunning.On the story side of things, the only thing I have to say about it is that it could have been more inspired. Basically, you choose a mercenary at the beginning of the game, and you play as that mercenary. The rest of the mercs on this list end up being your "buddies". Anyway, the story of the game is that you, an assassin for hire, was sent to this fictional country to kill "The Jackal", an international arms dealer who is supplying both factions that are fighting for power. Well, as soon as you get to this country, your malaria kicks in and "The Jackal" ends up saving you. "The Jackal" is, hands down, the most interesting character in the game. His philosophy about the current state of the country and his knowledge of politics invoke that he has no personal interest in whoever wins, but he is moralistic in that he does care about the civilians. After he leaves you for dead with a gun and machete, you escape and are saved by one of the faction generals who will task you with saving your first buddy. This is where the game gets repetitive, at least it seems to.Eventually, you'll save every buddy traversing through each area, doing missions for both faction leaders, doing missions for gun runners, doing missions for a mysterious contracter (assassinations). And, without going into details, these missions aren't that interesting. The only interesting moments honestly involve the few cutscenes you have with "The Jackal". But that doesn't mean the story is bad. It's just fleshed out with mercenary work as you are, after all, an assassin for hire. Eventually, you'll travel south to another part of the country where the remainder of the game takes place and more of the same is done. You find more buddies, you do more missions for the APR and the UFLL, and the, endgame.In terms of gameplay, this game is amazing. The hyper realism (except for car repairs which are the opposite of realistic) is splendid. Your gun will wear down and jam, you have to perform quick self surgeries if near death, branches and shrubs sway out of the way, the HUD is completely off when driving or running around, you have to take malaria pills to fight the malaria. The other interesting aspect is the use of diamonds as a form of currency. This is certainly much in line with how some African countries are due to a lack of a formal government.To summarize, brilliant FPS despite the weak story. And it's not even a weak story, it's just that the story was so sparse. The Jackal is such a great character, though, that he ends up saving the story.9.3/10

content:
6, 2016
Intro:Far Cry 2 was considered a good game at the time of release, but its gotten a lot of hate over the years.While it can definitely get repetitive, I still think its a pretty fun game and worth your time if you can get it for a couple dollars.Gameplay:The gameplay is pretty self-explanatory. Its a first person shooter. You kill some dudes, drive somewhere, talk to a guy, repeat.Don't take that as a means of negativity though, I actually enjoyed this game a good bit.The controls are very tight and responsive. The gunplay just feels good. When it comes to guns, there is a currency and ways to unlock new ones as you progress. I liked having things to work toward. After purchasing a gun it goes to a gun room where you can permanently access it. You are able to take weapons from enemies, but they'll be old and occasionally jam so saving up to buy your own is ideal.That's one thing I'll mention now - Older weapons do jam. You can tell when a weapon is old because it'll be dirty and rusted. This seems to be a very big complaint with the game, but I had no issues with it. Weapon deterioration is there to encourage you to swap your guns out. There's many safehouses around the map where you can retrieve stored weapons so its not a big deal and I almost never dealt with my guns jamming.When it comes to the missions, you'll be accepting specific objectives. There are a bunch of sidequests all over the place as well that are quite rewarding. Completely optional though; you can just carry on with the story missions if you prefer.While you will run into some more unique missions on occasion, you're usually going through a number of unique locations and taking out everyone. Sometimes you'll rescue someone or stop a delivery truck. Its pretty basic, but can be fun. One problem is this game lacks in stealth department, with the exception of a couple weapons such as the dart rifle. I found it pretty fun sniping people with it from far away, but its insanely easy to get spotted and have your cover blown if you're using anything else.The game can get repetitive and another common complaint is these camps set up around the map. Driving through them almost always gets a group of enemies chasing after you. This can slow gameplay down and become a bit of a pain. In most cases you can drive around the camps to avoid this, but you shouldn't have to do that in the first place.So the map itself? Its a pretty good size. You'll start out with only half the map though. As you progress through the story you'll eventually uncover the second half. When it comes to safehouses and some other locations, you'll have to discover them. If you like collecting in games then that's something that might keep you busy as well as finding hidden boxes that have your main currency in them. There's a couple towns, some bus stations for faster travel, and a ton of sidequests to run into.Another thing to mention is driving is your main transportation. You'll want to find vehicles. The driving mechanics are pretty good. There is fast travel, but it requires you go to a specific point before using it and it also advances the time which can be obnoxious. The day/ night cycle is fine and all, but some objectives are harder at night. You can always sleep in a safehouse to pass the time though.I do want to point out how immersive this game is to me. I really loved wandering around the world and taking on the missions. Sure, its simple but the atmosphere of the game really pulled me in. I also love how even the map is an item you pull out in front of you rather than a HUD icon. While this isn't a roleplaying game, there's definitely room to roleplay your own character - similar to games like Skyrim or Fallout. I found it pretty fun for that, but it requires you to be a huge nerd with some imagination!One final nitpick is there's something like 8 or 12 characters to pick from. All of them are males. The game was meant to have 4 female characters, but cut them out for absolutely no reason. I have no issues playing a dude, but does every game have to be such a sausage fest? Why completely cut out the female characters?Complaints aside, I really enjoyed the gameplay despite its simplicity.Story, Visuals, & Music:Far Cry's 2 story isn't too deep, but its enough to keep you going. I won't spoil anything but it ended up being somewhat satisfying and the way the storyline is setup worked pretty well.This game might be a bit old now, but it still looks great. The graphical quality is pretty nice with high textures and impressive lightning. The foilage could be better, but this was what.. 2008?For a game that's almost 10 years old, it looks amazing. The only problem is its incredibly dull and washed out. There's so much detail that is hardly noticeable with the washed out color scheme. Fortunately, this is an easy fix with ReShade or SweetFX. There's been a number of configs released for this game that really bring out its beauty and making your own isn't too difficult either.As for the audio, it definitely sets that Africa feel. The music may have not been memorable, but it really helped with the immersion aspect!PC Version:This port is a bit of a pain. Its nothing like Dark Souls or Saints Row 2, but its not perfect.Going into windowed mode and back to full screen always messed up my resolution. It would be stuck in 720p until I restarted. The game also has a horrible feeling stutter. I had to use the console to cap my FPS with a command. This was the only way I got rid of the stuttering. You might be able to make an autoexec to do it for you, but I'm not sure.There are some mods for this game. Nothing mindblowing, but some of the issues I mentioned like enemies at camps chasing you, weapons jamming, and stealth are vastly improved through mods out there. I've never tried them myself, but they're definitely worth looking into.I have no idea if the multiplayer servers are still up. I don't think they are, but this is one of those singleplayer games with the MP tacked on. You won't be missing much if you can't play it.Conclusion:Far Cry 2 may not be some amazing game nowadays and I imagine the sequels are superior, but it was pretty cool for its time. I think the game still holds up, especially for people who enjoy getting immersion.It may not be something worth a bunch of money, but if you can get it cheap then definitely try it out.I think its still a pretty good game, despite being a little repetitive and having some minor issues.

												No game has ever ended for me quite the same way Far Cry 2 did. That is, I didn't see it through to the end at all, at least the indended end. What happened instead is that about halfway through, I accidentaly shot my sister-in-arms while she was bleeding into the dusty sub-Saharan soil, begging me for help. You see, when one of your "buddies" goes down in a firefight, a plume of blue smoke will direct you to their location. You then have the option to either heal them with a magic syrette, leave them to their fate or, it turns out, blow their brains out right there and then. That latter option is denoted with the prompt "Press 2 for handgun". Clear enough, you'd think. Except I had been under the impression that "handgun" in this context would mean hauling the buddy to their feet and dragging them to safety, while fending off remaining assailants with a sidearm in your free hand. Because that is precisely what the buddies themselves will do for you when you've eaten one too many helpings of cold lead. So when instead of lending a helping hand, I watched myself put a gun to my friend's head and pull the trigger, I was left agape. Literally agape. As in, my mouth was hanging open and I was staring at the screen, for a good minute or so. After that, I drove around aimlessly for an hour or so, picking random fights, absent-mindedly going through the motions to complete a side mission. After that, I hopped onto a boat, drove out to a rocky island in the middle of a lake, climbed to the highest point I could reach, dropped an IED at my own feet and blew myself to hell, And thus ended the short and miserable career of Andre the Haitian. Definitely recommended.

content:
y 1
												far drive 2, I mean far cry 2, is a sandbox GTA-style shooter set in some african desert-jungle where you travel miles and miles and miles for each mission to merely shoot a guy or blow something up. and each time you hop into a car or jeep, you're tailed by some angry black men who want you ♥♥♥♥ing dead. I could sum up the game like that<, but that would be a bit boring, wouldn't it, let alone pessimistic as all hell. to put it more cheerfully: far cry 2 is a game that is as frustrating as it is enjoyable. make what you want out of that description. for a game where you're doing a ♥♥♥♥ of a lot of travelling, I have to admit that it pulls it all off rather well. the good thing about this system is that the map is lovely and big (it's very geographically diverse too which is even better), meaning you're not going to feel isolated in a tiny urban city area like you might feel when playing a game like saints row or GTA 4. the problem with the large degree of travel, however, is that you can only save your progress pretty much *after* you've beaten a mission. that's a huge problem because if you're travelling what literally seems like miles just to reach the objective, and you die in the heat of a shootout that follows, that means you have to go back to the beginning and disregard the fact that you've just wasted about half an hour of your precious life. either this is a pretty thrilling mechanic where you actually have a lot on the line, or it will send your controller routinely flying through the air.the graphics are surprisingly very crisp, especially for a game made in 2008. I played this game for years on the xbox 360 and the upgrade in picture quality on the PC is quite remarkable. if you had told me this game was only a few years old, I'd happy believe you, because it really does look good for its time. the enemy AI, while very responsive, can be quite bipolar. sometimes I swear the enemies have ♥♥♥♥ing spidey-senses and will spot you from about 100 feet away, even when you're only poking your head out from beyond a tree. they give enemies on MGS4's boss extreme settings a run for their money, that's for sure. but in other situations, you might come walking amongst them for a good 20 seconds until they actually realise that you're the enemy. it's quite a strange AI system. the gameplay itself, disregarding this, is pretty addictive, at least when you're on a winning streak. you can upgrade your weapons in a significant manner by doing side missions and this actually feels as if you're beefing up your character which gives this game a layer of RPG elements. you'll need to beef up your character too or else the game is going to absolutely slaughter you, especially if you're playing on at least normal difficulty. thankfully, these side missions are a nice break from the main story line. the vehicles, too, are very open for your usage and if you wanted to get from point A to B in, say, a boat, or a hang glider, it's all possible, but admittedly either finding the alternative vehicles is challenging or they simply aren't up to scratch (especially the boats when they crawl up the rivers like a ♥♥♥♥ing slug until you hit top speed). the currency system as well, which is rough diamonds, is also pretty nice, and it means you aren't limited to just getting the means to upgrade your rig by doing the missions in that diamonds can be found in the wild. lastly, the buddy system is a really nice new feature in such a game which I think delivers a huge deal of depth for a shooter like this. when your buddies stick their neck out for you and end up getting killed, it really is a sad sight to behold.oh, and did I mention dat map editor? good sweet jesus. pretty outstanding if you ask me. if you wanted to play sims creator mode but in far cry 2 instead, this is how you do it. and it's pretty fun. sure, it might be more trouble than it's worse when it will take you a massive amount of time to create a map that isn't shockingly bad, but so long as you're patient, like you'll need to be in all other departments in far cry 2, then it's worth the investment. evidently, far drive 2 is a flawed game. nobody can deny that. but it offers something GTA and its army of clones (saints row, sleeping dogs, red dead, etc) can't: an actual ♥♥♥♥ing challenge. sure, challenging games can only be challenging if they are occasionally frustrating, maddening and infuriating, but at the end of the day, I'd rather an experience like this where I feel like I'm actually a mortal human than some unkillable son of a ♥♥♥♥♥ - the former is a lot more fulfilling, and thankfully, far drive 2 isn't so challenging that it's unplayable. I'd compare the experience to the dark soul games - it's definitely a test of endurance. if you're an instant gratification style gamer - this game will get a 6 for you, if that. if you're a player who appreciates a good challenge where you actually have to sit tight and be patient - boost this game up to a 9 at max. personally, I'm tending towards the latter end with a 8/10 - not recommended for everybody, but it will definitely please a certain niche.

												What I liked:- Attention to detail: Wildfires spread, crappy guns jam, foliage conceals you. So many things are unexpectedly realistic.- Novel setting: Very few games are set in an African landscape, and this one pretty much makes it a main character.- Total immersion: There are no forced third-person cutscenes, and the HUD only appears when needed or when you press the "Reload" key.What I didn't care for:- Buddies are fragile: You can only successfully rescue a near-death buddy three times. This means you have to metagame if you want to keep a buddy alive.Recommendations:- Don't worry about having played the first Far Cry beforehand; there are no story ties between that game and this one.- Play it like Fallout 3 or Red Faction Guerrilla, not like Call of Duty or Gears of War. Explore, take side missions, and approach fights tactically rather than recklessly.- Turn off the music; it's not bad music, but it causes you to miss subtle audio cues.

												I bought Far Cry 2 for $3.39 about three days ago on steam and let me tell you thats a steal. I got about 20 hours of gameplay out of it and I bet you could get more if you weren't like me. (I used -GameProfile_GodMode 1 as soon as I finished the tutorial) So essentially I didn't die a single time in the game. I enjoy games when I'm unstoppable and here's why I think you should get this game. (For no more than $5 otherwise your wasting money). The game is fun as the story goes back and forth and you face moral dillemmas. The game gives you the illusion of choice however. It tells you to complete a mission you can do this or that. The story lets you think you are writing it and participating, but you aren't, you're just following along. The game's missions do get repetitive as its only assassinate this guy or blow this thing up. I payed $3 and cheated through the whole game so I wasn't expecting too much. As for replayability, its a Far Cry game so there is none. Also there are no achievements which give me no incentive to find stuff or kill guard posts. In Far Cry  3, there were achievements, and I was playing on Xbox so achievements mean something, so there was a reason to go do something in the game. Since I finished the game 5 mins ago, I don't think I'll be revisiting it. BUT, it was worth all 339 of my pennies and I would gladly pay 339 pennies for another Far Cry game. It is what it is, a shoot em up with nice scenary so don't expect too much.

												EDIT: I suggest giving Far Cry 3 a look. I hear it's pretty similar to this one but better in most ways. Compare some videos to decide which one you want.First thing's first: it's a shallow game. It could have been better in many ways. They could have made the world more lively. They could have tried a bit harder with the missions. They could have made a better story. They could have (done much more), but they didn't. I haven't looked into it, so consider this anecdotal in the purest form, but I would wager that it was rushed for release or held back by being designed for consoles.One thing you'll notice is that the game is still beautiful 7 years down the road, and despite being a game made for consoles first. The shadows, while not as fine as modern games, are still extremely efficient for how good looking they are, which is what mostly contributes to the beauty of the game. You can play on highest settings and still get very good performance on any semi-modern PC. One of the ways they get such great performance out of good shadows is the clever way they hide the level of detail scaling. If you pay attention during the opening cutscene when the trucks pass in front of you -on ultra- you'll notice how the shadows under them disappear very quickly. In regular play, this is almost entirely hidden by clever level design with high usage of obfuscation; that is to say, very compartmentalized to a big wide open area with a limited amount of "dynamic" shadow objects like cars and characters, supplemented with great-looking grass everywhere and clever usage of trees. The grass and trees, which move and react semi-dynamically to random wind patterns, produce seemingly dynamic shadows (don't know exactly if they are dynamic or static; if it's dynamic, it's extremely efficient on resources; if it's static, they look very dynamic) that react particularly well with the pretty lighting method the game uses. Remember: It was made first and foremost for the limited hardware of the Xbox 360. They deload all rendering of areas you are no longer in while keeping the areas still loaded in memory so there is no loading time, keeping the game openworld. All of the system load in the game is due to graphical fidelity, very low CPU usage is observed due to the mechanics of the game, which works perfectly for consoles which have subpar CPUs but usually good GPUs to keep down prices. You'll notice that console games are rarely complex for CPU-based actions like lots of pathfinding enemies; just an observation I wanted to point out, totally unrelated to this review.The game is "atmospheric" and "immersive", since I'm tired and don't know a more clever way to describe it. It pulls you in and really makes you feel like you're in Africa. It really "feels" hot and dry. You can "feel" the heat applied by the light on your character's arm. The sound design is incredibly detailed, and the beauty of the world never strains your suspension of disbelief.The gameplay is shallow and underrealized. As the Steam review of the game, by the user Koltraiin had said, "No elephants, Lions, Cheetahs, Snakes, Crocodiles." This is indicative of the shallowness of the game; they could have given it more, but it simply wasn't there. With all this in mind, I find the game fun to play. It's a unique experience for a unique game, and despite being shallow in gameplay it's a great deal for 10 dollars and it goes on sale fairly often. The biggest downside to the game is being a Ubisoft title, and requiring a Ubisoft account to play online.
