r 3, 2014
												[Played on Hardest difficulty setting with music off]If you're a fan of Far Cry 3 and are interested in trying this one out, be warned that it might not be what you're expecting.  It's more closely related to games like S.T.A.L.K.E.R. than any of the other games in the Far Cry series.  It's brutally unforgiving and slanted more towards realism and immersion than action-adventure.  The world is large, but exploration isn't necessarily a large part of the gameplay, as the only real purpose for doing so is finding diamonds, hidden tapes, and golden guns -- none of which are particularly essential to the experience of the game.At its core, the game is about tense gunfights and missions, and the different tactics you can use to ensure your survival.  The game has a robust array of different systems that organically create compelling moments -- last second escapes into the jungle while bullets whiz past you, guns jamming at the least opportune moment and forcing you to flee for the nearest sign of cover, buddies arriving just in the nic of time to save you from an otherwise unwinnable firefight, enemies whom you thought you had killed crawling to their knees and shooting you in the back for revenge -- the list goes on and on, and I'm still discovering new possibilities after hours of play.  Playing with the music turned off increases the tension in the game IMMENSELY, as you never know if there's an enemy around you just waiting for the perfect time to blast you apart and ruin the last ten minutes of progress you'd made.  You'll find yourself checking every corner, listening intently for footsteps or enemy chatter, and cursing yourself when you inevitably miss that lone gunman who finishes you off as soon as you step into the open.The narrative of the game is also smart and very sensible and aware of the topics which it brings up, which is a helluva lot more than you can say for most modern military shooters.  Don't expect to leave this one feeling like the hero.tldr;It's absolutely brilliant, especially if you're into S.T.A.L.K.E.R.-like games and emergent gameplay.

												Far cry 2 is, let's say... less than ideal. Long ago I had even anticipated this game to be absolutely awesome, reality however didn't meet my expectations. The original Far cry at the time it appeared was a masterpiece that I enjoyed immensely. It was absolutely gorgeous, engaging to play and overall it just felt good. Far cry number two however falls short or gets you annoyed in several different parts. First of all when I started playing, I wasn't expecting it to be an Africa based awful driving simulator. There's way too much driving around in an open world that has little less activities to do than to shoot at everyone because everyone is extremely mad at you for existing. The world feels empty. How the AI works and behaves is questionable and because the enemy guys' bare chests are actually kevlar or something even sturdier you find yourself asking is this game really a game worth playing. I would go as far to say that it isn't. Too much repetition, too much boring driving and too much forced confrontations with foes that merely want to slow your progress in an annoying way (destroying the engine of your car so you have to stop and fix it). It isn't all bad however. It brings up some interesting points in the story off how cruel a civil war truly is, the greed of mankind and all sorts of nasty things. The game can look pretty freaking beautiful at times especially on daytime. Some of the guns feel pretty nice to shoot until they jam or break completely and won't shoot anymore. I did finish the game and at the end I felt both relief and contentment. There are just a lot more and better FPS games to be had than this. Don't waste your time. The predecessor of Far Cry 2 was a better game and so is the successor as well. Better to spend your money on something completely different. Or maybe similar but better if the type of game ticks well with you.

Stupid...especially when one path could have easily allowed the player to live. But all my choices were made for me before I even began playing. AT LEAST I DIE SAVING REFUGEES AND NOT MURDERING THEM!!! Thank you for throwing me that bone, Ubisoft. But mostly its like Ubisoft is saying: "Thanks for buying Far Cry 2, an excericise in moral-dilemas with no "good ending". Enjoy wasting 80 hours of your life as you wander aimlessly through this open world, killing everything you see untill...we make you kill yourself.  F^#k you, Murdurer!"

er 29, 2014
												Modern shooters have become little more than corridor crawls. You enter a mission and are funneled through the map with almost no deviation available. As far as the possibility of "next-gen" world building goes, shooters are stuck in a rut. Interestingly enough, Ubisoft made a valiant effort to push the FPS genre forward back in 2008.Far Cry 2 is one of the most invigorating ideas for a shooter that I've ever played. It doesn't always succeed in it's ambition, but the sense of freedom and the massive size of the world lend themselves to some fantastic moments. Those moments are spread a bit thin, though.While the very first thing you do in the game has an objective, the next 16 hours are pretty much you exploring. There are light story elements driving some of your actions, but you would be forgiven for not knowing that a plotline even exists. Your starting goal is simply "Kill the Jackal" and that is about as far as the narrative goes.This is the biggiest flaw with the game. There is no urgency in anything you are doing. You could easily spend years combing over every inch of the game world and never feel obligated or inclined to tackle any missions. While that is very intriguing as a launching point, it makes for a game that feels lackadaisical and pointless.When you do take up a mission, that is when the game starts to breathe. The fast travel spots are rarely convenient, so you are (almost always) forced to find your own path. The in-game map can help you from getting lost, but it doesn't point out any direction to you. You simply need to chart your own course.During your travel to the objective spot, you often run into bandits. This emergent style of gameplay leads to some fantastic shoot outs that have you scrambling for your life. These moments do happen a bit too often to stay truly enveloping, but barely dodging a missile and sniping guys across a chasm never cease to be quick fixes of joy.When you finish a mission, you simply are left with nothing. The currency system in this game is almost entirely worthless. Since your weapons can break down or jam at random intervals, it makes some sense to want to buy fresh ones that you can replenish. Seeing as how you run out of ammo fairly quick, there doesn't seem to be a need to buy those weapons; just grab them off the endless amounts of bodies you pile up.There is also the threat of malaria consuming you, which can make for some tense shootouts where a question of your mortality comes into play. Honestly, though, apart from some flashy effects on the screen, the whole malaria side of the game seems like an excuse to extend the length. You have to undertake missions devoid of originality to get more medication and it just ends up feeling like wasted time.I find it hard to remain angry at this game. It took me several months to muster up the desire to even see the conclusion, but the moments of bliss I encountered cannot be understated. I can't think of any game on current generation systems that even comes close to capturing the amount of freedom you are given.Developers love to throw around the claim that their game will allow you to "go anywhere and see anything." Ubisoft is pretty much the only one that let you do this. Traveling through most of Far Cry 2, though, you begin to wonder if you really want to see every facet of the map.All in all, I won't say the game is bad. I don't even think it's bad. While there are some crashes here and there, everything works as it should. Enemies are sometimes smart and I never fell through the gameworld. I just wished I could travel around faster. I would also have loved to have a sense that my actions were doing something.For the average gamer, though....I would take a pass. A game like Far Cry 2 takes a lot of maturity to conquer. It's joys are not quick and easy to obtain. A lot of effort needs to happen on the player's part to make anything of this game. If you're willing to sit through some rough terrain, you'll eventually find the diamond in the rough that lies at the core of Far Cry 2.6/10

As such, there is not a very good storyline compared to Far Cry 3, where every mission takes place for a reason, and you feel like you've progressed every time you complete a mission.The AI and detection is a little janky, much smoother in Far Cry 3, and there is no detection meter in this game to tell you if you're being seen. Taking over outposts is also a finicky business, sometimes you take them over by walking around them, sometimes you can kill the inhabitants, wait up to 10 minutes and still nothing!It could be that I'm misinformed and playing it wrong, however as it is now Far Cry 3 is far superior and better value for money. Speaking of money, the only way to earn it in this game is through completing missions or finding it in chests around the map, there is no looting enemies. This seems a little weird, so if you want to buy a new pistol, you have to go complete an entire mission or go hunting for boxes of diamonds.The map is much larger however, and as open world games go this is rather good. Combat isn't all that bad, a decent variety of guns, and driving is a lot better than other games.All in all, I'd give it 4 out of 10, although I'll re-review this game after completing it most likely.

content:
ber 25, 2015
												Far Cry 2 is tedious, but if you value immersion above being fast-paced then you'd be hard pressed to find a better game. The empowerment you feel from playing the game comes from you persevering through mechanics that have been made more difficult than it is in typical FPS games by integrating real-world aspects, sometimes to unrealistic extremes. Playing through the campaign at max difficulty (makes you about as squishy as every NPC mook) with the music turned off (when you're on a far hill quietly picking off enemies one by one, hearing intense combat music play definitely throws you out of the moment).-Your "reputation" acts as your EXP level in the game, and generic NPC's react accordingly. Guards will tell you to f*ck off and frequently threaten you at the beginning of the game, but as you level up their dialogue will descend into professional respect and then to superstitious fear.-The HUD is very intentionally limited; the only onscreen effects are your health and ammo and they quickly fade when not in use. The map and compass have to be brought up like a weapon, and simulate a real paper map with pages of different scales. Sometime's it's a pain in the ♥♥♥ to be at the very bottom of a map section and not be able to see a decent area around you, but it's frustration with something that would be in real life, not frustration with some contrived immersion-breaking game mechanic so it only adds to the immersion.-You have to drive everywhere on the map but destinations are often close together and the geocaching side-quests, constant threat of ambush, and the detail put into making the "HUD" map feel real keep transportation from being boring. It's a rush to be looking down at your map, hear a close gunshot, and jolt back to the road to see a patrol that just came around the corner.-Guns start to jam around after you fire your very limited ammo capacity, but it forces you to plan ahead like a true professional and make full use of your 3 weapons slots. Necessity is the mother of invention, and the situations where you're completely surrounded with everything but your pistol broken because you weren't efficient with your shots make the game memorable. Likewise, the feeling of satisfaction when an outpost hit comes together perfectly because you stored the right backup loadout in your safehouse really seals the deal that you're a true professional and an unstoppable force.-Despite the game's difficulty, it's very feasible to beat the game without dying. The PC's that you didn't choose to play as can be encountered in-game and and turned into allies, and will rescue you if your health drops to 0. They're not invincible though, and they needed to be protected then met in a safehouse if you want to be rescued again by them.Far Cry 2 quickly became one of my favorite games because of how it sucked me in, made me feel weak, and then let me slowly adapt to it until I truly felt like the hardcore motherf*cker that I was supposed to be playing. 10/10, would recommend to anyone who wants to get absolutely submerged in a game.

												As far as I'm concerned, this was the game that addicted me to the "survival shooter" genre and I have never encountered another game with the same realistic-yet-stylised approach which both allowed the feeling of general superiority over enemies while still maintaining a sense of mortality and real danger. Not quite as gritty as S.T.A.L.K.E.R. but also not an overpowered player character experience like Crysis. Both are also great games, but this is the uniquely satisfying middle ground.Being an older game, it is more limited by its engine in many regards, such as enemies' strange ability to see the player from incredible distances and snipe with improbable accuracy, but forgiving it the wrinkles of it's age, it's still a great experience and one I would recommend to anyone interested in a realistically-influenced shooter without the complications of "hyper-realism".

4, 2015
												Beats the ♥♥♥♥ out of 3 in my opinion. This game is a lot like STALKER in that it doesn't give a ♥♥♥♥ about you. It sort of throws you out into the world and says "Good luck." This isn't the cinematic "The world revolves around you" type of game FC3 was. There's no skill trees or press Q to heal all your HP (aside from limited syringes you carry 3 of that can only be replenished by finding them) or free wallhack or crafting system, but if you're into the hard as ♥♥♥♥ but extremely rewarding with various ways to be played type of game, then this is for you.There are a few things common complaints about this game for and I think they're exaggerated and full of ♥♥♥♥.Malaria - I seriously think people are just looking for ♥♥♥♥ to add to their list of ♥♥♥♥♥ing. Malaria turns your screen yellow and eventually killing you, and you have to take a pill to make it go away (you have 5-7 pills I forget exactly how many). This happens every 40 minutes to an hour I think. The game will warn you when you're on your last pill to, and they're easy to get (go to the church, church will tell you to rescue people a.k.a kill the 2-4 guards outside of a house, the people will give you the pills)Weapon jamming - I seriously don't even know how this was an issue for anyone. Heres how it works: If your gun is rusted as ♥♥♥♥ it's prone to jamming, and if it jams too many times it can break. Guns you find lying on the ground are always rusted to hell, and guns get from the store (which gives you an infinite supply to replace yours with) are always in mint condition. They take a LONG time to degrade. So if you run out of ammo and need to use an enemies gun then get ready for the risks.Driving all the way across the map with respawning bases- This is another thing that's exaggerated as ♥♥♥♥. There's a bus system, that's like the stider system in morrowind but free, that can take you to every corner of the map and the center. The only thing that might make it tedious is the respawning checkpoints, but if you use the bus system you'll only have to clear 1-3.Cars breaking down - I think this was an issue for me once every 5 hours of gameplay, and when my car did break down I just jacked the car from whoever shot it up.Here are the ACTUAL flaws with the game IMO:Enemy AI: The AI is so smart it's not even funny, but theres one key problem. If one enemy sees you they ALL see you, this means if one enemy can see you in a shed then his 5 friends know exactly where you are and shoot you through the shed. Not a serious problem unless you're in an area with permeable cover (kinda rare). This is a serious problem though when snipers show up. In farcry 3 the snipers have a laser, but they don't in 2, so later in the game when you get to snipers all the sudden the entire enemy base knows exactly where you are and you have no idea why.Repetition: This wasn't an issue for me because I usually mixed things up, but this game is VERY repetetive. You will visit very different elaborately layed out levels, but to do the same thing. There's basically 4 types of missions they give you (assassinate, blow up convoy, save people, blow up/steal something in a base). Sometimes you'll revisit the same area for a different type of mission. Most of the areas have 3 ways to approach them, and theres a variety of weapons to mix your playing style.

												Far Cry 2 is a handful of good ideas buried under one of the most repetitive games I've ever played. Given the recent trend of reviewers re-examining it and declaring it some sort of misunderstood masterpiece I decided to buy it again (I'd lost my disk ages back) and give it another go. As I remembered it mostly consists of driving a vehicle backwards and forwards around the same parts of the map with the same 3-4 annoying AI troops respawning in the exact same areas and attacking you. If killed they'll simply respawn in their checkpoint ready to chase you next time and ignoring them simply results in them following you forever.Degradation is a nice idea but once your weapons have degraded you have to DRIVE BACK to the arms dealer again since picking up extra weapons from dead enemies is worthless (they are always in horrible condition). To even get weapons in the armoury you have to:A. Do a side mission to unlock the weapons for purchase (more driving to get there and back).B. Find diamonds to pay for the weapons (even more ♥♥♥♥ing driving).You do get small moments of fun now and then. Stealth, for example, sometimes works brilliantly but just as often the AI decides to spot me at random and then everyone in the area will magically know your position. I've got nothing against harder stealth but STALKER did it better even with its flaws. Some of the missions are fun too but most are fairly forgettable firefights.The game would likely have worked much better as a series of linear missions with a semi-open map for each (i.e. Far Cry 1). As usual open world here just means repetitive and empty.Buddy mechanics and the general atmosphere are the only good points but all the atmosphere in the world couldn't make up for the complete boredom of actually playing this game.Finally to add insult to injury the game is buggy as ♥♥♥♥, particularly the tutorial. Activating the DLC is an annoyance also. You might have to spend 1-2 hours hunting for fixes and replaying the unskippable intro/tutorial until it works (10+ minutes every time). As mentioned above the AI also varies between being completely blind and cheating depending largely on their alert status.

content:
7, 2014
												As far as I'm concerned, Far Cry 2 deserves to be remembered alongside the venerated classics of the genre; Half-Life, Deus Ex, Bioshock, and all those other semi-legendary shooters. But at the same time, it's not entirely surprising that it isn't remembered that way.To use a really crappy pun, Far Cry 2 is, in many ways, a rough diamond. It might not shine, but it's just as solid and precious as any other of its kind.Let's start with the good, and the first good thing right off the bat about the game is the setting and atmosphere. How many other shooters take place in sub-Saharan Africa? It's a brilliant premise that's rarely explored in the genre. A war-torn, hostile, exotic setting populated by power-hungry warlords and psychotic mercs? There aren't many other real-world scenarios that would work better as an environment in which to set a shooter of this style, and I find it much more memorable than the exaggerated, tropical setting of Far Cry 3. By Far Cry 4 I was entirely disinterested in the franchise, and never played that game or any later ones. So I can't say anything about them. Far Cry 2's fictional setting is very believable, and the originality and thought put into it is apparent from the get-go.To go along with the great atmosphere are some genuinely impressive visuals, which might sound weird to those who have only briefly played the game. The vanilla color palette is just plain awful, but the effects, textures, models and shaders are all top-notch for a 2008 title, and the Dunia engine has a few nice tricks up its sleeve. A little tweaking with the Sweetfx shader suite goes a long way towards rectifying the brown, muddy colors and is absolutely essential to getting the most out of the graphics and the overall experience, and with the right tweaks the game has massive visual appeal to this day, even compared to some contemporaries like Crysis that are more well-known for their visuals. The graphics are stylized yet realistic without ever really feeling uncanny or too outdated. Again-aside from the questionable color palette-the care put into the visuals is apparent right from the start.All this would just be academic if not for gameplay to truly make the game worthwhile, and FC2 surely delivers in that regard as well. I've always considered Far Cry 2 to be a minimalist shooter, which might sound bizarre when you consider the massive, open world and whatnot. But at its core, there are only a few core elements driving the gameplay here. No shoehorned RPG elements, no crafting, very little NPC interaction, no player-influenced dialogue, not even much of a story. This minimalist, almost barebones approach to gameplay? Well, quite frankly, it's just plain fantastic. One thing I really disliked about Far Cry 3 was the degree of artificial progression in it. By which I mean the skill trees and crafting- this doesn't add flavor to the game as everyone ends up getting everything by the end and it just limits early-game creativity. One term that frequently comes to mind when I think about Far Cry 2 is "emergent gameplay;" that is, progression that is directed by the player instead of the game. There are unlocks and upgrades, yeah, and there is a reason to get them, but the most prominent progression in the game is that of your own playstyle. You start to learn what weapons, what routes, what tactics work the best for you and work from there- instead of being given a list of skills for your character. I'm a huge fan of the concept of character proficiency, but it just doesn't belong in a game like this, and the fact that Far Cry 2 is so aware of that is really refreshing. You never feel truly forced into a gameplay style or scenario you genuinely dislike, a problem many open-world games suffer from.The AI in Far Cry 2 is absolutely insane, to say the least. It's way too smart for its own good much of the time, and while this might seem cheap at times, it's also an excellent catalyst for the aforementioned emergent gameplay and player-directed progression. I remember starting out my initial play through trying to get up close and personal and stealthy, but the AI just isn't stupid enough for that to work. So I shifted to a more distant playstyle- sniping, picking off enemies, constantly on the move- interspersed with aggressive, ballsy assaults when the situation called for it or my position was compromised. Part of the gameplay is learning the AI's tricks and figuring out what works best for you. The AI is advanced enough that there are no glaring exploits to make the game too easy, but at the same time, if you're expecting a stealth shooter you're going to be disappointed. It really contributes to a feeling of overall cerebrality- you can be great at shooters but if you don't plan your moves you won't get far. It's worth mentioning by now that I've been playing with a realism mod on Infamous difficulty, which really is the only way to play as far as I'm concerned. The enemies are a little too spongy in vanilla, but the setup I use can be brutally difficult yet is rarely ever unfair. The gameplay requires analysis and personal experience and I can admit I was frustrated early game that nothing I did seemed to work- probably one of the biggest reasons this game isn't better remembered- but when you get it down the core gameplay is both elegantly simple and constantly engaging, while always feeling personally rewarding.Moving onto some of the weaker points, the sound design is a mixed bag, with guns sounding stock and animations not always syncing properly with sounds, but the ambient noise, dynamic soundtrack and enemy chatter are all pretty memorable.It was at this point in the review I ran out of mentally pre-rehearsed stuff to say. I'm not good at properly reviewing stuff. But yeah this game's rad so play it if it sounds like something you'd play.

2015
												Should have been called driving across Africa.  Fast travel points (bus stations) are scattered and trips to the gun merchant feel unnecessary (should just phone in your order and have them waiting for you at your safe house).  Checkpoints are all over which is okay, but you can't shoot from your car unless on multi-player so you need to hop out at every one in addition to every single car on the road that immediately knows to kill you.  I would have liked an option to bribe guards with uncut diamonds as well, but that isn't an option.  Your safe house weapon crates contain one extra weapon of each type which you have to drop in there from the armory attached to the gun shop - so any of my dozen safe houses magically have a copy of the weapon, but I have to go back to the armory when the weapon breaks after enough use or I'm tired of it jamming all the time?Companions - there doesn't seem to be any point to doing their missions.  They add 1-2 small tasks to gain history with them, but then they easily die and also do not offer anything for having a high history.  Buddy rescue - where they come and save you after you get owned has a long cutscene you can't skip - you also don't cue your buddy rescue up until after you hit the safe house again instead of just automatically after some time.Missions are dull and repetitive - same mission for meds or gun runner every single time!  You also have to appear in person to start every story mission which just drags it out.  Your stealth options are a little limited as well.This game was probably okay in 2008, but really doesn't hold to current standards of a run and gun game.

												Can you say 'underrated?'Yea, you'd better believe it, Far Cry 2 is the best title in the series, for me. Perfect? No, but neither is the rest of the series. Totally satisfying? No, but neither is the rest of the series. Dropping with atmosphere like the knifed fresh corpse of a wilderbeast drips that essential red elixir? You must believe it. And this is a quality that evades the rest of the series entirely.You are [I can't remember I've played too many similar games], a face into which a video game camera has been thrust, itself belonging to a body which has been thrust right into the meatgrinder of a central african (I wanna say 'kinda Kenya but more sandy' though this may be entirely incorrect) civil war, complete with savage flora, savage fauna and savage hearts. You begin the game staring wonderously at the bump map'd face of a taxi driver as he drives you deeper and deeper into a threatening looking square of hell - dissapointingly scaled to accomodate the xbox 360 I believe, but certainly impactful - where he drops at a hotel. You get out, get to your room, get to bed and wake up with infected with Malaria and dodging bullets as fighting has broken out in the town.You escape. You have no idea where you are. The landscape is alien and scary, the locals seem more like human big cats with AKs and a thirst for blood than video game villains, the roars of labouring car engines spark off immediate "GTFO of here!" sprints for cover, trees flex in the breeze, bushes rustle, a hot sun beats down on you like a express post migraine, and you eventually make it to a safe house where a bunch of uncaring locals welcome you to their collective deathwarrant and start giving you orders. You net some pills for the Malaria - things which will always stick with you and occasionally give you cause to run errands for the missionaries who supply them - and a rusty assault rifle and you're loose - free to do what you will, if you dare.The quality of this game is in the oppressive environment which has been really wonderfull captured. Occasional townships light up real nice in dusty battles, blood diamonds litter the map in padded suitcases, militia held checkpoints stare down at you from every hilltop or intersection.Difficult, yes. Challenging, yes. But inaccesible? No. The completionist in me loved this game - finding diamonds is just so easy, though finding them all would be a very lengthy mission indeed. Discovering every portion of the map, likewise a treat in itself. Ticking off enemy base camps and noting down the location of weapons stashes for future reference, all of these tasks are seamless and require one to go out of one's way only very rarely. The sandbox gameplay is so dense and rewarding infact that the campaign is almost a saddle on it - a key final mission of the opening zone became markedly less imposing for me when I realized that it was set in a clifftop fortress which I had comprehensively massacred on my first day in country.Complete that story, those missions, though, because they will eventually open up new areas for you to explore, new people for you to meet (interactable characters are rare but convincing) and new atmosphere to soak up.This game is a simulator, a simulator of that gritty, horrifying mode of hot Central African civil war that movies like Blood Diamond and co just about hinted at. It is not the best game ever made, and it is no the best game available on these pages, but it is a good one, and I would recommend it ahead of the next two games in the series. Or the third one at least, which completely failed to live up to the achievements of this title.

So let's try and summarise it...- Since you are in Africa, and as we all know it, when you are in Africa, everything must be filtered through some awful brownish/yellowish colour to remind you... That you are in Africa... Or Mexico, or wherever... It is not pleasant for eyes...- Enemy AI goes from completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mushroom IQ to ultra intelligent super computer/robot from far future with integrated infra red/night vision/cat's ears...- About 50% of time fighting, you will turn around like an idiot, trying to pinpoint exact location of enemy who is shooting...- Once you shoot at them, they are able to see you even if you are laying silently in 1 meter high grass...- And, if that was not enough, once you clear out an enemy camp, return 10 minutes later, everyone are alive and kicking! ♥♥♥♥ yeah! :)- Missions... Oh, side missions... Every mission is the same... They tell you some completely irrelevant back story, and tell you to kill/destroy someone... You go to the mission location, there are 2-3 cars and usually a truck going in circles (!?)... Destroy the truck, and TA-DA, diamonds are automatically in your pocket!- Talking about cars... There are, I don't know, maybe 4 different vehicles in game... I cannot find any difference between them when driving...- And talking about driving... Wow, since most of the map is awful brownish terrain, you won't feel like exploring... There is nothing to explore, world is ugly (except for few exceptions), you will end up driving from one part of the map to the other all the time... Especially since missions are almost always as far from as they can be, from the point you took them... There are some bus stations, but they are so rare, it's easier to just drive...- Also, player character has a malaria... So, from time to time, you'll need to take pills, or survive through vertigo effects... It might be important for story, but I still have a feeling that it is too burdensome for gameplay...- As, it is usually a problem with games, main character is a mute retard...And now for Pros;- It has a QUIT button. I really tried to like this game, but...Yeah, it's actually one of the games I cannot find any good thing about; it's boring, repetitive and full of little problems and bugs... 												1-3/2016 Original Review:Picture Dead Island.  Now, take away all the zombies, skill trees, interesting characters, and set the game in Africa.  Hey look, you've got Far Cry 2, a game with a meaningless protagonist who loves doing people's chores!  I get why people could enjoy this game, but I really didn't.  I have yet to finish the game and I'm dreading having to press on.  Here's some pros and cons to help you understand why:Pros:-Absolutely beautiful atmosphere/map.  Looking out over a desert, lake, or bayou at sunset is amazing.-This game's multiplayer was my childhood, and the custom maps feature is awesome.  Playing escape maps with friends online holds some great memories for me.  Unfortunately, online play for this game is near dead now, but if you can get a chance to play some custom maps with friends they're fun.Cons:  Oh god, where do I start.  -Gameplay wise, get ready for some repetition.  Talk to an NPC, get a quest, drive to the other side of the damn map (or use the poorly implemented quick travel system), shoot people or blow something up, rinse & repeat.  It feels like a sin for a game with such a vast environment to feel so slow, dry, and outright boring.-This game is literally driving Simulator 2009 edition.  You have to drive so much, only to be interrupted halfway to your destination which feels 35253 miles away by some random mercenary who thought it'd be tactical to literally ram the hell into you.  This occurs WAY too often and gets extremely annoying.  -The game is divided into two acts.  The problem with this, is by the end of act one the game feels like it's ready to end.  But it doesn't.  It goes into act two.  This literally made my jaw drop.  I was so ready to be done with this driving simulator.-If you're looking for a good story, don't come here.  In the beginning of the game, your character gets an idea in their mind of what they want to do.  Without spoiling anything, I'll say that at literally EVERY opportunity they get to carry out their objective, they're hindered physically (in pain, can't move, etc etc).  Total bs.  If this was the main goal of the game, I'd go to think they'd lift a finger a little more.  I think at the point in the game I'm currently at I can see why the protagonist might be changing their mind about killing the Jackal, but since our character doesn't talk we have no way of knowing their intentions.  Overall if you're a fan of the Far Cry series give this a whirl.  Otherwise stay away, stay far away.  5/101-7/2016 UPDATE:I've been trying to finish this game, and oh has it been hard.  Not gameplay difficulty wise, but hard as in difficult to sit through this p.o.s...This game is a perfect example of where a company threw the golden rule of games out the window: Gameplay over Graphics.  This game is gorgeous, but the gameplay is dry and repetative, not fun at all no matter how many different ways there are to approach missions.  This is because they're all the same exact thing, as I discussed in my older review above.  This game crashes constantly for me.  I was able to deal with this, up until now.  I have a few different save files that I've been making throughout the game just as a safety, and boy I'm glad I did.  I was at 88% game completion on my primary save, and I thought, I haven't saved in a while, I better save before end game!  Guess what?  I went to save, the game crashed, my heart sank.  "No," I thought to myself , "please don't let my save be corrupted."  Sure enough, it was.  Back to 73% game completion for me.  I get to do all those repetitious missions over again.  Woo-hoo.  I may add more comments when I do manage to finish this glitchy pile of crap.  But, until then, this is me signing out, advising you to not waste your time on this installment of the Far Cry franchise.1-7/2016 UPDATE 2 (Several hours later):Well, I did it.  I managed to finish the game.  I managed to combat losing my save progress by creating multiple new save files instead of overwriting the same one.  The ending of the game is o.k, but certainly not very good.  Before the ending, the game tries to make you feel as though your choices throughout the second half of the game meant something, but really it just decides slight aesthetic differences (who's present at the end, etc).  I'm in a love/hate relationship with the fact that  all of your friends that you helped throughout the game turn on you and betray you, and you have to in turn murder all of them.   It's a twist that attempts to show the true nature of the world you're in, but also makes little sense after all you've been through.Even the final choice in the game makes no difference whatsoever.  Choice is a complete illusion in this game, which is lame.  I went back to my save just before the final choice and tried the other option, the game ends exactly the same no matter which errand you decide to run.Overall, having finished the game, my opinion isn't very changed.  The ending doesn't redeem the poor gunplay.  It doesn't redeem the annoying as hell A.I. who shoot me on sight without good reason, and who ram my car with their every 5 minutes which made driving so unenjoyable.  The voice acting is shoddy and there's only one or two people who seem to have actually tried to sound convincing.  Neither of this people are the main antagonist, either.It's just not a very good game.Remember Devs, Gameplay over Graphics.Revised score: 3/10P.S:  I hit uninstall on the game and the game opened.  What?

content:
2015
												Should have been called driving across Africa.  Fast travel points (bus stations) are scattered and trips to the gun merchant feel unnecessary (should just phone in your order and have them waiting for you at your safe house).  Checkpoints are all over which is okay, but you can't shoot from your car unless on multi-player so you need to hop out at every one in addition to every single car on the road that immediately knows to kill you.  I would have liked an option to bribe guards with uncut diamonds as well, but that isn't an option.  Your safe house weapon crates contain one extra weapon of each type which you have to drop in there from the armory attached to the gun shop - so any of my dozen safe houses magically have a copy of the weapon, but I have to go back to the armory when the weapon breaks after enough use or I'm tired of it jamming all the time?Companions - there doesn't seem to be any point to doing their missions.  They add 1-2 small tasks to gain history with them, but then they easily die and also do not offer anything for having a high history.  Buddy rescue - where they come and save you after you get owned has a long cutscene you can't skip - you also don't cue your buddy rescue up until after you hit the safe house again instead of just automatically after some time.Missions are dull and repetitive - same mission for meds or gun runner every single time!  You also have to appear in person to start every story mission which just drags it out.  Your stealth options are a little limited as well.This game was probably okay in 2008, but really doesn't hold to current standards of a run and gun game.

content:
y 3, 2012
												Far Cry 2 is a solid game, with great graphics, a cool story, a realistic, open setting and... a lot of respawning enemies. It's pretty much the only downside to this game. The fact that you have to inject yourself, fix your car, that rockets fall down only a few metres away from you on occasion and that fire spreads across the land is all very unique and adds to the atmosphere. But like I said, the enemies keep respawning. And I'm not talking about the 'you close your game and the next you start it the enemies have respawned' kind of respawning. No, more like 'enemies respawn within 30 minutes or so' respawning. It gets very frustrating because at times you get the feeling that you have no influence on the gameworld, that you're doing practically everything for nothing. If you can just ignore that then there's a great game waiting for you here.[Rating: 86/100]
